page.title: Concerns and controversies at the 2018 Asian Games

revision.comment: /* Doping */
revision.text:
A number of concerns and controversies surfaced before and during the [[2018 Asian Games]] in [[Jakarta]] and [[Palembang]], [[Indonesia]].
==Prior to the Games==
Jakarta, consistently ranked as having one of the world's worst traffic congestion problems, is building a subway. However, it will not be ready until 2019, so organizers have proposed closing schools during the event to curb traffic from millions of commuting pupils. Authorities also proposed to set aside toll roads and bus lanes for special official and athlete use during the Games. Jakarta has also instated an [[Odd–even rationing|odd-even licence plate system]] to limit congestion.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-games-asia-indonesia/indonesia-confident-on-asian-games-preparations-traffic-concerns-remain-idUSKCN1GK1CC|title=Indonesia confident on Asian Games preparations, traffic concerns...|last=Davies|first=Ed|work=U.S.|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.talkvietnam.org/2018/07/asian-games-2018-risks-of-traffic-jam-and-terror-attack-concern-organisers/|title=Asian Games 2018: Risks of traffic jam and terror attack concern organisers|date=18 July 2018|work=Talk Vietnam|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
Air pollution also becomes a concern on both cities. Jakarta has long struggled to boost air quality, regularly rated as unsafe by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO) as Jakarta's average score on the Air Quality Index (AQI) had exceeded 100 during early July 2018, once reaching the "unhealthy" range at 171 on 11 AM, Tuesday, 17 July 2018. Palembang also had been constantly under risk of [[haze]] caused by peatland fire during dry season which coincides with the Games. Authorities are looking into the possibility of [[cloud seeding]] to combat the fire hotspots by triggering rainfall in dry areas with flares of salt shot into suitable clouds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://in.reuters.com/article/us-games-asia-pollution/from-cloud-seeding-to-vehicle-curbs-indonesia-fights-pollution-ahead-of-asian-games-idINKBN1K713D|title=From cloud seeding to vehicle curbs, Indonesia fights pollution...|last=Editorial|first=Reuters|work=IN|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-IN}}</ref> Authorities covered a polluted, foul-smelling river near the Asian Games athletes' village in Jakarta with black nylon mesh over fears it will be an eyesore at the showpiece event.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/jakarta-covers-up--stinky--toxic--river-near-asian-games-village-10549506|title=Jakarta covers up 'stinky, toxic' river near Asian Games village|work=Channel NewsAsia|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en-GB}}</ref>
Security is another concern, with the Games taking place just a few months after [[Surabaya bombings|a series of terror attacks]], which killed dozens of people and provoked fear over Islamist militants. Some 100,000 security staff including bomb squad and sniper teams will be deployed in Jakarta, Palembang, and West Java, where the majority of events are hosted. Local police said they have been taking part in a pre-Asian Games crackdown on terror suspects and petty street criminals.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://en.vietnamplus.vn/asian-games-2018-risks-of-traffic-jam-and-terror-attack-concern-organisers/134883.vnp|title=Asian Games 2018: Risks of traffic jam and terror attack concern organisers|date=18 July 2018|work=vietnamplus.vn|access-date=21 July 2018}}.</ref>
The Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) also raised concerns over [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysian men's U-16 national football team]] security issues due to the recent provocations by Indonesian fans at venues and on social media.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2018/08/396949/ocm-look-athletes-safety-asian-games|title=OCM look into athletes' safety at Asian Games|last=Peter|first=Fabian|work=New Straits Times|access-date=5 August 2018|language=en-US}}</ref> Although, it was initially triggered by the [[Instagram|Instagram's post]] of one Malaysian when they were competing the [[2018 AFF U-16 Youth Championship]] at [[East Java]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://jateng.tribunnews.com/2018/07/27/muda-muda-provokator-pemain-timnas-u-16-malaysia-pasang-terbalik-bendera-indonesia|title=Muda-muda Provokator, Pemain Timnas U-16 Malaysia Pasang Terbalik Bendera Indonesia - Tribun Jateng|date=2018-07-27|work=Tribun Jateng|access-date=2018-08-28|language=id-ID}}</ref>
On 21 July 2018, less than one month from the Games, women football venue of Gelora Sriwijaya Stadium in Palembang had been partially damaged in a riot during local football league. At least 335 seats had been destroyed by the mob.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://bola.kompas.com/read/2018/07/21/20005778/kecewa-dengan-manajemen-suporter-sriwijaya-fc-rusak-kursi-stadion|title=Kecewa dengan Manajemen, Suporter Sriwijaya FC Rusak Kursi Stadion - Kompas.com|last=Media|first=Kompas Cyber|date=21 July 2018|work=KOMPAS.com|access-date=21 July 2018|language=en}}</ref>
Officials had held Asian Games' men football tournament drawing three times due to protest from UAE and Palestine which were incidentally not included in the first drawing. Later, Iraq withdrew from tournament which forced officials to rebalance the groups by determining which of Palestine or UAE would be moved to Group C to replace Iraq.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidethegames.biz/articles/1068349/draw-for-asian-games-football-tournament-held-for-third-time|title=Draw for Asian Games football tournament held for third time|last=Mackay|first=Duncan|date=4 August 2018|work=insidethegames.biz|access-date=7 August 2018}}</ref>
Prior to the start of the [[Golf at the 2018 Asian Games|golf tournament of the Asian Games]], several national golf associations complained to the [[Court of Arbitration for Sport]] that Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, Macau and Uzbekistan had possibly entered professional golfers, but the CAS ruled that none of the players were professional as the golf tournament was reserved only for the amateur players.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/games-asia-golf/games-cas-satisfied-asian-games-golfers-arent-professional-idUKL8N1VD3CD|title=Games-CAS satisfied Asian Games golfers aren't professional |agency=Reuters|date=24 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Careem|first=Nazvi|date=23 August 2018|title=Asian Games: pros cut from Sri Lanka golf squad after Hong Kong and others complain about breach of amateur rules|url=https://www.scmp.com/sport/golf/article/2160924/asian-games-pros-cut-sri-lanka-golf-squad-after-hong-kong-and-others|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|location=Hong Kong, China|access-date=24 August 2018}}</ref>
==During the Games==
===Alcohol ban=== The Indonesian Asian Games Organizing Committee ([[Indonesian Olympic Committee|INASGOC]]) banned athletes competing in the Games from consuming alcohol and outside food in their accommodation in the host cities of Jakarta and Palembang. On 28 August 2018, officials said they had confiscated many bottles and cans of beer that athletes and officials had tried to bring in from outside the athletes' villages.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Potkin |first1=Fanny |title=No Drowning Your Sorrows: Indonesia Bans Alcohol at Athletes' Villages |url=http://jakartaglobe.id/news/no-drowning-sorrows-indonesia-bans-alcohol-athletes-villages/ |accessdate=30 August 2018 |agency=Reuters |publisher=Jakarta Globe |date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Alleged gratification===
Since the sales of closing ceremony ticket, Indonesian anti-corruption commission, [[Corruption Eradication Commission|KPK]] has alleged to receive 14 free tickets with 13 of them had not been used. The gratification allegations started when the state enterprises of Indonesia ([[State-owned Enterprise of Indonesia|BUMN]]) bought several tickets, KPK has warned some officials in BUMN to report back of the buying. [[Jusuf Kalla]], Vice President of Indonesia, had declared that "it did not include in gratification because it is less than Rp 10 millions [threshold of official gratification in Indonesia]". Even more, KPK had not known whether it was included in gratifications or not.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dewi|first=Santi|title=KPK Terima 14 Laporan Dugaan Gratifikasi Tiket Asian Games 2018|url=https://www.idntimes.com/news/indonesia/santi-dewi/kpk-sudah-terima-14-laporan-penerimaan-tiket-asian-games|work=IDN TIMES|date=5 September 2018|accessdate=5 September 2018|language=id}}</ref>
===Organizational issues===
During the medal ceremony of [[Swimming at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's 200 metre freestyle|men's 200 metre freestyle]] swimming on 19 August 2018, the flags of the three medalists crashed to the ground due to a technical malfunction. [[Sun Yang]], the Chinese swimmer and the gold medalist of the event, immediately got off the podium, walked to some officials and demanded the medal ceremony to be conducted once again. The flags were re-attached to the broken hoist but couldn't be raised, and the [[March of the Volunteers|Chinese anthem]] was played for a second time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/asia_pacific/sun-celebrates-asian-games-win-upset-over-flag-malfunction/2018/08/19/29fa97cc-a3bc-11e8-ad6f-080770dcddc2_story.html|title=Sun celebrates Asian Games gold medal before flags fall|last=Pye|first=John|date=19 August 2018|work=The Washington Post|access-date=20 August 2018}}</ref>
===Athletics===
On 25 August 2018, [[Hiroto Inoue]] won the Asian Games men's marathon in a controversial sprint finish, with Bahrain later lodging a complaint to race officials, accusing the Japanese runner of barging second-place finisher [[Elhassan Elabbassi]].<ref>{{cite news| url = https://mobile.reuters.com/article/amp/idUSKCN1LA04M| title = Asian Games: Bahrain complain after Inoue wins marathon for Japan | author = Amlan Chakraborty | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 26, 2018}}</ref> Meanwhile, on the same day, a [[cat]] [[pitch invasion|ran into the track]] of the Gelora Bung Karno Main Stadium during the interval of women's 100m qualification competition.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2018-08/26/c_137419050_3.htm| title = Cat runs into track during 18th Asian Games in Jakarta, Indonesia | author = Xinhua | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 26, 2018}}</ref>
===Basketball===
Coach [[Yeng Guiao]] of the [[Philippines men's national basketball team|Philippine men's National Basketball team]] raised doubts on why a Hong Kong referee officiated the match up between China and the Philippines. Despite having its own organized sports body, [[Hong Kong]] is special administrative region of the of China. He questioned the number of China's free throw attempts to the Philippines', 39 foul shots to 15. The Chinese team was assessed to only 16 fouls compared to the Philippines, 25.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.philstar.com/sports/2018/08/23/1845139/no-excuses-yeng-guiao-calls-out-hong-kong-referee#L99T6ZcO1ydb21Xv.99 | title = No excuses but Yeng Guiao calls out Hong Kong referee | author = Joaquin Henson | date = August 23, 2018 | accessdate = August 24, 2018}}</ref>
===Boxing=== In women's 57 kg, Filipino boxer Nesthy Petecio lost a controversial bout against Chinese rival Yin Junhua to the surprise of most of the crowd at the Jakarta International Expo Hall C. Japanese and Turkmen judges ruled in favor of the Filipino while Bulgarian and South Korean judges ruled in favor of the Chinese. The French judge scored a 28-28, but later handed the fight to the Chinese to break the deadlock. Petecio shed tears of anger and stared at the judges. Philippine chef de mission [[Richard Gomez]] said it's a case of “bad call, bad decision and bad scoring” while [[Association of Boxing Alliances in the Philippines]] (ABAP) executive director Ed Picson blasted the result of the bout and appeals to officials “that the judges responsible for this travesty not be assigned to officiate in the coming Philippines fights as judges or referees.”<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.philstar.com/sports/2018/08/25/1845769/petecio-phl-sports-officials-cry-foul | title = Petecio, Phl sports officials cry foul | author = Nelson Beltran | date = August 25, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://manilastandard.net/sports/fightsports/273907/boxing-exec-wants-3-judges-banned-from-philippine-asiad-fights.html|title= Boxing exec wants 3 judges banned from Philippine Asiad fights |date=25 August 2018|work=Manila Standard|access-date=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Football===
[[Luis Milla]], the head coach of [[Indonesia national under-23 football team|Indonesian men's national football team]] called the referee Shaun Evans from Australia 'unfit' after he gave two controversial penalties during a game between Indonesia and the United Arab Emirates. Milla was disappointed because the referee was biased during the whole game. "The referee doesn't have any competence to officiate at the Asian Games. He [Shaun Evans] is not on that level. He's the [opponent’s] 12th player and I am sad that our players' struggle had to end like this," the Spanish coach said. The Indonesian goalkeeper, [[Andritany Ardhiyasa]], added at the press conference, "Today is a sad day for us because we were robbed by [the referee]. The second penalty should not have been awarded".<ref>{{cite news| url = http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/08/24/asian-games-uae-eliminates-indonesia-in-round-of-16-soccer-match.html | title = Asian Games: UAE eliminates Indonesia in round of 16 soccer match | author = Fachrul Sidiq | date = August 24, 2018 | accessdate = August 20, 2018}}</ref>
===Pencak Silat===
On 26 August 2018, in the Semifinal of [[Pencak silat at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's tanding 90 kg|Men's tanding 85 kg to 90 kg]], Muhammad Robial Sobri, a Malaysian athlete, deliberately kicked his Singaporean opponent, Sheik Alauddin Sheik Ferdous, after the Singaporean had fell to the ground.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://theindependent.sg/malaysian-silat-athlete-sparks-uproar-after-illegally-kicking-singaporean-opponent-while-hes-down/| title = Malaysian silat athlete sparks uproar after illegally kicking Singaporean opponent while he’s down | author = Jewel Stolarchuk | date = August 28, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref>
On 27 August 2018, another Malaysian pencak silat athlete, Mohd Al-Jufferi Jamari accused the judges of bias. Even he was walked out off the [[Pencak silat at the 2018 Asian Games – Men's tanding 70 kg|final match]], the furious three-time world champion left a damage in the changing room's partition at venue after the match,<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.nst.com.my/sports/others/2018/08/405445/malaysia-robbed-silat-gold| title = Malaysia robbed of silat gold | work = New Straits Times | date = August 27, 2018 | accessdate = August 28, 2018}}</ref> something for which the Malaysian delegation had apologized.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.cnnindonesia.com/olahraga/20180829214728-178-326029/sekjen-pencak-silat-malaysia-minta-maaf-atas-aksi-al-jufferi| title = Sekjen Pencak Silat Malaysia Minta Maaf Atas Aksi Al Jufferi | work = CNN Indonesia | date = August 29, 2018 | accessdate = September 4, 2018| language=id}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.scmp.com/sport/other-sport/article/2161932/asian-games-indonesia-little-things-they-declare-war-malaysia| title = Asian Games: ‘Indonesia is like that, little things they declare war’ – Malaysia fuming over pencak silat ‘walk-off’ incident | work = South China Morning Post | date = August 30, 2018 | accessdate = September 1, 2018}}</ref> Indonesia had won 14 out of 16 gold medals on offer, while several countries including Singapore and Iran had complain about the judging in this event, claiming that judges are favouring local atheltes.<ref name="silat">{{cite news| url = https://www.scmp.com/sport/other-sport/article/2162113/asian-games-indonesia-rejects-pencak-silat-cheating-claims-says#comments| title = Asian Games: Indonesia rejects pencak silat cheating claims – top official Erick Thohir ‘saddened by fellow Muslim countries’ | work = South China Moring Post | date = August 31, 2018 | accessdate = September 1, 2018}}</ref>
On the other hand, the Indonesian Asian Games Organizing Committee (INASGOC) chairman [[Erick Thohir]], had rejected accusations of cheating, claiming that the game "is open, with people can see it on television and it is clear". Erick also insisted that they have "monitor closely all judges, who are chosen by the Asian governing body".<ref name="silat"/> He added that, "We see the domination of certain countries in sports such as judo, karate and taekwondo. The funny thing is when Indonesia achieves such success, why do people complain?".<ref name="silat" />
==Doping==
On August 24, Turkmenistani wrestler, Rustem Nazarov became the first athlete to fail a doping test. Nazarov had competed in the men's 57 kilograms freestyle event on August 19 and was beaten 12-8 in his first match by India's Sandeep Tomar.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.manilastandard.net/sports/sports-plus/273855/doping-case-hits-asiad-ikee-eyes-history.html|title= Doping case hits Asiad, Ikee eyes history |date=24 August 2018|work=Manila Standard|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
On September 2, Mongolian reigning world champion Orkhon Purevdorj was stripped of the gold medal she claimed in the women's 62 kilogram event. Purevdorj tested positive for anabolic steroid [[Stanazolol]] and received lengthy ban on sporting events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://vietnamnews.vn/sports/465322/mongolia-loses-wrestling-gold-promoting-viet-nams-ranking-in-asiad.html|title= Mongolia loses wrestling gold, promoting Việt Nam’s ranking in ASIAD |date=7 September 2018|work=Việt Nam News|access-date=13 September 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:2018 Asian Games]] [[Category:2018 controversies]] [[Category:Sports controversies]]

revision.comment: pluralized business
revision.text:
{{See also |Cyber Intelligence Sharing and Protection Act}} {{Infobox U.S. legislation | name = Cybersecurity Information
Sharing Act of 2015 | fullname = To improve cybersecurity in the United States through enhanced sharing of information about cybersecurity threats, and for other purposes | acronym = CISA | enacted by = | title amended = | sections created = | sections amended = | leghisturl = https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/senate-bill/754 | introducedin = [[United States Senate|Senate]] | introducedbill = S. 2588 | introducedby = [[Dianne Feinstein]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[List of United States Senators from California|CA]]) | introduceddate = July 10, 2014 * '''Reintroduced in the''' [[United States Senate|Senate]] '''as''' S.754 '''by''' [[Richard Burr]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[List of United States Senators from North Carolina|NC]]) '''on''' March 17, 2015 | committees = [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Select Committee on Intelligence]] | passedbody1 = | passeddate1 = | passedvote1 = }} The '''Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act''' ('''CISA''' {{USBill|113|S|2588}} [113th Congress], {{USBill|114|S|754}} [114th Congress]) is a [[United States federal law]] designed to "improve [[cybersecurity]] in the United States through enhanced sharing of information about cybersecurity threats, and for other purposes".[https://www.feinstein.senate.gov%2Fpublic/index.cfm/files/serve/?File_id=08de1c1b-446b-478c-84a8-0c3f35963216 "Discussion Draft of the 'Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2014' (S.2588)"], 113th Congress, 2d Session, June 11, 2014. The law allows the sharing of Internet traffic information between the U.S. government and technology and manufacturing companies. The bill was introduced in the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] on July 10, 2014, and passed in the Senate October 27, 2015.[https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/senate-bill/754 S.754 - Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015] Opponents question CISA's value, believing it will move responsibility from private businesses to the government, thereby increasing vulnerability of personal private information, as well as dispersing personal private information across seven government agencies, including the NSA and local police. The text of the bill was incorporated by amendment into a [[Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2016|consolidated spending bill]] in the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House]] on December 15, 2015,[https://www.congress.gov/bill/114th-congress/house-bill/2029 H.R.2029 - Military Construction and Veterans Affairs and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2016] which was signed into law by President [[Barack Obama]] on December 18, 2015.[https://www.engadget.com/2015/12/18/house-senate-pass-budget-with-cisa/ Budget bill heads to President Obama's desk with CISA intact] ==History== The Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act was introduced on July 10, 2014 during the 113th Congress, and was able to pass the [[Senate Intelligence Committee]] by a vote of 12-3.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/07/09/controversial-cybersecurity-bill-known-as-cisa-advances-out-of-senate-committee/|title=Controversial Cybersecurity Bill Known As CISA Advances Out Of Senate Committee|publisher=Forbes|author=Gregory S. McNeal|date=9 Jul 2014|accessdate=31 Jul 2015}} The bill did not reach a full senate vote before the end of the congressional session. The bill was reintroduced for the 114th Congress on March 12, 2015, and the bill passed the Senate Intelligence Committee by a vote of 14-1. {{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/cisa-cybersecurity-bill-advances-despite-privacy-critiques/ |title=CISA Cybersecurity Bill Advances Despite Privacy Concerns |publisher=Wired |author=Andy Greenberg |date=12 Mar 2015 |accessdate=27 Jul 2015}} Senate Majority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]], (R-Ky) attempted to attach the bill as an amendment to the annual [[National Defense Authorization Act]], but was blocked 56-40, not reaching the necessary 60 votes to include the amendment. {{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/senate-vote-falls-short-of-approving-defense-act-with-cisa-amendment/article/2566527 |title=Senate vote falls short of approving defense act with CISA amendment |publisher=The Washington Examiner |author=Charlie Mitchell |date=22 Jun 2015 |accessdate=28 Jul 2015}} {{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2015/06/11/cybersecurity-information-sharing-bill-senate-cloture-vote/71077022/ |title=Democrats block effort to attach cybersecurity legislation to defense bill |publisher=USA Today |author=Erin Kelly |date=11 Jun 2015 |accessdate=28 Jul 2015}} Mitch McConnell hoped to bring the bill to senate-wide vote during the week of August 3–7, {{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/senate-once-again-looks-to-bring-back-cisa/article/2568396 |title=Senate, once again, looks to bring back CISA |publisher=The Washington Examiner |author=Charlie Mitchell |date=20 Jul 2015 |accessdate=27 Jul 2015}} but was unable to take up the bill before the summer recess. The Senate tentatively agreed to limit debate to 21 particular amendments and a manager's amendment, {{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/255599-house-intelligence-chair-cisa-will-pass-senate-overwhelmingly |title=House Intel chief says cyber-sharing bill will pass 'overwhelmingly' |publisher=The Hill |author=Katie Bo Williams |date=1 Oct 2015 |accessdate=4 Oct 2015}} but did not set time limits on debate. In October 2015, the US Senate took the bill back up following legislation concerning [[Sanctuary city|sanctuary cities]]. ==Provisions== The main provisions of the bill make it easier for companies to share personal information with the government, especially in cases of cyber security threats. Without requiring such information sharing, the bill creates a system for federal agencies to receive threat information from private companies.{{Cite journal|last=Kominsky|first=Mitchell|date=February 2014|title=The Current Landscape of Cybersecurity Policy: Legislative Issues in the 113th Congress|url=http://harvardnsj.org/2014/02/the-current-landscape-of-cybersecurity-policy-legislative-issues-in-the-113th-congress/|journal=Harvard Law School National Security Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}} With respect to privacy, the bill includes provisions for preventing the act of sharing data known to be both personally identifiable and irrelevant to cyber security. Any personal information which does not get removed during the sharing procedure can be used in a variety of ways. These shared cyber threat indicators can be used to prosecute cyber crimes, but may also be used as evidence for crimes involving physical force.{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/2015/03/cisa-security-bill-gets-f-security-spying/|title=CISA Security Bill: An F for Security But an A+ for Spying|publisher=Wired|author=Andy Greenberg|date=20 Mar 2015|accessdate=31 Jul 2015}} ==Positions== ===Businesses and trade groups=== The CISA has received some support from advocacy groups, including the [[United States Chamber of Commerce]],{{cite web|url=http://www.fiercehomelandsecurity.com/story/industry-rep-businesses-get-stronger-liability-protection-sharing-cyber-thr/2015-03-05|title=Industry rep: Businesses get stronger liability protection for sharing cyber threat info under CISA|publisher=Fierce Homeland Security|author=Dibya Sarkar|date=Mar 5, 2015|accessdate=July 27, 2015}} the [[National Cable & Telecommunications Association]], and the [[Financial Services Roundtable]]. A number of business groups have also opposed the bill, including the [[Computer & Communications Industry Association]],{{cite web|url=http://dcinno.streetwise.co/2015/10/20/cisa-senate-vote-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-congress/|title=Apple, Google and Friends Join Forces Ahead of Crucial CISA Decision |author=Chris Bing|date=20 Oct 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} as well as individual companies such as [[Twitter]], [[Yelp]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], and [[Reddit]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2015/10/20/twitter-slams-controversial-cybersecurity-bill.html|title=Twitter slams controversial cybersecurity bill|publisher=Fox News|author=James Rogers |date=20 Oct 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} [[BSA (The Software Alliance)]] appeared initially supportive of CISA, sending a letter on July 21, 2015 urging the senate to bring the bill up for debate.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/248645-software-industry-urges-action-on-senate-cyber-bill|title=Software industry urges action on Senate cyber bill|publisher=The Hill|author=Cory Bennett|date=July 21, 2015|accessdate=July 27, 2015}} On September 14, 2015, the BSA published a letter of support for amongst other things cyber threat information sharing legislation addressed to Congress, signed by board members [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], [[Apple Inc.]], [[Altium]], [[Autodesk]], [[CA, Inc.|CA Technologies]], [[DataStax]], [[IBM]], [[Microsoft]], [[Minitab]], [[Oracle Corporation|Oracle]], [[Salesforce.com]], [[Siemens]], and [[Symantec]].{{cite web|url=http://www.bsa.org/~/media/Files/Policy/data/09142015CongLeadershipDataAgendaLetter.pdf |title=Congressional Leadership Data Agenda Letter |date=September 14, 2015 |publisher=BSA}} This prompted the digital rights advocacy group [[Fight for the Future]] to organize a protest against CISA.{{cite web|url=https://www.youbetrayedus.org/ |title=Betrayed by Tech |publisher=Fight for the Future}} Following this opposition campaign, BSA stated that its letter expressed support for cyber threat sharing legislation in general, but did not endorse CISA, or any pending cyber threat sharing bill in particular.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/2015/09/24/tech-vendor-cybersecurity-bill/|title=Apple, Microsoft, others slammed for supporting cybersecurity bill|publisher=Fortune|author=Barb Darrow|date=24 Sep 2015|accessdate=4 Oct 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/marc-benioff-tweets-against-cisa-2015-9|title=A few tweets from Salesforce's Marc Benioff threaten to squash a cyber-spying law|publisher=Business Insider|author=Julie Bort|date=28 Sep 2015|accessdate=4 Oct 2015}} BSA later stated that it is opposed to CISA in its current form.{{cite web|title = Security|url = http://www.bsa.org/policy/security/?sc_lang=en-US|website = www.bsa.org|accessdate = 2015-12-18}} The [[Computer & Communications Industry Association]], another major trade group including members such as [[Google]], [[Amazon.com]], [[Cloudflare]], [[Netflix]], [[Facebook]], [[Red Hat]], and [[Yahoo!]], also announced its opposition to the bill.{{cite web|title = CCIA Urges Senate To Improve Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act|url = https://www.ccianet.org/2015/10/ccia-urges-senate-to-improve-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act/|website = www.ccianet.org/|accessdate = 2015-12-18}} ===Government officials=== Proponents of CISA include the bill's main cosponsors, senators [[Dianne Feinstein]] (D-CA) and [[Richard Burr]] (R-NC).{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/editorial/kaveh-waddell|title=Cybersecurity Bill Nears Crucial Senate Vote |publisher=National Journal|author=Kaveh Waddell|date=20 Oct 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} Some senators have announced opposition to CISA, including [[Ron Wyden]] (D-OR), [[Rand Paul]] (R-KY), and [[Bernie Sanders]] (I-VT).{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/politics/bernie-sanders-cisa-senate-2016-presidential-candidates/|title=Bernie Sanders comes out against CISA, a controversial cybersecurity bill|publisher=Daily Dot|author=Eric Geller|date=12 Oct 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} Senator Ron Wyden (D-OR) has objected to the bill based on a classified legal opinion from the [[United States Department of Justice|Justice Department]] written during the early [[Presidency of George W. Bush|George W Bush Administration]]. The [[Obama administration]] states that it does not rely on the legal justification laid out in the memo.{{cite web|url=http://www.nationaljournal.com/tech/what-s-inside-the-justice-department-s-secret-cybersecurity-memo-20150727|title=What’s Inside the Justice Department’s Secret Cybersecurity Memo?|publisher=National Journal|author=Dustin Volz|date=July 27, 2015|accessdate=July 28, 2015}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jun/13/cisa-cybersecurity-surveillance-government-data-access|title=A government surveillance bill by any other name is just as dangerous|publisher=The Guardian|author=Trevor Timm|date=June 13, 2015|accessdate=July 28, 2015}} Wyden has made repeated requests to the [[US Attorney General]] to declassify the memo,{{cite web|url=https://www.techdirt.com/articles/20150204/05522629903/senator-wyden-follows-up-with-eric-holder-all-requests-doj-has-totally-ignored.shtml|title=Senator Wyden Follows Up With Eric Holder On All Of The Requests The DOJ Has Totally Ignored|publisher=Tech Dirt|author= Mike Masnick|date=4 Feb 2015|accessdate=July 31, 2015}} dating at least as far back as when a 2010 [[Office of Inspector General]] report cited the memo as a legal justification for the FBI's warrantless wire-tapping program.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2010/02/obamas-secret-wiretap-memo/35134/|title=Obama's Secret Wiretap Memo|series=DHS/NPPD/PIA-029 Automated Indicator Sharing|publisher=The Atlantic|author=Marc Ambinder|date=February 1, 2010|accessdate=July 31, 2015}} On August 4, 2015, White House spokesman Eric Schultz endorsed the legislation, calling for the senate to "take up this bill as soon as possible and pass it".{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/250241-white-house-endorses-senate-cyber-bill|title=White House endorses Senate cyber bill|publisher=The Hill|author=Cory Bennett|date=4 Aug 2015|accessdate=4 Oct 2015}} The [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] initially supported the bill, with [[Jeh Johnson]], the secretary of the DHS, calling for the bill to move forward on September 15.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/cybersecurity/253803-dhs-head-to-senate-move-on-stalled-cybersecurity-bill|title=Homeland Security chief pushes Senate to move cyber bill|publisher=The Hill|author=16 Sep 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} However, in an August 3 letter to senator [[Al Franken]] (D-MN), the deputy secretary of the DHS, [[Alejandro Mayorkas]], expressed a desire to have all connections be brokered by the DHS, given the Department's charter to protect the executive branch networks. In the letter, the DHS found issue with the direct sharing of information with all government agencies, advocating instead that the DHS be the sole recipient of cyberthreat information, allowing it to scrub out private information.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailydot.com/politics/dhs-cisa-letter/|title=Homeland Security joins privacy groups in pushback against CISA|publisher=The Daily Dot|author=Eric Geller|date=3 Aug 2015|accessdate=20 Oct 2015}} In addition, the Department of Homeland Security has published a Privacy Impact Assessment detailing its internal review of the proposed system for handling incoming indicators from Industry.{{cite web|url=https://www.dhs.gov/publication/dhsnppdpia-029-automated-indicator-sharing|publisher=The Department of Homeland Security|title=DHS/NPPD/PIA-029 Automated Indicator Sharing|date=28 Oct 2015|accessdate=18 Dec 2015}} ===Civil liberties groups=== Privacy advocates were aghast in October when the [https://www.wired.com/2015/10/cisa-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-passes-senate-vote-with-privacy-flaws/ Senate passed the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act by a vote of 74 to 21], leaving intact portions of the law they say make it more amenable to surveillance than actual security while quietly stripping out several of its remaining privacy protections. CISA has been criticized by advocates of [[Internet privacy]] and [[civil liberties]], such as the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]] and the [[American Civil Liberties Union]].[https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2014/06/zombie-bill-comes-back-look-senates-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-2014 "A Zombie Bill Comes Back to Life: A Look at The Senate's Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2014"], Mark Jaycox, Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), June 29, 2014.[https://www.aclu.org/blog/national-security-technology-and-liberty/beware-dangers-congress-latest-cybersecurity-bill "Beware the Dangers of Congress’ Latest Cybersecurity Bill"], Sandra Fulton, ACLU (Washington), June 27, 2014. It has been compared to the criticized [[Cyber Intelligence Sharing and Protection Act]] proposals of 2012 and 2013, which passed the United States House of Representatives, but did not pass the Senate. ===Similar laws in different countries=== [https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/2010-to-2015-government-policy-cyber-security/2010-to-2015-government-policy-cyber-security United Kingdom government policy: cyber security] [http://www.gov.scot/Topics/People/Young-People/gettingitright/information-sharing The Scottish Government Information Sharing] ==See also== * [[Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement]] * [[Chinese intelligence operations in the United States]] * [[Communications Assistance for Law Enforcement Act]] * [[Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002]] * [[Freedom of information laws by country]] * [[Intellectual Property Attache Act]] * [[National Security Agency]] * [[Vulnerabilities Equities Process]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == External links == * [https://beta.congress.gov/bill/113th-congress/senate-bill/2588 S.2588 - Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2014], Congress.gov, Library of Congress. * [http://www.mercurynews.com/opinion/ci_26188154/dianne-feinstein-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-will-help "Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act will help protect us"], Dianne Feinstein, ''San Jose Mercury News'', July 21, 2014. * [https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/07/09/controversial-cybersecurity-bill-known-as-cisa-advances-out-of-senate-committee/ Forbes: Controversial Cybersecurity Bill Known As CISA Advances Out Of Senate Committee], Gregory S. McNeal, July 9, 2014. * [https://cdt.org/insight/analysis-of-feinstein-chambliss-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-of-2014/ Center for Democracy and Technology: Analysis of Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act], Gregory T. Nojeim and Jake Laperruque, July 8, 2014. *[https://www.wired.com/2015/10/cisa-cybersecurity-information-sharing-act-passes-senate-vote-with-privacy-flaws - CISA Security Bill Passes Senate With Privacy Flaws Unfixed] ANDY GREENBERG AND YAEL GRAUER Oct 27, 2015 *[https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/2010-to-2015-government-policy-cyber-security/2010-to-2015-government-policy-cyber-security/] 2010 to 2015 government policy: cyber security [[Category:Computer security]] [[Category:Copyright enforcement]] [[Category:Cybercrime]] [[Category:Internet law in the United States]] [[Category:Proposed legislation of the 113th United States Congress]] [[Category:Internet censorship]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Use British English|date=February 2015}} {{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=February 2008}} {{tone|date=February 2008}} {{original research|date=February 2010}} }}
'''Fuckart & Pimp''' was a media [[hoax]] conceived by Alex Chappel and David C West in April 1998 which subjected [[London|London's]] [[Decima gallery]] to worldwide media attention and became a British front page [[newspaper]] sensation, as well as featuring on national [[television]]. The show was originally presented as a real event and managed to dupe many national newspapers in the UK before being revealed as a hoax.
==Beginning== The show "Fuckart & Pimp" was conceived by [[Alex Chappel]] and freelance reporter [[David C. West]]. An initial press release was sent out in April 1998 to all the newspapers and media describing the concept show, to open on 17 April: "Fuckart and Pimp" featured a Canadian artist named Angela Marshall. The gallery (the Pimp) prostitutes the artist (the Whore), and the buyer (the Punter) has to consummate the sale of a painting by performing a sexual act with Angela. It was billed as "a stark comment on the world of contemporary art", and the show would "enable both the punter and Angela to fully understand the workings of the curator-artist relationship". photographs were encouraged, "A small picture will cost £25 and require oral sex; a medium-size picture is full sex, at £50 and for a large painting at £75, 'anything kinky'".
==Media assault== That same day, from 9 p.m. onwards, the Decima gallery became besieged by press reporters. Everyone from the [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]]s to [[ITN]] arrived, and as they were all expecting to see an art show, one was staged. Angela Marshall{{who|date=November 2013}} arrived to the glare of lenses, "squeezed into a nine year old's leopard print leotard (she aspires to be 'in her twenties') and sporting a red rhinestone dog collar, hat, gloves, torn black stockings, topped by a blond wig and dark sunglasses", as ''[[The Scotsman]]'' reported.<ref name="Scotsman">''[[The Scotsman]]'', 18 April 1998</ref>
The crowds stayed away, "possibly deterred by the ranks of camera crews and reporters gathered outside the gallery", as ''[[The Guardian]]'' speculated. The reason for them not materialising, however, was the fact that none ever existed to begin with; thus, to curb the media hunger, a punter was invented in the form of "someone calling himself Mark Childs and claiming to be a buyer".{{cn|date=November 2013}}
As ''The Scotsman'' put it, "Under a dim red light bulb, a man and two women - the second being the artist's Scottish 'assistant' Jessica Konopka - thrashed about on a dirty mattress in a pathetic pantomime copulation". On ''[[London Tonight]]'', Mark Childs could be seen leaving the gallery with lipstick-smeared face, carrying a digitally blurred painting. The reason why the painting was digitally blurred is because it bore the lipstick scrawled slogan 'Media Cunts'.
==Threatened legal action== A counter [[sabotage]] that fuelled much of the coverage was [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark council's]] letter presented in full view of the cameras, 'warning that the property appeared to be being used for sexual entertainment, and that the show's curator may have committed an offence. If the exhibition continued, the gallery would be risking prosecution. This was on the evidence of the eyewitness reports of the undercover council officer who paid five pounds to watch the act through a spy hole, and was reported by The Scotsman as saying 'she's still wearing the G-string but he's got all his kit off and they're definitely at it.'<ref name="Scotsman"/>
'Nick', as he was called in the article, publicly issued a warning for [[obscenity]]. Despite the insistence that the warning would not hinder the show continuing over the weekend, the pinnacle of the event had been reached and it did not continue.
==Hoaxers play to the gallery== The following day, 18 April, nearly every paper reported on the event, some skeptical as to its authenticity; it was only [[The Daily Telegraph]] that actually caught on with the headline 'Hoaxers play to the gallery with sex and art show,' with a sub heading '[[Tom Leonard (journalist)|Tom Leonard]] reports on the elaborate and bizarre activities of two publicity-seekers'. 'Faking it in the name of art' gave a brief synopsis of the previous lengthier stories with the small inclusion of a quote: 'yesterday show organiser David West admitted, "It was a hoax...a charade."'<ref>The Sunday Mirror, 19 April 1998</ref> The nationwide press were reluctant to follow up the original story with the truth, and potentially suffer embarrassment, thus, outside of the UK many were ignorant of the fact that it was a hoax.
== References == {{Reflist}} * The Scotsman,18 April 1998 * The Sunday Sun,21 April 1998
==Further References== * "The Independent", 28 & 30 April 1998 * "The Telegraph", 18 April 1998 * "The Mirror", 18 April 1998 * Cork, Richard "London Tonight", 17 April 1998 * Leonard, Tom [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1998/04/18/nart18.html "Hoaxers play to the gallery with sex and art show"] "The Telegraph", 18 April 1998. Accessed 3 April 2007 * Watson-Smyth, Kate [http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_19980418/ai_n14160545 "A Brush with the law for artist selling sex"] "The Independent", 18 April 1998. Accessed 5 April 2007
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fuckart and Pimp}} [[Category:Hoaxes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1998 in London]] [[Category:1998 hoaxes]] [[Category:Journalistic hoaxes]]

Millions of Kurds [[Kurdish refugees|displaced and turned refugees]] | notes = | campaignbox = }} {{Campaignbox Kurdish–Iraqi conflict}} The '''Iraqi–Kurdish conflict''' consists of a series of wars and rebellions by the [[Kurdish people|Kurds]] against the central authority of Iraq during the 20th century, which began shortly after the defeat of the [[Ottoman Empire]] in [[World War I]] and lasting until the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|U.S. invasion of Iraq in 2003]]. Some put the marking point of the conflict beginning to the attempt by [[Mahmud Barzanji]] to establish an independent [[Kingdom of Kurdistan]], while others relate to the conflict as only the post-1961 insurrection by the Barzanis.[https://books.google.com/books?id=nrN077AEgzMC&pg=PA454&lpg=PA454&dq=kurdish-iraqi+conflict&source=bl&ots=LVyHy8m-68&sig=1SxG8OpgWnkuetti-zwgS1dLQFI&hl=iw&sa=X&ei=cmQeUN8D5pvUBfDEgOgL&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=kurdish-iraqi%20conflict&f=false Heo U.K. and Derouen K. ''CIVIL WARS OF THE WORLD''. P.445] The conflict lasted until the US invasion of Iraq in 2003, though tensions between the [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Kurdish autonomy]] and the central Iraqi government have continued. The first chapter of the Iraqi–Kurdish dispute followed the end of World War I and the arrival of British forces. [[Mahmud Barzanji]] began [[Mahmud Barzanji revolts|secession attempts]] in 1919 and in 1922 proclaimed the short-lived [[Kingdom of Kurdistan]]. Though Mahmud's insurrections were defeated, another Kurdish sheikh, [[Ahmed Barzani]], began to actively oppose the central rule of the Mandatory Iraq during the 1920s. The first of the major [[Mustafa Barzani|Barzani]] revolts took place in 1931, after Barzani, one of the most prominent [[Kurdish People|Kurdish]] leaders in [[Iraqi Kurdistan|Northern Iraq]], succeeded in defeating a number of other [[Kurdish People|Kurdish]] tribes.''The Kurdish Minority Problem'', p.11, Dec. 1948, ORE 71-48, [[CIA]] {{cite web|url=http://www.foia.cia.gov/docs/DOC_0000258376/0000258376_0014.gif |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308123142/http://www.foia.cia.gov/docs/DOC_0000258376/0000258376_0014.gif |archivedate=2012-03-08 |df= }}. He ultimately failed and took refuge in Turkey. The next serious Kurdish secession attempt was made by [[Ahmed Barzani]]'s younger brother [[Mustafa Barzani]] in 1943, but that revolt failed as well, resulting in the exiling of Mustafa to Iran, where he participated in an attempt to form the Kurdish [[Republic of Mahabad]]. In 1958, [[Mustafa Barzani]] and his fighters returned to Iraq from exile, and an attempt was made to negotiate Kurdish autonomy in the north with the new Iraqi administration of Gen. Qasim. The negotiations ultimately failed and the [[First Iraqi–Kurdish War]] erupted on 11 September 1961, lasting until 1970 and inflicting 75,000–105,000 casualties. Despite the attempts to [[Iraqi–Kurdish Autonomy Agreement of 1970|resolve]] the conflict by providing Kurds with a recognized autonomy in north Iraq (Iraqi Kurdistan), the negotiations failed in 1974, resulting in resumed hostilities known as the [[Second Iraqi–Kurdish War]], which resulted in the collapse of the Kurdish militias and the reconquest of northern Iraq by Iraqi government troops. As a result, [[Mustafa Barzani]] and most of the KDP leadership fled to Iran, while PUK gained power in the vacuum, leading an [[PUK insurgency|insurgency campaign]] against the central Iraqi government. Since 1976 PUK and KDP relations quickly deteriorated, reaching the climax in April 1978, when PUK troops suffered a major defeat by KDP, which had the support of Iranian and Iraqi air forces. During this period, the Ba'athist authorities took the opportunity to perform large-scale [[Ba'athist Arabization campaigns in North Iraq|displacement and colonization]] projects in North Iraq, aiming to shift demographics and thus distabilize Kurdish power bases. The [[Kurdish Rebellion of 1983|conflict]] re-emerged as part of the [[Iran–Iraq War]], with the Kurdish parties collaborating against [[Saddam Husein]] and KDP also gaining military support by the Islamic Republic of Iran. By 1986 Iraqi leadership grew tired of the strengthening and non-loyal Kurdish entity in north Iraq and began a genocidal campaign, known as [[Al-Anfal campaign|Al-Anfal]], to oust the Kurdish fighters and take revenge on the Kurdish population—an act often described as the ''Kurdish genocide'', with an estimated 50,000–200,000 casualties. In the aftermath of the [[Gulf War|Persian Gulf War]], [[1991 uprisings in Iraq|a series of uprisings]] shattered Iraq, but only the Kurds succeeded in achieving a status of unrecognized autonomy within one of the [[Iraqi no-fly zones]], established by the US-led coalition. In the mid-1990s the conflict between the KDP and PUK erupted once again, resulting in a [[Kurdish Civil War|bloody civil war]], which ended in 1997. Despite mutual recognition after the 2003 Iraq war which ousted Ba'ath rule, relations between [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] and the [[Politics of Iraq|Iraqi central government]] grew strained between 2011–12 due to power-sharing issues and the export of oil. ==Early conflicts== ===Mahmud Barzanji (1919–1924)=== [[Mahmud Barzanji revolts]] were a series of armed uprisings against the British forces in the newly conquered Mesopotamia and later the [[Kingdom of Iraq (British administration)|British Mandate in Iraq]]. Following his first insurrection in May 1919, Sheykh Mahmud was imprisoned and eventually exiled to India for a one-year period. When he returned he was once again appointed a governor, but shortly afterwards revolted again and declared himself the ruler of the [[Kingdom of Kurdistan]]. The Kingdom of Kurdistan lasted from September 1922 – 1924.Prince, J. (1993), "A Kurdish State in Iraq" in ''Current History'', January. With British forces greatly exceeding his in ammunition and training, Barzani was finally subdued and the region reverted to central British Iraqi rule in 1924. Sheykh Mahmud retreated into the mountains, and eventually reached terms with the independent [[Kingdom of Iraq]] in 1932, over his return from the underground. Shaykh Mahmud revolts are considered the first chapter of the modern Iraqi–Kurdish conflict. ===1931 Kurdish revolt=== [[Ahmed Barzani revolt]] refers to the first of the major [[Mustafa Barzani|Barzani]] revolts, taking place in 1931 after [[Ahmed Barzani]], one of the most prominent [[Kurdish People|Kurdish]] leaders in [[Southern Kurdistan]], succeeded in unifying a number of other [[Kurdish People|Kurdish]] tribes. The [[Barzan, Iraq|Barzan]] forces were eventually overpowered by the Iraqi Army with British support, forcing the leaders of Barzan to go underground. Ahmed Barzani was later forced to flee to [[Turkish Kurdistan|Turkey]], where he was held in detention and then sent to exile in the south of [[Iraq]]. Although initially a tribal dispute, the involvement of the Iraqi government inadvertently led to the growth of Shaykh Ahmad and Mulla Mustafa Barzani as prominent Kurdish leaders.Lortz, Michael G. [http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf "The Kurdish Warrior Tradition and the Importance of the ''Peshmerga''"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191132/http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf |date=2013-10-29 }}, ''Willing to face Death: A History of Kurdish Military Forces – the Peshmerga – from the Ottoman Empire to Present-Day Iraq'', 2005-10-28. Chapter 1 Throughout these early conflicts, the Barzanis consistently displayed their leadership and military prowess, providing steady opposition against the fledgling Iraqi military. It is speculated that exile in the major cities exposed the Barzanis to the ideas of urban Kurdish nationalism. ===1943 Kurdish revolt=== {{Main article|1943 Barzani revolt}} The [[1943 Barzani revolt|1943–1945 Kurdish revolt in Iraq]] was a Kurdish nationalistic insurrection in the Kingdom of Iraq, during World War II. The revolt was led by Mustafa Barzani and later joined by his older brother Ahmed Barzani, the leader of the [[Ahmed Barzani revolt|previous Kurdish revolt]] in the [[Kingdom of Iraq]]. The revolt, initiating in 1943, was eventually put down by Iraqi military assault in late 1945, combined with the defection of a number of Kurdish tribes. As a result, the Barzanis retreated with much of their forces into [[Iranian Kurdistan]], joining the local Kurdish elements in establishing the [[Republic of Mahabad]]. ==Main phase== ===Negotiations over Kurdish autonomy (1958–1960)=== After the [[14 July Revolution|military coup]] by [[Abdul Karim Qasim]] in 1958, [[Mustafa Barzani]] was invited by new Iraqi President Qasim to return from exile, and was greeted with a "hero's welcome", as a former dessident to the now abolished Iraqi monarchy. As part of the deal arranged between Qasim and Barzani, Qasim promised to give the Kurds regional autonomy in return for Barzani's support for his policies. Meanwhile, during 1959–60, Barzani became the head of the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party]] (KDP), which was granted legal status in 1960. ===First Iraqi–Kurdish War (1961–1970)=== {{Main|First Iraqi–Kurdish War}} First Iraqi–Kurdish WarMichael G. Lortz. (Chapter 1, Introduction). ''The Kurdish Warrior Tradition and the Importance of the Peshmerga''. pp.39-42. {{cite web|url=http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191132/http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf |archivedate=2013-10-29 |df= }} or Barazani Rebellion was a major event of the Iraqi–Kurdish conflict, lasting from 1961–1970. The struggle was led by [[Mustafa Barzani]] in an attempt to establish an independent Kurdish state in north Iraq. Throughout the 1960s the uprising escalated into a long war, which failed to resolve despite internal power changes in Iraq. The war ended with a stalemate by 1970, resulting in between 75,000{{cite web |author1=Arnold et al. |title=18. Iraq/Kurds (1932-present) |url=http://uca.edu/politicalscience/dadm-project/middle-eastnorth-africapersian-gulf-region/iraqkurds-1932-present/ |website=uca.edu}} to 105,000 casualties.{{cite web |last1=Wars since 1900 |title=All wars in the 20th century, since 1900 {{!}} the Polynational War Memorial |url=http://www.war-memorial.net/wars_all.asp |website=www.war-memorial.net}} A series of [[Iraqi–Kurdish Autonomy Agreement of 1970|Iraqi–Kurdish negotiations]] followed the war in an attempt to resolve the conflict. ===Cease-fire (1970–1974)=== {{Main article|Iraqi–Kurdish Autonomy Agreement of 1970}} A [[Iraqi–Kurdish Autonomy Agreement of 1970|Kurdish Autonomy agreement]] was reached in March 1970 by the [[Iraq]]i government and the [[Kurdish people|Kurds]], in the aftermath of the [[First Iraqi–Kurdish War]], for the creation of an [[Autonomous entity|Autonomous]] Region, consisting of the three Kurdish governorates and other adjacent districts that have been determined by census to have a Kurdish majority. The plan also gave Kurds representation in government bodies, to be implemented in four years.G.S. Harris, ''Ethnic Conflict and the Kurds'', Annals of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, pp.118–120, 1977 For its time it was the most serious attempt to resolve the long-running conflict. ===Second Iraqi–Kurdish War (1974–1975)=== {{Main|Second Iraqi–Kurdish War}} Second Iraqi–Kurdish War was an offensive, led by Iraqi forces against rebel [[Kurdish Democratic Party|KDP troops]] of [[Mustafa Barzani]] during 1974–75. The war came in the aftermath of the [[First Iraqi–Kurdish War]] (1961–70), as the 1970 [[Iraqi–Kurdish Autonomy Agreement of 1970|peace plan]] for Kurdish autonomy had failed to be implemented by 1974. Unlike the previous guerilla campaign, waged by Barzani, the 1974 war was an attempt for symmetric warfare against the Iraqi Army, which eventually led to the quick collapse of the Kurds, lacking advanced and heavy weaponry. The war ended with the exile of the Iraqi KDP and between 7,000–20,000 deaths on both sides. ===Arabization of Iraqi Kurdistan and PUK insurgency (1976–1979)=== {{Main article|PUK insurgency|Ba'athist Arabization campaigns in North Iraq}} The [[PUK insurgency]] was a low-level militant campaign by the [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan]] (PUK) against the state of [[Iraq]], after the defeat of the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party]] (KDP) in the [[Second Iraqi–Kurdish War]], which forced the KDP organization to declare a ceasefire and move into exile. Due to lack of foreign support, however, the guerrillas were only able to operate in the highest regions of [[Iraqi Kurdistan]]'s mountains.Galbraith, Peter (2006), ''The End of Iraq: How American Incompetence Created a War without End''; Simon and Schuster. {{ISBN|0-7432-9423-8}} The PUK also faced the KDP, the KDPI, led by [[Abdul Rahman Ghassemlou]], and Iran supporting the Iraqis at various occasions. The insurgency dimmed with the [[1979 Kurdish rebellion in Iran]]. [[Ba'athist Arabization campaigns in North Iraq]] were forced displacement and cultural [[Arabization]] of minorities (Kurds, Yezidis, Assyrians, Shabaks, Armenians, Turkmen, Mandeans), in line with [[settler colonialism|settler colonialist]] policies, led by the Ba'athist government of Iraq from 1960s to early 2000s, in order to shift the demographics of North Iraq towards Arab domination. The Baath party under Saddam Hussein engaged into active expulsion of minorities from the mid-1970s onwards.Eva Savelsberg, Siamend Hajo, Irene Dulz. ''Effectively Urbanized - Yezidis in the Collective Towns of Sheikhan and Sinjar''. Etudes rurales 2010/2 (n°186). {{ISBN|9782713222955}} The campaigns took place during the Iraqi–Kurdish conflict, being largely motivated by the Kurdish-Arab ethnic and political conflict. The policies are sometimes referred as "internal colonialism",Prof. Rimki Basu. ''International Politics: Concepts, Theories and Issues'':p103. 2012. described by Dr. Francis Kofi Abiew as a "Colonial 'Arabization'" program, including large-scale Kurdish deportations and forced Arab settlement in the region.Francis Kofi Abiew. ''The Evolution of the Doctrine and Practice of Humanitarian Intervention'':p146. 1991. ===Kurdish rebellion during the Iran–Iraq War (1980–1988)=== Between 1980 and 1988, the conflict intensified as the [[Iran–Iraq War]] commenced. One of the groups targeted in particular by Iraqi authorities were the [[Feyli Kurds]], a community of [[Shi'ite]] Kurds settled in the southern area of the [[Zagros Mountains]] near Iraq's border with Iran. [[Saddam Hussein]] considered the group as 'Iranians' and began a campaign to drive the settlers out of the area as a part of his '[[Arabization]]' policy in 1980.,{{cite web|title=PBS: The Fayli Kurds|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/iraq501/events_faylee.html|accessdate=22 November 2014}} Saddam Hussein was severely critical of the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party]] (KDP) as they aligned forces with Iran in the conflict. In 1983, to avenge this liaison, he ordered the Army to abduct as many as 8,000 men and boys from [[Erbil]] province, where the clan of [[Barzani Kurds]] was based. [[Massoud Barzani]], the leader of the clan and the KDP, himself lost 37 members of his family to the Iraqi troops. They were reported to having been sent to Nugra Salman prison in the southern deserts of Iraq, where they were tortured. Subsequently, the remains of 512 Barzani men were discovered in a mass grave.{{cite web|title=PBS: The Missing Barzanis|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/iraq501/events_barzanis.html|accessdate=22 November 2014}} On March 16, 1988, Iraqi troops began shelling the Kurdish town of [[Halabja]], in retaliation for an attack on Iraqi positions carried out by [[Iranian Revolutionary Guards]] and the aligned [[Peshmerga]] fighters. Subsequently, the town was attacked with a mix of chemical substances such as [[VX (nerve agent)]], [[sarin]] and [[mustard gas]] (see [[Halabja chemical attack]]). Over 5,000 people are believed to have been killed in the attack, which was considered to be a part of the [[Al-Anfal Campaign]], directed against Kurds by the government under the command of [[Ali Hassan al-Majid]], head of the Northern Bureau of the [[Ba'ath Party]].{{cite web|title=PBS: Halabja|url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/iraq501/events_halabja.html}}{{cite web|title=BBC - On This Day: 16th March 1988|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/16/newsid_4304000/4304853.stm}} ===1991 Kurdish uprising=== {{main article|1991 uprisings in Iraq}} On 2 August 1990, Saddam launched a military invasion onto neighboring [[Kuwait]], reportedly due to its vast oil reserves, which would have helped him pay off the debts he owed to other countries during the [[Iran–Iraq War]] (see [[Gulf War]]). Within 24 hours, the [[Emir of Kuwait]] had fled. However, subsequently, an international coalition force consisting of [[United States|American]], [[United Kingdom|British]], [[Saudi]] and other troops liberated the country in 1991 and Iraqi troops were forced out of Kuwait (see [[Operation Desert Storm]]).{{cite web |author1=Dave Johns |title=FRONTLINE/WORLD . Iraq - Saddam's Road to Hell - A journey into the killing fields . PBS |url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/iraq501/events_kuwait.html |website=www.pbs.org}} Subsequently, one month after the Gulf War in February 1991, [[United States President]] [[George H. W. Bush]] called on the Iraqi people to stage an uprising against Saddam Hussein. This was followed by a series of rebellions in many parts of the country, such as the south by [[Shi'ite]] groups such as [[SCIRI]] and the [[Islamic Da'awa Party]]. Meanwhile, the Kurds in the north staged their own uprising for autonomy, under the leadership of [[Massoud Barzani]], leader of the [[Kurdistan Democratic Party]], and [[Jalal Talabani]], leader of the [[Patriotic Union of Kurdistan]]. The [[Peshmerga]] were trained into hardened guerrillas, who managed to infiltrate the Jash, a Saddam-orientated Kurdish militia (see [[Jash (term)]] and [[National Defense Battalions (Iraq)]]). The rebels soon managed to capture the town of [[Ranya]], [[Sulaimaniya]] and ultimately the oil center of [[Kirkuk]]. Saddam retaliated swiftly, battering Kirkuk with artillery and targeting hospitals in particular. Geographically the towns captured by the Kurdish rebels were difficult to defend as they sat on plains below mountains. The rebels were forced to retreat in the mountains, where reportedly the Iraqi helicopters threw flour of them (which was believed to be a grim legacy of the reputed powdery [[chemical weapons]] which were used by the Iraqi administration during the [[Al-Anfal Campaign]]).{{cite web |author1=Dave Johns |title=The Crimes of Saddam Hussein |url=https://www.pbs.org/frontlineworld/stories/iraq501/events_uprising.html |website=www.pbs.org}} ==Later phase== ===Kurdish Civil War (1994–1997)=== {{Main article|Iraqi Kurdish Civil War}} The [[Iraqi Kurdish Civil War]] was a military conflict, which took place between rival [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] factions in [[Iraqi Kurdistan]] in the mid-1990s, most notably the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan vs. the Kurdistan Democratic Party. Over the course of the conflict, Kurdish factions from [[Iran]] and [[Turkey]], as well as Iranian, [[Iraq]]i and Turkish forces were drawn into the fighting, with additional involvement from the American forces. Between 3,000 and 5,000 fighters and civilians were killed throughout more than 3 years of warfare. ===2003 invasion of Iraq=== {{Main article|Operation Viking Hammer}} Arriving in July 2002 to Iraqi Kurdistan, the CIA seldom worked with the peshmerga, despite their claim to be on a counterterrorism mission against Ansar al-Islam. To the disappointment of PUK peshmerga intent on destroying Ansar al-Islam, the true mission of the CIA was to acquire intelligence about the Iraqi government and military. CIA-peshmerga operations eventually went beyond the scope of intelligence gathering however, as PUK peshmerga were used to destroy key rail lines and buildings prior to the U.S. attack in March 2003.[http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf Willing to face Death: A History of Kurdish Military Forces – the Peshmerga – from the Ottoman Empire to Present-Day Iraq (page 67)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191132/http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf |date=2013-10-29 }}, Michael G. Lortz Following [[Turkey]]'s decision to deny any official use of its territory, the Coalition was forced to modify the planned simultaneous attack from north and south.''Operation Hotel California: The Clandestine War inside Iraq'', Mike Tucker, Charles Faddis, 2008, The Lyons Press. Special Operations forces from the CIA and US Army managed to build and lead the Kurdish Peshmerga into an effective force and assault for the North. On March 20, 2003 at approximately 02:30 [[UTC]] or about 90 minutes after the lapse of the 48-hour deadline, at 05:33 local time, explosions were heard in Baghdad, signing the beginning of the [[2003 invasion of Iraq|U.S. led invasion]]. Beginning on 21 March 2003, U.S. forces launched Tomahawk missiles at selected Ansar al-Islam positions throughout the Sargat Valley. In preparation for the ground assault, nicknamed [[Operation Viking Hammer]], American Lt. Col. Tovo divided his forces into six mixed peshmerga-Special Forces units. The peshmerga in two of these teams refused to contribute to the assault for various reasons including having lost too many personnel in previous fighting. The peshmerga who did fight were once again armed with AK-47s, rocket-propelled grenades, and other assorted weapons. Despite their well-armed adversaries, during the operation only 24 peshmerga were killed in the fighting, compared to an enemy body count of over 300.[http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf Willing to face Death: A History of Kurdish Military Forces – the Peshmerga – from the Ottoman Empire to Present-Day Iraq (page 67)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191132/http://etd.lib.fsu.edu/theses/available/etd-11142005-144616/unrestricted/003Manuscript.pdf |date=2013-10-29 }}, Michael G. Lortz ==Aftermath== [[File:Kurdish flag photo.jpg|thumb|180px|Kurdish flag in northern Iraq]] ===2011–2012 tensions=== {{further information|Disputed territories of Northern Iraq}} Tensions between Iraqi Kurdistan and the central Iraqi government mounted through 2011–2012 on the issues of power sharing, oil production and territorial control.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/12/10/254359.html] On April 2012, the president of Iraq’s semi-autonomous northern Kurdish region demanded that officials agree to their demands or face consequences of a secession from Baghdad by September 2012.[http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/04/26/210364.html] On September 2012, Iraqi government ordered the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] (KRG) to transfer its powers over Peshmerga to the central government and the relations strained further by the formation of a new command center (Tigris Operation Command) for Iraqi forces to operate in a disputed area over which both Baghdad and the [[Kurdistan Regional Government]] (KRG) claim jurisdiction.https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/18/us-iraq-kurds-idUSBRE8AG0I220121118 On 16 November 2012, a military clash between the Iraqi forces and the Peshmerga resulted in one person killed. CNN reported that 2 people were killed (one of them an Iraqi soldier) and 10 wounded in clashes at the Tuz Khurmato town.[http://edition.cnn.com/2012/11/16/world/meast/iraq-violence/index.html] On the night of November 19, it was reported that clashes between security forces of the central Iraqi government and the KRG forces in Tigrit left 12 Iraqi soldiers and one civilian dead, according to Doğan news agency.http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/iraq-tensions-added-to-regional-turmoil.aspx?pageID=238&nID=35108&NewsCatID=352 The clash erupted when Iraqi soldiers attempted to enter northern Iraq; peshmargas tried to prevent the Iraqi soldiers from entering the area upon Barzani’s instructions. There was no confirmation of the event. On November 25, it was reported that Iraqi Kurdistan sent reinforcements to a disputed area, where its troops are "involved in a standoff with the Iraqi army", despite calls on both sides for dialogue to calm the situation.[http://ekurd.net/mismas/articles/misc2012/11/state6643.htm Iraqi Kurdistan send more troops into standoff with Iraq Arab-led army] EKurd Daily. November 25, 2012. On December 11, Iraqi Kurdistan President Massoud Barzani, dressed in a military uniform, visited Kurdish-controlled areas of Kirkuk, a city long seen as a flashpoint for Arab-Kurdish tensions after the US military withdrawal in December 2011.http://www.todayszaman.com/news-300806-iraqs-barzani-says-kurds-ready-to-fight-over-disputed-city.html Following Massoud Barzani's visit of Kurdish troops stationed in the disputed area near Kirkuk, Iraqi Prime Minister Maliki's party – The State of Law – issued a statement that "the visit of the President of Kurdistan Region Massoud Barzani and his son wearing a military helmet to inspect the battlefronts in Kirkuk province is a 'declaration of war' on all Iraqis not only Maliki, and even on President Jalal Talabani".[http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2012/12/maliki-barzanis-kurdish-troop-review-a-declaration-of-war.html#ixzz2EvltfRLa Al-Monitor] ===2014 regional conflict in Iraq=== {{Main article|Northern Iraq offensive (June 2014)|Northern Iraq offensive (August 2014)}} In 2014, Iraqi army units fled large parts of northern Iraq in the face of attacks by the [[Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant]]. Peshmerga forces took control of Kirkuk and other Kurdish-populated areas outside the official territory of the KRG. Officials in Baghdad were angered by the sale of tankers worth of oil transported through the [[Kirkuk–Ceyhan Oil Pipeline#Kurdistan pipeline|Kurdish pipeline]].{{cite news|last1=Emre|first1=Peker|title=Iraqi Kurdistan Gets Around $100 Million for First Major Oil Export|url=https://online.wsj.com/articles/iraqs-kurdish-region-gets-around-100-million-for-first-major-oil-export-1403521403|accessdate=24 June 2014|work=Wall Street Journal|date=23 June 2014}} ===2017 Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum and ensuing clashes=== {{main|Iraqi Kurdistan independence referendum, 2017|2017 Iraqi–Kurdish conflict}} After holding an independence referendum on 15th October 2017, Iraqi authorities have warned the KRG to void and cancel the result of the referendum, but the Kurdistan authority does not follow the request, then after intense preparation between Iraq, Iarn, and Turkey, the Iraqi army conqured the area which is called a disputed territory. ==Casualties== [a].{{note|a}} Iraqi–Kurdish conflict (combined casualty figure 163,800–345,100): :[[Mahmud Barzanji revolts]] (1919–1924) – unknown :[[Ahmed Barzani revolt]] (1931–1932) – hundreds killed :[[1943 Barzani revolt]] (1943–1945) – hundreds killed :[[First Iraqi–Kurdish War]] (1961–1970) – 12,000–105,000 killed.http://users.erols.com/mwhite28/warstat4.htm :[[Second Iraqi–Krudish War]] (1974–1975) – 9,000 killed.http://pards.org/2005/Iraq(Kurds)AtRisk).doc :[[PUK insurgency]] (1976–1978) – 800 killed. : 1980 [[ Persecution of Feyli Kurds under Saddam Hussein]] - 25,000{{cite book|last1=Jaffar Al-Faylee|first1=Zaki|title=Tareekh Al-Kurd Al-Faylyoon|date=2010|location=Beirut|pages=485, 499-501|accessdate=26 May 2017}}{{cite book|last1=Al-Hakeem|first1=Dr. Sahib|title=Untold stories of more than 4000 women raped killed and tortured in Iraq, the country of mass graves|date=2003|pages=489-492|accessdate=26 May 2017}}{{Clarification|is this a supplied title because it cannot be traced by title or author|date=December 2017}} :[[Kurdish Rebellion of 1983|Iraqi Kurdish uprising (1982–1988)]] – 50,000–198,000 killed. :[[1991 Uprising in As Sulaymaniyah]] – 700–2,000 killed. :[[Iraqi Kurdish Civil War]] (1994–1997) – 3,000Jordi Tejel. ''Syria's Kurds: history, politics and society''. 2009. p.156.–5,000 killed :[[2003 invasion of Iraq]] ([[Operation Viking Hammer]]) – 300 Islamists killed, at least 24 Peshmerga killed; unknown number of Iraqi agents "eliminated". ==See also== * [[Kurdish–Turkish conflict]] * [[Kurdish separatism in Iran]] * [[Syrian Kurdistan conflict]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} ==Further reading== * [http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,74703,00.html Iraqi Insurgent Groups] {{Iraqi Kurdistan}} {{Middle East conflicts}} {{Post-Cold War Asian conflicts}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iraqi-Kurdish Conflict}} [[Category:Iraqi–Kurdish conflict| ]] [[Category:Military history of Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Military history of Iraq]] [[Category:Kurdish separatism in Iraq]] [[Category:Kurdistan independence movement]] [[Category:20th century in Iraq]] [[Category:Rebellions in Iraq]] [[Category:History of Kurdistan]] [[Category:Wars involving Iraq]] [[Category:History of the Kurdish people]] [[Category:Separatism in Iraq]] [[Category:Wars involving Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Category:Kurdish rebellions]] [[Category:Civil wars in Iraq]]

revision.text:
'''Massacre Day''' was a holiday in [[Boston, Massachusetts]], from 1771 to 1783. It was held on March 5, the anniversary of the 1770 [[Boston Massacre]].
==History== Each year a featured speaker would deliver an oration to commemorate the massacre. The speech would subsequently be printed. [[James Lovell (delegate)|James Lovell]] delivered the first speech in 1771. Dr. [[Joseph Warren]] delivered the Massacre Day oration in 1772 and 1775. [[Benjamin Church (physician)|Benjamin Church]] was the featured speaker in 1773, followed the next year by [[John Hancock]]. In emotional language, the early speeches reminded listeners of the killings of civilians in Boston by British soldiers while touching upon themes such as the dangers of [[standing army|standing armies]] in times of peace and opposition to the policies of the [[Parliament of Great Britain|British Parliament]] that the speakers believed violated colonial rights.
The final observance of Massacre Day was in 1783. With the end of the [[American Revolutionary War]] and the securing of American independence, the [[Boston Board of Selectmen]] thought it was appropriate to replace the holiday with [[Independence Day (United States)|Independence Day]], held on July 4 in honor of the [[United States Declaration of Independence|Declaration of Independence]]. The final oration was delivered by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Welch and focused on the dangers of armies being garrisoned in cities.<ref>Fowler, William M., Jr. ''The Baron of Beacon Hill: A Biography of John Hancock''. Boston: Houghton Mifflin, 1980.</ref><ref>Travers, Len. ''Celebrating the Fourth: Independence Day and the Rites of Nationalism in the Early Republic.'' [[University of Massachusetts Press]], 1999.</ref>
==See also== *[[Evacuation Day (Massachusetts)]] *[[Patriot's Day]] *[[Bunker Hill Day#Commemorations]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://ahp.gatech.edu/boston_mass_orat_1772.html Text of the 1772 speech by Joseph Warren] *[http://ahp.gatech.edu/boston_mass_orat_1774.html Text of the 1774 speech by John Hancock] *[http://ahp.gatech.edu/boston_mass_orat_1775.html Text of the 1775 speech by Joseph Warren]
[[Category:1770s in the Thirteen Colonies]] [[Category:Holidays related to the American Revolution]] [[Category:Massachusetts in the American Revolution]] [[Category:Culture of Boston]] [[Category:March observances]]
