{{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Mighty Sounds | image = | location = Airport Capuv dvur, [[Tábor]] | dates = 3 days, 3rd week in July
2015: 24–26 July | years_active = 2005–present | founders = HPK Production | genre = [[Ska]], [[punk rock]], [[reggae]], [[hardcore punk]], [[rock and roll]], [[electronic dance music|EDM]] | website = {{url|http://www.mightysounds.cz}} }} '''Mighty Sounds''' is a [[ska]] and [[punk rock]] festival in the [[Czech Republic]]. The festival first took place in 2005, in the village of [[Olší (Tábor District)|Olší]] near [[Opařany]], remaining at that location for its first five years,{{cite web| url=http://www.denik.cz/hudba/festival-mighty-sounds-dostal-pokutu-360-000-byl-moc-hlucny-20130116-hdkr.html| title=Festival Mighty Sounds dostal pokutu 360 000. Byl prý moc hlučný| language=Czech| work=[[Deník]]| date=19 January 2013| accessdate=27 April 2014}} before moving to a disused airport in [[Tábor]] in 2010. In 2007 the festival attracted around 10,000 people,{{cite web| url=http://www.praguepost.cz/archivescontent/6536-out-of-the-mainstream.html| title=Out of the mainstream| work=[[The Prague Post]]| date=16 July 2008| accessdate=27 April 2014| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140427181702/http://www.praguepost.cz/archivescontent/6536-out-of-the-mainstream.html| archivedate=27 April 2014| df=dmy-all}} and in 2010 its attendance exceeded 12,000 people, making it one of the biggest festivals of its kind in Europe.{{cite web|url=http://budejovice.idnes.cz/pokuta-za-prekroceni-hlukovych-limitu-na-mighty-sounds-pjt-/budejovice-zpravy.aspx?c=A140402_140938_budejovice-zpravy_khr|title=Pokuty pro hlučný Mighty Sounds rostou, 420 tisíc může festival položit|language=Czech|work=[[Mladá fronta DNES]]|date=2 April 2014|accessdate=27 April 2014}} == Festival == The festival is held over three days. Originally the festival featured one large stage and a second smaller one, plus a Theatre tent. Another smaller tent known as the "Sado maso stage" featured techno and [[drum'n'bass]] DJs. After heavy rain in 2009 festival site and a nearby campsite for visitors was damaged by mud, and the owner of the site did not renew the contract for next event. Mighty Sounds moved to an unused grass-covered airfield in Tábor for the 2010 event. The festival subsequently featured two large stages, called the [[Jan Hus]] and [[Jan Zizka]] stages. Other stages include: a Theater tent, where less-known bands perform; the Radio 1 stage, which features electronic music DJs; and the Rudeboy Rhythm stage, which features DJs playing older ska, reggae, rocksteady and punk music. The festival also features a u-ramp for skateboarders and BMX riders, workshops, and special events, alongside normal festival amenities. == Lineups == {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Year ! Date ! Visitors ! Notable artists |- |'''2005''' |8–10 July |align="right" |4,500 | * [[Persiana Jones]] * [[Skarface]] |- |'''2006''' |14–16 July |align="right" |6,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[The Hotknives]] * [[Panteón Rococó]] * [[Desorden Público]] * [[The Toasters]] * [[Mark Foggo's Skasters]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2007''' |13–15 July |align="right" |10,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Derrick Morgan]] * [[Skalariak]] * [[Mad Sin]] * [[The Slackers]] * [[Dr. Ring-Ding]] * [[The Peacocks (band)|The Peacocks]] * [[Karamelo Santo]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2008''' |18–20 July |align="right" |12,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[The Real McKenzies]] * [[Obrint Pas]] * [[Mad Caddies]] * [[Demented Are Go]] * [[Sonic Boom Six]] * [[Vice Squad]] * [[Subhumans (British band)|Subhumans]] * [[The Turbo A.C.'s]] * [[The Toasters]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2009''' |18–20 July |align="right" |9,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Buzzcocks]] * [[Backyard Babies]] * [[Pat Kelly (musician)|Pat Kelly]] * [[Dave Barker]] * [[Chris Ellis (musician)|Chris Ellis]] * [[NoMeansNo]] * [[Dub Inc.]] * [[The Aggrolites]] * [[The World/Inferno Friendship Society]] * [[The Peacocks (band)|The Peacocks]] * [[Talco (band)|Talco]] * [[Liberator (band)|Liberator]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2010''' |16–18 July |align="right" |9,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Pauline Black]] * [[The Busters]] * [[Civet (band)|Civet]] * [[Donots]] * [[H2O (American band)|H2O]] * [[Mad Sin]] * [[Russkaja]] * [[Ska-P]] * [[Skarface]] * [[Sworn Enemy]] * [[Third World (band)|Third World]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2011''' |15–17 July |align="right" |12,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Anti-Flag]] * [[Anthony B]] * [[The Casualties]] * [[The Creepshow]] * [[Demented Are Go!]] * [[Dub Pistols]] * [[Karamelo Santo]] * [[Madball]] * [[Obrint Pas]] * [[Pennywise (band)|Pennywise]] * [[Ska2tonics]] * [[The Skatalites]] * [[The Toasters]] {{div col end}} |- |'''2012''' |13–15 July |align="right" |over 10,000 | {{div col|colwidth=18em}} * [[Adolescents (band)|Adolescents]] * [[Alborosie]] * [[Biohazard (band)|Biohazard]] * [[The Carburetors]] * [[Discharge (band)|Discharge]] * [[Distemper (band)|Distemper]] * [[Frank Turner]] * [[Gallows (band)|Gallows]] * [[Inner Circle (band)|Inner Circle]] * [[Irie Révoltés]] * [[The Locos (band)|The Locos]] * [[Los de Abajo (band)|Los de Abajo]] * [[The Meteors]] * [[The Peacocks (band)|The Peacocks]] * [[Pipes and Pints]] * [[Poison Idea]] * [[The Real McKenzies]] * [[The Skints]] * [[Sonic Boom Six]] * [[Street Dogs]] * [[The Varukers]] {{div col end}} |- revision.comment: /* External links */ - added new official website URL
revision.text:
'''The Montol Festival''' is an annual festival in [[Penzance]], [[Cornwall]], UK, held on the 21st of December each year since 2007. The festival is a revival or reinterpretation of many of the traditional [[Cornwall|Cornish]] midwinter customs & Christmas traditions formerly practiced in and around the Penzance area and common to much of Cornwall at one point. Montol is held on the traditional date of the feast of St [[Thomas the Apostle]], usually the 21st of December, which always coincides with the [[winter solstice]].
== Origin of the word ''Montol''== [[Edward Lhuyd]], in his 1700 MSS of vocabulary in the [[Cornish language]], states that ''Montol'' means 'winter solstice'.<ref>Teer Ha Tavas - Late/Modern Cornish Website Christmas special</ref> However, he later translates the word as 'balance' (in [[Latin language|Latin]], ''Trutina'' – 'a set of scales'<ref>Edward Lhuyd: online transcript of 'Archaeologia Britannica'. National Library of Wales</ref>).
== Revived customs == [[Image:Montol1.jpg|thumb|right|300px|The 2007 Montol beacon at Lescudjack Hillfort]] At the very core of the festival are several of the revived customs of the West Cornwall area including, predominantly, [[Guise dancing]], the masked celebrations common to Cornwall in the 19th century, the [[Cornish candle dance]] ([[Dons Cantol]]) in revived Cornish and the performance of traditional Guisers plays such as ''[[St George]] and the Turkish Knight'' or ''Buffy and the [[Bucca (mythological creature)|Bucca]]''. Cornish [[Christmas carol]]s also feature during the festivities. The "Chalking of the Mock", a Cornish [[Yule Log]] custom usually found in pubs or homes on [[Christmas Eve]], is part of the climax of the celebrations, usually happening at 10pm near the dock area of the town.
===Historical basis for revived customs=== The historical basis for many of the customs described above is taken from the texts of notable Cornish antiquarians and contemporary research into the subject. [[A. K. Hamilton Jenkin]] in his book ''Cornish Homes and Customs<ref>{{cite book|last1=Hamilton Jenkin|first1=Alfred Kenneth|title=Cornish Homes and Customs|date=1934|publisher=J. M. Dent|location=London|page=178}}</ref>'' describes the Guise dance processions and performances of 1831 as "like an Italian carnival" and further noted that "everyone including the rich and the great came masked and disguised on to the streets". However, he does not give a reference for this quote.
A detailed description of the Penzance Guise dancers is given by [[William Bottrell]] in his book ''Traditions and Hearthside Stories of West Cornwall'' (1870–80):
{{Quote|During the early part of the last century the costume of the guise dancers often consisted of such antique finery as would now raise envy in the heart of a collector. The chief glory of the men lay in their cocked hats which were surmounted with plumes and decked with streamers and ribbons. The girls were no less magnificently attired with steeple crowned hats, stiff bodied gowns, bag skirts or trains and ruffles hanging from their elbows.}}
==Montol Eve== The main event of the festival is Montol Eve, on the 21st of December every year. During the evening large Guiser processions can be seen through the town, carrying lanterns, wearing masks and traditional costumes. Early in the evening a [[Lord of Misrule]] is chosen from among the masked revellers.<ref>Montol Official Website</ref> The Lord of Misrule leads the main processions and has certain honorary functions, although there is no historical basis for this part of the event prior to 2007; there are no historical references to a Lord of Misrule in Penzance or Cornwall. A number of other "Mock leader" customs can also be seen during the evening, including the "Master of the Corn-Market" followed by the Corn-Market revellers. These groups take their inspiration from descriptions of the similarly named groups early in the 19th century.
Later on the appearance of the "Montol Oss" occurs in several locations throughout the town, culminating in the ceremony of the chalking of the Mock. The Mock is the Cornish Yule Log; a member of the public is chosen to mark the Mock with a stick man. In tradition, this represents either the [[Christ Child]] or [[Old Father Time]] marking the death of the year, or the celebration of the birth of Christ, "the light of the world". Some suggest that this very old Cornish imagery may have some connection to the sacrificial nature of the Roman [[Saturnalia]]{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}; the likelihood of this is open to question. A great deal of [[Cornish dance]] and music is performed during the evening, often in an improvised and impromptu manner.<ref>Simon Reed, The Cornish Traditional Year, Troy Books 2009</ref> The symbols of the festival are the spear and square of St Thomas, and the "Sun Resplendent", a traditional image used by Guise dancers{{citation needed|date=January 2017}}.
==Community events == During the festival there are a series of workshops dedicated to the making of [[lantern]]s and costumes which are used in a large public parade on 21 December in Penzance Town Centre, followed by the lighting of the midwinter fire (the location of which depends on the year in question).
== See also ==
*[[Golowan Festival]] *[[Tom Bawcock's Eve]]
== External links == *[http://www.montolfestival.co.uk/ Official website for the Montol Festival] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q6vUrsYy610k Amateur footage of the Montol Festival] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060703085307/http://www.teerhatavaz.org/introduction/christmas.php Origin of the word Montol from the Teer Ha Tavaz website (archived version)] *[http://www.montol.info Website of the Montol festival] *[http://holidaycottagesindevonandcornwall.co.uk/rivers-of-fire-at-the-montol-festival-in-penzance Rivers of Fire at the Montol Festival in Penzance] (Eyewitness account of the celebration)
== References ==
<references/>
{{Culture of Cornwall}} {{Winter solstice}}

/* Homo Homini Award */
revision.text:
{{ad|date=October 2018}} '''One World''' ([[Czech Republic|Czech]]: ''Jeden Svět'') is the biggest human rights film festival in the world{{cn|date=October 2018}}, held annually in [[Prague]] and other cities of the [[Czech Republic]], with a selection later shown in Brussels and other countries.
Established in 1999 by [[Igor Blaževič]] and the Czech NGO [[People In Need (Czech Republic)|People in Need]], the One World Festival presents over 100 documentary films during nine days in Spring from around the world. It is a founding member of the Human Rights Film Network, which brings together 33 festivals around the world.
In 2006, the festival received a Special Mention from [[UNESCO]] for its contribution to human rights and peace education. Three years later, in 2009, One World published a handbook entitled Setting Up a Human Rights Film Festival, which offers practical advice as well as case studies of prominent human rights events.<ref name="peopleinneed.cz">{{cite web|url=http://peopleinneed.cz/index2en.php?id%3D517 |title=Visit 13th annual one world festival |accessdate=19 May 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110824065507/http://peopleinneed.cz/index2en.php?id=517 |archivedate=24 August 2011 }}</ref>
In 2011, the One World Festival was in its 13th year and took place from 8 – 17 March, presenting 104 documentaries from more than 40 countries around the world. The festival seeks to promote the best quality documentary films on social and political issues. Furthermore, it has been held in 33 other towns and cities throughout the Czech Republic.<ref name="peopleinneed.cz"/> A selection of One World films was also presented in Brussels. One World was held under the auspices of [[Václav Havel]], the Minister of Foreign Affairs [[Karel Schwarzenberg]], the Minister of Culture [[Jiří Besser]], and the Mayor of Prague [[Bohuslav Svoboda]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.david-kilgour.com/2009/Mar_11_2009_03.php|title=Czech human rights Homo Homini Award goes to Chinese dissident and signatories of Charter 08|work=|date=11 March 2009|accessdate=4 February 2014}}</ref>
==Homo Homini Award== During the festival, [[People In Need (Czech Republic)|People in Need]] grants the annual [[Homo Homini Award]] to individuals in recognition of a dedication to promote human rights, democracy and nonviolent solutions to political conflicts. The 2011 award went to the underground network of Syrian doctors, [[Doctors Coordinate of Damascus]], for their work in aiding victims of violence in Syria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ceskatelevize.cz/ct24/domaci/165215-clovek-v-tisni-udeli-podzemni-siti-lekaru-v-syrii-cenu-homo-homini/|title=Člověk v tísni udělí podzemní síti lékařů v Sýrii cenu Homo Homini|language=Czech|work=[[Česká televize]]|date=21 February 2012|accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref>
''Winners of the Homo Homini Award''<ref name="award">{{cite web|url=http://clovekvtisni.cz/index2en.php?id=549 |title=PREVIOUS RECIPIENTS OF THE HOMO HOMINI AWARD |author= |date= |work= |publisher=People in Need |accessdate=18 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110501192644/http://clovekvtisni.cz/index2en.php?id=549 |archivedate=1 May 2011 }}</ref> *'''1994:''' [[Sergei Kovalev]] *'''1997:''' [[Szeto Wah]] *'''1998:''' [[Ibrahim Rugova]] *'''1999:''' [[Oswaldo Payá|Oswaldo Payá Sardiñas]] *'''2000:''' [[Min Ko Naing]] *'''2001:''' [[Zackie Achmat]] *'''2002:''' [[Thích Huyền Quang]], [[Thích Quảng Độ]] and [[Nguyễn Văn Lý]] *'''2003:''' [[Nataša Kandić]] *'''2004:''' [[Gheorghe Briceag]] *'''2005:''' [[Ales Bialatski]] and the Belarusian organisation [[Viasna]] *'''2006:''' [[Svetlana Gannushkina]] *'''2007:''' [[Su Su Nway]], [[Phyu Phyu Thin]], and [[Nilar Thein]] *'''2008:''' [[Liu Xiaobo]] *'''2009:''' [[Majid Tavakoli]] and [[Abdollah Momeni]] *'''2010:''' [[Azimjan Askarov]] *'''2011:''' [[Doctors Coordinate of Damascus]] *'''2012:''' [[Intiqam Aliyev|Intigam Aliyev]] *'''2013:''' [[Sapiyat Magomedova]] *'''2014:''' [[Souad Nawfal]] *'''2015:''' [[Black Spring (Cuba)]]''':''' Martha Beatriz Roque Cabello, Jorge Olivera Castillo, Ángel Juan Moya Acosta, José Daniel Ferrer García, Félix Navarro Rodríguez, Iván Hernández Carrillo, Héctor Maseda Gutiérrez, Óscar Elías Biscet González, Eduardo Díaz Fleitas, Librado Ricardo Linares García, Arnaldo Ramos Lauzurique *'''2016:''' [[Committee for the Prevention of Torture (Russia)]] *'''2017:''' [[Pham Doan Trang]]
==See also== *[[People In Need (Czech Republic)]]
==References== {{reflist}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}}
==External links== *[http://www.oneworld.cz One World Film Festival Official Site] * [http://intransit.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/03/04/at-prague-festival-movies-with-a-conscience/ At Prague Festival, Movies With a Conscience in: The New York Times] * [http://www.oneworld.cz/2011/films-awards Movies and Prizes 2011]

revision.comment: Fix links to [[Punjab]] (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Punjabis}} '''Punjabi festivals''' are various festive celebrations observed by [[Punjabis]] in [[Pakistan]], [[India]] and the diaspora Punjabi community found worldwide. The Punjabis are a diverse group of people from different religious background that affects the festivals they observe. According to a 2007 estimate, the total population of [[Punjabi Muslims]] is about 90 million (~75% of all Punjabis), with 97% of Punjabis who live in Pakistan following Islam, in contrast to the remaining 30 million Punjabi Sikhs and Punjabi Hindus who predominantly live in India.{{cite book|author1=Wade Davis|author2=K. David Harrison|author3=Catherine Herbert Howell|title=Book of Peoples of the World: A Guide to Cultures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rkG8f2lyeUMC&pg=PA132|year=2007|publisher=National Geographic|isbn=978-1-4262-0238-4|pages=132–133}} The Punjabi Muslims typically observe the Islamic festivals, do not observe Hindu or Sikh religious festivals, and in Pakistan the official holidays recognize only the Islamic festivals.[http://www.schools.punjab.gov.pk/system/files/Notification_2.pdf Official Holidays 2016], Government of Punjab – Pakistan (2016)[http://www.kmc.gos.pk/Contents.aspx?id=48 Official Holidays 2016], Karachi Metropolitan, Sindh, Pakistan The Punjabi Sikhs and Hindus typically do not observe these, and instead observe historic festivals such as Lohri, Basant and Baisakhi as seasonal festivals.[https://books.google.com/books?id=1O0eAQAAMAAJ&dq=maghi+punjab+bathing+rivers&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=makara Census of India, 1961: Punjab. Manage of Publications] The Sikh and Hindu festivals are regional official holidays in India, as are major Islamic festivals.[http://punjab.gov.in/list-of-holidays Official Holidays], Government of Punjab, India (2016) Other seasonal Punjabi festivals in India include Teejon (Teeyan) and Maghi. The Punjabi Muslim festivals are set according to the lunar Islamic calendar (Hijri), and the date falls earlier by 10 to 13 days from year to year.{{cite book|author1=Jacqueline Suthren Hirst|author2=John Zavos|title=Religious Traditions in Modern South Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bBOpAgAAQBAJ |year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-62668-5|page=274}};
[https://www.timeanddate.com/holidays/india/eid-ul-fitar Eid ul-Fitar], Ramzan Id/Eid-ul-Fitar in India, Festival Dates The Hindu and Sikh Punjabi seasonal festivals are set on specific dates of the luni-solar [[Bikrami calendar]] or [[Punjabi calendar]] and the date of the festival also typically varies in the [[Gregorian calendar]] but stays within the same two Gregorian months.{{cite book|author=Tej Bhatia|title=Punjabi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nTKBAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA209|year= 2013|publisher= Routledge|isbn=978-1-136-89460-2|pages=209–212}} Some Punjabi Muslims participate in the traditional, seasonal festivals of the Punjab region: Baisakhi, Basant and to a minor scale Lohri, but this is controversial. Islamic clerics and some politicians have attempted to ban this participation because of the religious basis of the Punjabi festivals,[https://www.dawn.com/news/1315376 The ban on fun], IRFAN HUSAIN, Dawn, Feb 18, 2017 and they being declared [[haram]] (forbidden in Islam).[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/sunday-special/columns/the-barricaded-muslim-mind/286436.html The barricaded Muslim mind], Saba Naqvi (August 28, 2016), Quote: "Earlier, Muslim villagers would participate in Hindu festivals; now they think that would be haraam, so stay away. Visiting dargahs is also haraam" ==Buddhist festivals== Punjabi Buddhists are a minority in [[Punjab, India]].Jain, Harish (2003) Punjab Hand Book: Population and Housing Census. Unistar Books.[https://books.google.com/books?id=4ZFiVQM-vw8C&pg=PA19&dq=buddhists+of+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj-gb2rwsTTAhXKD8AKHaPNAc84FBDoAQg3MAQ#v=onepage&q=buddhists%20of%20punjab&f=false] In the Punjab province of Pakistan, the Buddhist population is negligible.[http://www.pbs.gov.pk/sites/default/files//tables/POPULATION%20BY%20RELIGION.pdf POPULATION BY RELIGION], Pakistan Bureau of Statistics Punjabi Buddhists celebrate festivals such as [[Vesak|Buddha Jayanti]].D. C. Ahir (1992) Dr. Ambedkar and Punjab. B.R. Publishing Corporation [https://books.google.com/books?id=9ABIAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi+buddhists&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=festivals] ==Christian Festivals== {{double image|right|Church Vestry, Murree.JPG|100|Sadhu Sunder Singh Memorial Church.jpg|226|Left: Church in Murree (Pakistan), Right: Chandigarh (India).}} [[Christians]] are a minority in [[Pakistan]], constituting about 2.3% of its population in contrast to 97.2% Muslims.[http://www.pbs.gov.pk/sites/default/files//tables/POPULATION%20BY%20RELIGION.pdf POPULATION BY RELIGION], Pakistan Bureau of Statistics In Indian state of Punjab, Christians form about 1.1% of its total population, while the predominant majority of the population being Sikh and Hindus. Punjabi Christians celebrate [[Christmas]] to mark the birth of Jesus. In [[Punjab, Pakistan]], people stay up late singing Punjabi Christmas carol services.Sarfraz, Emanuel The Nation (25.12.2016) Understanding the changing face of Christmas [http://nation.com.pk/national/25-Dec-2016/understanding-the-changing-face-of-christmas]. People attend churches in places such as [[Gurdaspur]], [[Amritsar]], [[Jalandhar]] and [[Hoshiarpur]] districts in [[Punjab, India]] that have a higher Christian population, to be part of Christmas celebrations.Hindustan Times (25.12.2015) Christmas celebrations held across Punjab, Haryana and Chandigarh [http://www.hindustantimes.com/punjab/christmas-celebrations-held-across-punjab-chandigarh/story-gakSO27TYKPEX5YeikJGhN.html] Christians also celebrate [[Easter]] by engaging in processions.The Tribune (10/04/2017)[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/chandigarh/community/cultural-fest-at-government-mohindra-college/389715.html] {{clear}} == Hindu and Sikh festivals== {{Main|List of Hindu festivals in Punjab|List of Sikh festivals}} ===Holi=== {{Main|Holi}} [[File:India - Color Powder stalls - 7242.jpg|thumb|left|India - Colour Powder stalls on Holi- 7242]] [[Holi]] is the spring Hindu festival of colours which is celebrated by throwing colours on each other.{{cite book|author=McKim Marriott|editor=John Stratton Hawley and Vasudha Narayanan|title=The Life of Hinduism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9hairjdT-ekC|year=2006|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-24914-1|page=102}}The New Oxford Dictionary of English (1998) {{ISBN|0-19-861263-X}} - p.874 "Holi /'həʊli:/ noun a Hindu spring festival ..." The festival is celebrated on the first day of the Punjabi lunar month of Chet and marks the Spring season. The festival is primarily celebrated by Hindus. But Sikhs also participate in the festival which is seasonal in its significance and secular in its celebration.Rait, S.K (2005) Sikh Women in England: Their Religious and Cultural Beliefs and Social Practices. Trentham Books. [https://books.google.com/books?id=hRfkTq1ykSIC&pg=PA79&dq=holi+sikh&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1opyHh77TAhWsLcAKHYK1AAwQ6AEIQDAF#v=onepage&q=holi%20sikh&f=false] In the Indian state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], Holi is preceded by Holika Dahan the night before. On the day of Holi, people engage in throwing coloursParminder Singh Grover and Moga, Davinderjit Singh, Discover Punjab: Attractions of Punjab [https://books.google.com/books?id=Dy-pOAnlQL0C&pg=PT180&lpg=PT180&dq=punjab++holi&source=bl&ots=RaFXq2ML4s&sig=T-YkgBcEQEQRJeQ_21DkXo7J6dU&hl=en&sa=X&ei=nFmtVKWZFaOI7QbctICoBw&ved=0CEkQ6AEwBzgK#v=onepage&q=punjab%20%20holi&f=false] on each other.Jasbir Singh Khurana, Punjabiyat: The Cultural Heritage and Ethos of the People of Punjab, Hemkunt Publishers (P) Ltd, {{ISBN|978-81-7010-395-0}} During Holi in [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], walls and courtyards of rural houses are enhanced with drawings and paintings similar to [[rangoli]] in South India, ''mandana'' in Rajasthan, and rural arts in other parts of India. This art is known as ''chowk-poorana'' or ''chowkpurana'' in Punjab and is given shape by the peasant women of the state. In courtyards, this art is drawn on cloth. The art includes drawing tree motifs, flowers, ferns, creepers, plants, peacocks, palanquins, geometric patterns along with vertical, horizontal and oblique lines. These arts add to the festive atmosphere.[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/362722/drawing-designs-walls.html Drawing Designs on Walls], Trisha Bhattacharya (13 October 2013), ''Deccan Herald''. Retrieved 7 January 2015 {{clear}} ===Lohri=== {{Main|Lohri}} [[Image:Solstice fire Montana.jpg|thumb|left|Lohri fire]] [[Lohri]] is a popular winter time Punjabi folk festival, celebrated primarily by Sikhs and Hindus from the [[Punjab region]] of [[Indian subcontinent]].{{cite book|author1=S. Warrier|author2=John G. Walshe|title=Dates and Meanings of Religious and Other Multi-Ethnic Festivals, 2002-2005|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R6VQ_YRIPl0C|year=2001|publisher=Foulsham |isbn=978-0-572-02659-2|page=112}}, Quote: "Lohri is the winter festival of Punjab and is celebrated by Hindus and Sikhs."{{cite book|author=Colleen Taylor Sen|title=Food Culture in India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YIyV_5wrplMC&pg=PA142|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing |isbn=978-0-313-32487-1|page=142}}, Quote: "In the Punjab, this festival is called Lohri and is celebrated by Sikhs and Hindus with bonfires" According to Chauhan (1995), all Punjabis, including Muslims and Christians celebrate Lohri in [[Punjab, India]].Chauhan, Ramesh K. (1995) Punjab and the nationality question in India. Deep and Deep Publications [https://books.google.com/books?id=X2RuAAAAMAAJ&dq=hindu+muslim+sikh+christian+lohri&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=lohri] Lohri is celebrated on the last day of the month of poh (January).[https://books.google.com/books?id=vgixwfeCyDAC&pg=PA122&dq=lohri+30+poh&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiYyfimga7TAhVML1AKHQAfDRIQ6AEIJzAB#v=onepage&q=lohri%2030%20poh&f=false McLeod, W. H. (2009) The A to Z of Sikhism. Scarecrow Press] Many people believe the festival commemorates the passing of the [[winter solstice]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/1998/98jul19/science.htm|title=The Tribune...Science Tribune|publisher=|accessdate=12 January 2017}}[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/gyan-zone/festival-binge/28107.html The Tribune Festival binge: Amarjot Kaur 10 January 2015]Celebrating with the Robin Hood of the Punjab and all his friends! Nottingham Post 13 01 2014 {{cite web |url=http://www.nottinghampost.com/Celebrating-Robin-Hood-Punjab-friends/story-20434739-detail/story.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216093127/http://www.nottinghampost.com/Celebrating-Robin-Hood-Punjab-friends/story-20434739-detail/story.html |archivedate=2014-12-16 |df= }} Lohri is observed the night before [[Makar Sankranti]], also known as [[Maghi]], and according to the solar part of the lunisolar [[Bikrami calendar]] and typically falls about the same date every year (January 13).{{cite book|author=Dr. H.S. Singha|title=Sikh Studies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nRodBu9seiIC&pg=PA101|year=2005|publisher=Hemkunt Press|isbn=978-81-7010-245-8|pages=101–102}} Lohri is an official gazetted holiday in the state of Punjab (India),[http://www.hindustantimes.com/punjab/punjab-notifies-gazetted-restricted-holidays-for-2016/story-IdSI5D43hsqiu8i98G1YWJ.html Punjab notifies gazetted, restricted holidays for 2016], The Hindustan Times (2016) but it is not a holiday in Punjab (Pakistan).[https://schools.punjab.gov.pk/system/files/PublicHolidays2017.pdf#overlay-context=holidays Public and Optional Holidays], Government of Punjab, Lahore, Pakistan (2017) It is, however, observed by Sikhs and some Punjabi Muslims and Christians in [[Pakistan]] as well.[http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Punjab-celebrates-the-Lohri:-From-culture,-an-invitation-to-a-springtime-of-peace-and-unity-26972.html] Asian News Jan 2013: Lohri celebrated in Faislabad, Punjab, Pakistan {{clear}} ===Maghi=== {{Main|Maghi}} Maghi is a Sikh festival and one of their largest annual gatherings near Gurudwaras.{{cite book|author1=J. Gordon Melton|author2=Martin Baumann|title=Religions of the World: A Comprehensive Encyclopedia of Beliefs and Practices, 2nd Edition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v2yiyLLOj88C&pg=PA1769 |year=2010|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-204-3|page=1769}} The same festival is called [[Makar Sankranti]] by Hindus, who gather near Hindu temples. The ''Magha Mela'', according to [[Diana L. Eck]] – a professor at Harvard University specializing in Indology, is mentioned in the Hindu epic, the ''[[Mahabharata]]'', thus placing this festival to be around 2,000 years old. Many go to sacred rivers or lakes and bathe with thanksgiving to the sun.{{cite book|author=Diana L. Eck|title=India: A Sacred Geography|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PyC4o7i9tnEC&pg=PA153| year=2013|publisher=Random House| authorlink=Diana L. Eck | isbn=978-0-385-53192-4|pages=152–154}} People visit the [[Gurdwara]] or the [[Mandir]]. The festival marks the increase in daylight. Maghi is celebrated by people eating [[kheer]] such as Rauh di kheer which is an old dish where rice is cooked in sugarcane juice. The dish is prepared in the evening before Maghi and is kept to cool. It is served cold next morning on Maghi with red-chilly mixed curd.'Rauh di kheer’ is the people’s favourite. (14.01.2017 )The Tribune. accessed 15.01.2017 [http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/amritsar/-rauh-di-kheer-is-the-people-s-favourite/350132.html] In some parts of [[Punjab, India]], it is also traditional to eat [[kichdi]] mixed with lentils, consume raw sugarcane and [[jaggery]],Sundar mundarye ho by Assa Singh Ghuman Waris Shah Foundation ISBN B1-7856-043-7 Fairs are held at many places on Maghi.Sekhon, Iqbal S. The Punjabis. 2. Religion, society and culture of the Punjabis. Cosmos (2000) [https://books.google.com/books?id=bU0wAQAAIAAJ&q=maghi+makar+sankranti+punjab&dq=maghi+makar+sankranti+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiqzKzu9rjTAhVSKlAKHYKQCFU4ChDoAQghMAA] Sports festivals are also held in the region. {{clear}} ===[[Basant Kite Festival (Punjab)|Basant Festival]]=== {{Main|Basant Kite Festival (Punjab)}} [[File:Kite fastival in gujarat.jpg|thumb|right|Kite flying on Basant]] [[Basant Kite Festival (Punjab)|Basant Festival]] is an ancient Hindu spring festival dedicated to god [[Kama]] as well as goddess [[Saraswati]].{{cite book|author=James G. Lochtefeld|title=The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Hinduism: N-Z|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g6FsB3psOTIC&pg=PA741 |year=2002|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-8239-3180-4|pages=741–742}} Its link with the Hindu god of love and its traditions have led some scholars to call it "a Hindu form of Valentine's Day".{{cite book|author=J. Gordon Melton|title=Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, Solemn Observances, and Spiritual Commemorations |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lD_2J7W_2hQC&pg=PA903 |year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-206-7|page= 903}}, Quote: "Vasant Panchami is a day to think about the person one loves, a spouse or special friend. In rural areas, people note that the crops are already in the field and rippening. It has in the modern world developed a reputation as a Hindu form of Valentine's Day." The festival is also observed by Punjabi Sikhs.ASPECTS OF PUNJABI CULTURE S. S. NARULA Published by PUNJABI UNIVERSITY, INDIA, 1991 The traditional colour of the day is yellow and the dish of the day is saffron rice. People fly kites.{{cite book|author=Nikky-Guninder Kaur Singh|title=Sikhism: An Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w8yWAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT87|year=2011|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-0-85773-549-2|page=87}} In [[North India]], and in the Punjab province of [[Pakistan]], Basant is celebrated as a spring festival of kites.The Sikh World: An Encyclopedia Survey of Sikh Religion and Culture: Ramesh Chander Dogra and Urmila Dogra; {{ISBN|81-7476-443-7}} The festival marks the commencement of the spring season. In the [[Punjab region]] (including the Punjab province of [[Pakistan]]), Basant Panchami has been a long established tradition of flying kites''Punjabiat: The Cultural Heritage and Ethos of the People of Punjab'': Jasbir Singh Khurana and holding fairs. Punjabi Muslims have treated parts of the festival as a cultural event. In Pakistan however kite flying has been banned starting in 2007 with officials stating that it uses dangerous, life-threatening substances on the strings.[http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2017/02/07/punjab-govt-says-no-to-basant-festival/ PT (07.02.2017) Punjab govt says ‘NO’ to Basant festival] The festival ban was confirmed by the Pakistan Punjab state chief minister Shehbaz Sharif in 2017. According to some analysts, "the festival was banned due to pressure from hardline religious and extremist groups like the Hafiz Saeed-led Jamaat-ud Dawah, which claimed the festival had “Hindu origins” and was “un-Islamic”.[http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/pakistan-s-punjab-govt-imposes-complete-ban-on-basant-festival/story-6DmkwFleJkkxxaoFCeb6IK.html Pakistan’s Punjab govt imposes ‘complete ban’ on Basant festival], The Hindustan Times (Apr 03, 2017) ===Vaisakhi=== {{Main|Vaisakhi}} [[File:Kothe-da-mela.jpg|thumb|left|Mela]] [[File:Punjabi Pengra Drummer.JPG|thumb|right|Punjabi Bhangra Drummer]] Vaisakhi is a religious festival of Sikhs and Hindus. Vaisakhi is also a harvest festival for people of the [[Punjab region]].Bakshi,S. R. Sharma, Sita Ram (1998) Parkash Singh Badal: Chief Minister of Punjab [https://books.google.com/books?id=cyebnJdCFlEC&dq=baisakhi+punjabi+festival&source=gbs_navlinks_s] In the Punjab, Vaisakhi marks the ripening of the [[rabi crop|rabi]] harvest. Vaisakhi also marks the new year for Punjabi Sikhs and Hindus.{{cite book|author=Cath Senker|title=My Sikh Year|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PsQozVTKW44C&pg=PA10|year=2007|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4042-3733-9|page=10}}, Quote: "Vaisakhi is the most important mela. It marks the Sikh New Year. At Vaisakhi, Sikhs remember how their community, the Khalsa, first began."{{cite book|author=Knut A. Jacobsen|title=South Asian Religions on Display: Religious Processions in South Asia and in the Diaspora |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WT2odZ7_d7MC&pg=PA192 |year=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-07459-4|page=192}}, '''Quote:''' "Baisakhi is also a Hindu festival, but for the Sikhs, it celebrates the foundation of the Khalsa in 1699." Punjabi Muslims observe the new year according to the Islamic calendar. The harvest festival is celebrated by Punjabi Sikhs and Hindus.Gupta, Surendra K. (1999) Indians in Thailand, Books India International [https://books.google.com/books?id=5rBuAAAAMAAJ&dq=baisakhi+harvest+punjab+hindus+and+sikhs&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=barley] According to Aziz-ud-din Ahmed, [[Lahore]] used to have Baisakhi Mela after the harvesting of the wheat crop in April. However, adds Ahmed, the city started losing its cultural vibrancy in 1970s after Zia-ul-Haq came to power, and in recent years "the [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] government in Punjab banned kite flying through an official edict more under the pressure of those who want a puritanical version of Islam to be practiced in the name of religion than anything else".[http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/02/21/cultural-decline-in-lahore/ Cultural Decline in Pakistan], Pakistan Today, Aziz-ud-din Ahmed (February 21, 2015) Unlike the Indian state of Punjab that recognizes the Vaisakhi Sikh festival as an official holiday,[http://punjab.gov.in/list-of-holidays Official Holidays], Government of Punjab, India (2016) the festival is not an official holiday in Punjab or Sindh provinces of Pakistan where Islamic holidays are officially recognized instead.[http://www.schools.punjab.gov.pk/system/files/Notification_2.pdf Official Holidays 2016], Government of Punjab – Pakistan (2016)[http://www.kmc.gos.pk/Contents.aspx?id=48 Official Holidays 2016], Karachi Metropolitan, Sindh, Pakistan However, On 8 April 2016, Punjabi Parchar at Alhamra (Lahore) organised a show called Visakhi mela, where the speakers pledged to "continue our struggle to keep the Punjabi culture alive" in Pakistan through events such as Visakhi Mela.Pakistan Today (8 April 2016) [http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2016/04/08/promoting-peace-with-punjabi-at-visakhi-mela/ Punjabi Parchar spreads colours of love at Visakhi Mela] Elsewhere Besakhi fairs or melas are held in various places including [[Eminabad]][https://www.dawn.com/news/953015 A fair dedicated to animal lovers (20.04.2009) Dawn] and [[Dera Ghazi Khan]].Agnes Ziegler, Akhtar Mummunka (2006) The final Frontier: unique photographs of Pakistan. Sang-e-Meel Publications [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AhNuAAAAMAAJ&q=besakhi+mela+sakhi&dq=besakhi+mela+sakhi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQ67W705zTAhVrKsAKHZ5iBJIQ6AEIHDAA]{{refn|group=note|Security concerns are another reason for the lack of holding fairs which lead to the Baisakhi mela in [[Gujranwala]] to mark wheat harvesting being cancelled in 2015.Dunya New 14 April 2016: Gujranwala: Baisakhi festival cancelled due to security threats [http://dunyanews.tv/en/Pakistan/332199-Gujranwala-Baisakhi-festival-cancelled-due-to-sec] Despite the bomb blast at the Sakhi Sarwar sufi shrine in [[Dera Ghazi Khan]] in 2011,[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12951923 BBC News (03 04 2011) Pakistan Sufi shrine suicide attack kills 41] the Baisakhi mela around the water channel near the shrine that continues until the wheat harvest was integrated with the annual [[Urs]] of the saint in 2012.Tariq Ismaeel (01.03. 2012)"Sakhi Sarwar: Thousands arrive for festival ahead of urs" The Express Tribune [https://tribune.com.pk/story/343647/sakhi-sarwar-thousands-arrive-for-festival-ahead-of-urs/]}} ===Teeyan=== {{Main|Teej|Teeyan}} [[Teeyan]] welcomes the monsoon season and the festival officially starts of the day of [[Teej]] and last for 13 days. The seasonal festival involves women and girls dancing Gidha and visiting family. The festival is observed in [[Punjab, India]]. The festival is celebrated during the monsoon season from the third day of the lunar month of [[Sawan]] on the bright half, up to the full moon of [[sawan]], by women. Married women go to their maternal house to participate in the festivities.Alop Ho Raha Punjabi Virsa: Harkesh Singh KehalUnistar Books PVT Ltd {{ISBN|81-7142-869-X}}Shankarlal C. Bhatt (2006) Land and People of Indian States and Union Territories: In 36 Volumes. Punjab, Volume 22 [https://books.google.com/books?id=awketfu78rsC&pg=PA351&dq=teeyan+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAWoVChMIlsCw_rH9xgIVgZ8UCh1pXQnK#v=onepage&q=teeyan%20punjab&f=false] In the past, it was traditional for women to spend the whole month of [[Sawan]] with their parents.Rainuka Dagar (2002) Identifying and Controlling Female Foeticide and Infanticide in Punjab [https://books.google.com/books?id=1QfaAAAAMAAJ&dq=teej+punjab&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=precaution] [[Teej]] is historically a Hindu festival, dedicated to Goddess [[Parvati]] and her union with Lord [[Shiva]], one observed in northern, western, central and Himalayan regions of the Indian subcontinent.{{cite book|author=J Mohapatra|title=Wellness In Indian Festivals & Rituals|isbn=9781482816907|page=125}}{{cite journal| author=Manju Bhatnagar| title=The Monsoon Festival Teej in Rajasthan| year=1988|volume=47|number=1| jstor=1178252| journal=Asian Folklore Studies|pages=63–72}} ===Others=== Other festivals observed by [[Punjabi Hindus]] and Sikhs include [[Diwali]], [[Dussehra]], [[Rama Navami]], [[Bandi Chhor Divas]] and [[Gurpurab]]s. [[Raksha Bandhan]] in the Punjab is known as '[[Rakhri]]' and is celebrated as a brothers and sisters day. ==Muslim festivals== [[File:The Badshahi in all its glory during the Eid Prayers.JPG|thumb|right|Eid prayer in [[Badshahi Mosque]], [[Lahore]] ]] The following religious festivals are observed by Punjabi Muslims. ===Eid ul-Adha=== [[Eid ul-Adha]] is also known as Eid-ul-Azha. The festival is celebrated on the tenth day of the last Islamic month of Zilhij. Eid-ul-Azha occurs about two months after Eid-ul-Fitr. Eid-ul-Azha is celebrated to commemorate the occasion when the prophet Abraham was ready to sacrifice his son, Ismail, on God's command. Abraham was awarded by God by replacing Ismail with a goat. Muslims make pilgrimage ([[hajj]]) to [[Mecca]] during this time.Mohiuddin, Yasmeen Niaz (2007) Pakistan: A Global Studies Handbook. ABC-CLIO [https://books.google.com/books?id=OTMy0B9OZjAC&pg=PA296&dq=eid+ul+azha&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwil7ty51b3TAhViLMAKHYuVDiQQ6AEIPjAF#v=onepage&q=eid%20ul%20azha&f=false] Animal sacrifice is a tradition offered by Muslims on this day.[https://books.google.com/books?id=isDgI0-0Ip4C&pg=PA207&dq=Eid+sacrifice&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWos2E2r3TAhWiF8AKHe86AsAQ6AEIKDAB#v=onepage&q=sacrifice&f=false Leaman,Oliver (2006 The Qur'an: An Encyclopedia. Taylor & Francis] Special markets are set up to deal with the increase in demand of animals. Cattle markets are set up in places such as [[Multan]], ([[Punjab, Pakistan]])The Express Tribune (05.09.2015) Eid preparations: Eight Eid cattle markets to be set up in Multan[https://tribune.com.pk/story/950982/eid-preparations-eight-eid-cattle-markets-to-be-set-up-in-multan/] and goat markets in [[Ludhiana]],Sharma, Arjun (14.09.2015)Goat sellers go online ahead of Bakr-Eid, to affect direct retail The Hindustan Times [http://www.hindustantimes.com/punjab/goat-sellers-go-online-ahead-of-bakr-eid-to-affect-direct-retail/story-mImWf7I6lrNAWFns6tyUpM.html] ([[Punjab, India]]). The children celebrate Eid ul-Adha and Eid ul-Fitr with great pump and show and receive gifts and Eidi (money) from parents and others.1998 provincial census report of Punjab (2001) Population Census Organization[https://books.google.com/books?id=DHeFAAAAIAAJ&dq=eidi++gifts+punjab&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=eidi++] {{clear}} ===Eid-ul-Fitr=== [[Eid al-Fitr]] takes place on the first day of the tenth month of the Islamic lunar calendar and celebrates the end of [[Ramadan]]. Ramadan is the time of fasting that continues throughout the ninth month.Barbara DuMoulin, Sylvia Sikundar (1998) Celebrating Our Cultures: Language Arts Activities for Classroom Teachers. Pembroke Publishers Limited [https://books.google.com/books?id=QysY7lNWnPkC&pg=PA27&dq=Eid-ul-Fitr+end+of+ramadan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiUgqKz2L3TAhXMKcAKHU9EA68Q6AEINTAE#v=onepage&q=Eid-ul-Fitr%20end%20of%20ramadan&f=false] On this day, after a month of fasting, Muslims express their joy and happiness by offering a congregational prayer in the mosques. Special celebration meals are served.Bhalla,Kartar Singh 2005) Let's Know Festivals of India. Star Publications [https://books.google.com/books?id=WORYY5Vl0ygC&pg=PP17&dq=Eid-ul-Fitr+end+of+ramadan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjqh_DK2b3TAhXKJMAKHS0VAog4ChDoAQgmMAE#v=onepage&q=Eid-ul-Fitr%20end%20of%20ramadan&f=false] The festival is celebrated in [[Punjab, Pakistan]]. It is also celebrated in [[Malerkotla]] ([[Punjab, India]]) which has a sizable Muslim population where Sikhs and Hindus also participate in the observance.Kamal, Neel (01.09.2011) The Times of India. Eid celebrated with fervour in Malerkotla [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/Eid-celebrated-with-fervour-in-Malerkotla/articleshow/9817443.cms] ===Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi=== [[File:International Mawlid Conference at Minar-e-Pakistan Lahore by Minhaj-ul-Quran1.jpg|thumb|left|International Mawlid Conference, [[Minar-e-Pakistan]], [[Lahore]], [[Pakistan]].]] [[Mawlid|Eid-e-Milad-un- Nabi]] is an Islamic festival which is celebrated in honour of the birth-day of Prophet Muhammad.[https://books.google.com/books?id=wuIcAAAAMAAJ&dq=Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi+lahore&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=illuminations Guide to Lahore. Ferozsons] The festival is observed in the third month of the Islamic lunar calendar called Rabi'al-Awal.Edelstein, Sari (2011) Food, Cuisine, and Cultural Competency for Culinary, Hospitality, and Nutrition Professionals. Jones & Bartlett Learning. [https://books.google.com/books?id=lj0CeaIIETkC&pg=PA260&dq=Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjv8uubur3TAhWrBcAKHbKeBF0Q6AEILzAD#v=onepage&q=Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi%20punjab&f=false] Various processions take place in [[Lahore]] to celebrate the festival.[http://nation.com.pk/lahore/25-Jan-2013/city-celebrates-eid-miladun-nabi The Nation. (25.01.2013) City celebrates Eid Miladun Nabi] According to Nestorovic (2016), hundreds of thousands of people gather at Minare-Pakistan, Lahore, between the intervening night of 11th and 12th Rabi' al-awwal of the Islamic calendar [http://www.eidmila-dunnabi.com/ Eid Milad Dun Nabi].Nestorović, Čedomir (2016) Islamic Marketing: Understanding the Socio-Economic, Cultural, and Politico-Legal Environment. Springer [https://books.google.com/books?id=LXJBDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA215&dq=Milad+nabi+celebrations+started+in+lahore&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWh-j2vb3TAhWIIMAKHVB2AI4Q6AEIRTAH#v=onepage&q=Milad%20nabi%20&f=false] The festival was declared a national holiday in Pakistan in 1949.Paracha, Nadeem. F. Dawn (02.02.2017) Pakistan: The lesser-known histories of an ancient land [https://www.dawn.com/news/1312059] People from various places in [[Punjab, Pakistan]] including [[Bahawalpur]], [[Faisalabad]], [[Multan]] and [[Sargodha]] participate in processions and engage in decorating Mosques, streets and houses with green flags and lights.The Express Tribune (16.02.2011) Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi celebrations: What’s new on the milad menu? [https://tribune.com.pk/story/119437/eid-e-milad-un-nabi-celebrations-whats-new-on-the-milad-menu/] According to Khalid, children, teenagers and young adults decorate their Pahari (mountain) of all sorts of toys, including cars, stereos, and numerous other commodities. Within various places of Lahore, there are numerous stalls. Before the festival became a celebratory day, people used to celebrate the day quietly. However, the first procession to mark the day was led from Delhi gate in Lahore in 1935. This tradition then became popular elsewhere.Khalid, Haroon (14.02.2011) Celebrating Eid Millad ul Nabi by Haroon Khalid. Lahorenama [https://lahorenama.wordpress.com/tag/eid-millad-un-nabi/] Processions are also taken out in [[Bathinda]] ([[Punjab, India]]).The Tribune (25.12.2015) Milad-un-Nabi celebrated [http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/bathinda/milad-un-nabi-celebrated/174922.html] ===Muharram=== [[File:A street observation of Muharram in Lahore Pakistan.jpg|thumb|A street observation of Muharram in Lahore Pakistan]] Remembrance of [[Mourning of Muharram|Muharram]] is a set of rituals associated with [[Shia]],{{cite web|last1=Jean|first1=Calmard|title=AZĀDĀRĪ|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/azadari|website=iranicaonline|year=2011}} which takes place in [[Muharram]], the first month of the [[Islamic calendar]]. Many of the events associated with the ritual take place in congregation halls known as ''[[Hussainia]]''. The event marks the anniversary of the [[Battle of Karbala]] when Imam [[Hussein ibn Ali]], the grandson of [[Muhammad]], was killed by the forces of the second [[Umayyad Caliphate|Umayyad caliph]] [[Yazid I]] at [[Karbala]]. Family members, accompanying [[Hussein ibn Ali]], were killed or subjected to humiliation. The commemoration of the event during yearly mourning season, from first of [[Muharram]] to twentieth of [[Safar]] with [[Day of Ashura|Ashura]] comprising the focal date, serves to define [[Shia Islam|Shia]] communal identity.{{cite book|last1=Martín|first1=Richard C.|title=Encyclopedia of Islam & the Muslim World|date=2004|publisher=Macmillan Reference USA|page=488}} In Pakistani Punjab, Muharram is celebrated twice, once according to the Muslim year and again on the 10th of harh.Jacobsen, Knut A. (ed) (2008) South Asian Religions on Display: Religious Processions in South Asia and in the Diaspora. Routledge [https://books.google.com/books?id=WT2odZ7_d7MC&pg=PA107&dq=punjabi+desi+hindu+calendar+pakistan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiVzYyKvKbTAhUkLsAKHeKqDdsQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=punjabi%20desi%20hindu%20calendar%20pakistan&f=false] ====Processions==== [[File:Ashura in layyah.jpg|thumb|Ashura procession in [[Layyah]], [[Punjab, Pakistan]]]] Traditionally, a white horse representing Ali's white Mule Duldul, is usually lead in the Muharram procession, as in [[Jhang]], Punjab, Pakistan.[https://books.google.com/books?id=r5cfAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA31&dq=muharram+punjab+jhang&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE3LXHgb7TAhUKKsAKHcbVCqgQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=muharram%20punjab%20jhang&f=false Schimmel, Annemarie (1982) Islam in India and Pakistan. BRILL] Zuljanah, Tazia and Alam processions are observed in many places in [[Punjab, Pakistan]] including [[Sialkot]], [[Gujranwala]], [[Bahawalnagar]], [[Sargodha]], [[Bahawalpur]].(26.10.2015) The Nation Punjab marks Ashura with fervour amid tight security. [http://nation.com.pk/national/26-Oct-2015/punjab-marks-ashura-with-fervour-amid-tight-security] and [[Lahore]]. =====Zuljana===== [[Zuljanah]] processions are held which involves taking a replica of a horse. The Zuljanah has two wings and the processions were introduced from Iran to Lahore during the 19th century.Knut A. Jacobsen (2008) South Asian Religions on Display: Religious Processions in South Asia and in the Diaspora. Routledge. [https://books.google.com/books?id=WT2odZ7_d7MC&pg=PA105&dq=Zuljinnah+processions+punjab&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1geWTkMLTAhVqJ8AKHQPYCo4Q6AEIKTAB#v=onepage&q=Zuljinnah%20processions%20punjab&f=false] =====Tazia===== [[File:Imambada .jpg|thumb|left|Tazia at Jama Masjid, Delhi]] Shia [[Muslim]]s take out a [[Ta'zieh|Tazia]] procession on the [[day of Ashura]]. {{cite book|author=Reza Masoudi Nejad | editor= Peter van der Veer|title=Handbook of Religion and the Asian City: Aspiration and Urbanization in the Twenty-First Century |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_gtaCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA95 |year=2015|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-96108-1|pages=89–105}} A Tazia is traditionally a bamboo and paper model of Hussain's tomb at [[Karbala]], which is carried in procession by [[Shia]]s on the tenth day of the month of [[Muharram]].Proceedings, Volume 21 (1988) Punjab History Conference. Punjab University. [https://books.google.com/books?id=akZuAAAAMAAJ&dq=tazia+punjab+shia&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=bamboo+] Moderns forms of Tazia can be more elaborate. Tazia processions in Punjab are historic and were observed during the Sikh and British period when the Tazia would be divided into many storeys, but not ordinarily more than three.Latif, Syad Muhammad (1892) Lahore: Its History, Architectural Remains and Antiquities: With an Account of its Modern Institutions, Inhabitants, Their, Customs. New Imperial Press.[https://books.google.com/books?redir_esc=y&id=RWsTAAAAQAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=tazia] Such processions take place in [[Lahore]] where mourners take to the streets to commemorate the sacrifices of Imam Hussain and his family in Karbala. Various stalls are set up offering milk, water and tea along the route of the processions. Some distribute juice packets, dry fruit, sweetmeats and food among mourners.The Express Tribune (12.10.2016) Annual commemoration: Mourners brace for Ashura amid tight security.[https://tribune.com.pk/story/1197556/annual-commemoration-mourners-brace-ashura-amid-tight-security/] Tazia processions can also be seen in [[Malerkotla]]Randhawa, Karenjot Bhangoo (2012) Civil Society in Malerkotla, Punjab: Fostering Resilience through Religio. Lexington Books [https://books.google.com/books?id=KAxJvWu1wUQC&pg=PA106&dq=tazia+punjab+shia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwityJjIi8LTAhXHCMAKHT8VCWkQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=tazia%20punjab%20shia&f=false] and [[Delhi]].[http://www.tribuneindia.com/news/delhi/muharram-observed-amid-tight-security/308846.html The Tribune (13.10.2016 ) Muharram observed amid tight security] =====Alam===== Alam processions take place in [[Punjab, Pakistan]] too.The International News (12.10.2016) Security tightened in City on Youm-e-Ashur [https://www.thenews.com.pk/print/156696-Security-tightened-in-City-on-Youm-e-Ashur] Alam is an elaborate, heavy battle standard, carried by a standard bearer, alam-dar, ahead of the procession. It represents Imam Hussain’s standard and is revered as a sacred object.[https://books.google.com/books?id=XsWorLT4p3UC&pg=PA297&dq=alam+muharram&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjewJLDkcLTAhUlL8AKHSIqC3EQ6AEILDAC#v=onepage&q=alam%20&f=false Torab, Azam (2007) Performing Islam: Gender and Ritual in Islam. BRILL] ==Local festivals== Various local fairs and festivals are associated with particular shrines, temples and gurdwaras. ===Mela Chiragan=== Mela Chiraghan (Festival of Lights) is a three-day annual festival to mark the [[urs]] (death anniversary) of the [[Punjabi people|Punjabi]] [[Sufi]] poet and saint [[Shah Hussain]] (1538-1599) who lived in Lahore in the 16th century. It takes place at the shrine of Shah Hussain in [[Baghbanpura]], on the outskirts of [[Lahore]], Pakistan, adjacent to the [[Shalimar Gardens (Lahore)|Shalimar Gardens]].http://apnaorg.com/articles/news-1/, An article on Mela Chiraghan on Academy of the Punjab in North America (APNA) website, Published 29 March 2005, Retrieved 19 Aug 2016 ===Rath Yatra Nabha=== [[File:Nabha Ratha Yatra.jpg|thumb|Nabha Ratha Yatra]] [[Rath Yatra Nabha]], Ratha Jatra or Chariot Festival is a [[Hindu festival]] associated with the god [[Jagannath]] held at [[Mandir Thakur Shri Saty Narayan Ji]] in the [[Nabha]] City, state of [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], India. This annual festival is celebrated in the month of August or September. The festival is connected to Jagannath's visit to [[Nabha]] city. {{clear}} ===Hola Mohalla=== A fair is held at [[Anandpur Sahib]] ([[Punjab, India]]) during the [[lunar month]] of [[Chet (month)|Chet]] to celebrate the Sikh festival of [[Hola Mohalla]]. The fair is held on a very large scale every year on the day following [[Holi]]. Thousands of devotees come from all parts of the country to pay their homage to Guru Gobind Singh.Singha, H.s (2000) The Encyclopedia of Sikhism (over 1000 Entries). Hemkunt Press. [https://books.google.com/books?id=gqIbJz7vMn0C&pg=PA100&dq=hola+mohalla&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiGub-VksfTAhXEIMAKHYDdCxkQ6AEIIjAA#v=onepage&q=hola%20mohalla&f=false] ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} {{Punjab, India}} {{Commons category|Festivals of Punjab}} {{Punjabi festivals}} {{Sikhism}} {{HinduFestivals}} [[Category:Lists of festivals by topic]] [[Category:Punjabi festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Punjab, Pakistan]]

{{italic title}} {{Infobox play | name = Real Women Have Curves | image = | alt = | caption = | writer = [[Josefina López]] | chorus = | characters = Ana
Estela
Carmen
Pancha
Rosali | mute = | setting = A tiny sewing factory in [[East Los Angeles, California|East Los Angeles]] | premiere = {{Start date|1990|05|25}} | place = Mission Cultural Center for Latino Arts
San Francisco, California{{cite news |last=Hurwitt |first=Sam |url= https://www.mercurynews.com/2016/08/29/review-real-women-have-curves-charms-in-hayward/ |title=Review: ‘Real Women Have Curves’ charms in Hayward |work=[[The Mercury News]] |date=August 29, 2016 |accessdate=February 10, 2018}} | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''Real Women Have Curves''''' is a [[stage play]] by [[Josefina López]] and is set in a tiny [[sewing]] [[factory]] in [[East Los Angeles, California|East Los Angeles]] in September 1987.{{cite news |last=Churnin |first=Nancy |url= http://articles.latimes.com/1992-04-23/entertainment/ca-1326_1_real-women |title=Young Playwright Finds Life's Lessons the Best |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=April 23, 1992 |accessdate=February 10, 2018}} It is marked by the issues of [[gender politics]] and the [[Latina]] [[immigration|immigrant]] experience. The story is told from the point of view of Ana, the youngest employee at the factory. Ambitious and bright, Ana yearns to go to college, but does not have the money. The action follows the course of a week at the factory, as the women talk about their lives, loves and deepest desires while attempting to meet impossible production deadlines. In the [[playwright]]'s notes, López writes about how she grew up in Los Angeles herself. With the threat of [[U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement|''La Migra'']] looming over her childhood, she once saw a [[meter maid]] in a corner store and immediately attempted to "act white" out of fear that the official looking person could [[deportation|deport]] her. After the 1987 [[Simpson-Rodino Amnesty Act]], López was able to become a [[Permanent residency|legal resident]]. She reflects on the [[Illegal immigration to the United States|undocumented people]] she knew who were afraid to register themselves for fear that the act was a trick. "They, like me, couldn't believe that after hiding and being persecuted for so long they were finally going to have the freedom to live and work in this country." She recounts that before she went to college she worked in a garment factory; those experiences inspired ''Real Women Have Curves''. In 2002, the play was adapted into a [[Real Women Have Curves|film of the same name]], directed by [[Patricia Cardoso]] and starring [[America Ferrera]] as Ana. ==Characters== *Ana: the young [[feminism|feminist]] and recent [[high school]] graduate. She is politically [[activism|active]] and concerned; she is waiting on her [[Student financial aid in the United States|financial aid]] to come through so she can attend college. *Estela: the owner of the Garcia Sewing Factory, behind on her payments, kind but hardworking. Described in the play's intro as "plain-looking" and "plump". She is afraid to apply for amnesty because she [[debt|owes money]] on some sewing machines, and thus spends most of the play's action being [[anxiety|nervous]], afraid and driven to complete her large order. She has a huge crush on a man the group jokingly calls "El Tormento"; he takes her for a date and behaves inappropriately, making sexual advances that a smarter woman would have seen coming. *Carmen: the oldest of the women, [[mother]] of Ana and Estela, described as "short" and "large". She is a conventional example of a Latina mother; has a talent for [[storytelling]] and a tendency to use a harsh, blunt tone. She speaks her mind on all issues. *Pancha: Smart, sassy, described as a "huge woman". She is very comfortable with herself despite the fact that she [[Female infertility|cannot have children]], something her social conditioning has raised her to expect from life. Her character is, like Carmen, rather conventional, believing that Ana's [[education]] will be a turn-off for her future [[husband]]. *Rosali: often acts as the mediator of fights within the group, a little thinner than the others probably because she is constantly [[dieting]]. She is described as "sweet and easygoing" by the playwright. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:1990 plays]] [[Category:American plays adapted into films]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American culture in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Hispanic and Latino American plays]] [[Category:Plays based on actual events]] [[Category:Plays set in the 1980s]] [[Category:Plays set in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Working-class literature]] [[Category:Working class women]]

{{no footnotes|date=January 2017}}
'''Stanley Clifford Weyman''' (November 25, 1890 – August 27, 1960), was an [[United States|American]] multiple [[impostor]] who impersonated public officials, including the [[United States Secretary of State]] and various military officers.
Weyman was born as '''Stanley Jacob Weinberg''' on November 25, 1890 in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. His parents could not afford college tuition. He worked mainly in nondescript jobs but on occasion ventured to become somebody in the higher social ladder.
In 1910, Weyman's first imposture was as US consul representative to [[Morocco]] who dined in the finest restaurants of [[New York City]]. He was eventually arrested for [[fraud]].
Next Weyman took a role of both a [[military attaché]] from [[Serbia]] and a [[US Navy]] [[lieutenant]] so the identities could use each other as a reference. He was soon caught.
Weyman was released the second time in 1915. He then became Lt Commander Ethan Allen Weinberg, consul general for [[Romania]]. He inspected the ''USS Wyoming'' and invited everyone to a dinner in the [[Astor Hotel]]. The advance publicity alerted the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation|Bureau of Investigation]] and federal agents arrested him at the party. He was heard to complain that they should have waited until dessert. He got a year in jail.
In 1917 he took the mantle of Royal St. Cyr, a lieutenant in the [[Army Air Corps (United Kingdom)|Army Air Corps]]. He was arrested when he was on an inspection tour in the Brooklyn [[Armory (military)|armory]] because a suspicious military tailor had alerted the police.
Weyman was paroled in 1920. Shortly afterwards he forged credentials to become a company doctor in [[Lima, Peru|Lima]], [[Peru]]. There he threw lavish parties until his credit ran out and he was arrested.
In 1921 he noticed Princess Fatima of [[Afghanistan]] who was visiting the US and was trying to get an official recognition. The [[US State Department]] mainly ignored her. Weyman visited her as a State Department Naval Liaison Officer, apologized for the oversight and promised to arrange an appointment with the president. He managed to convince the princess to give him $10,000 for "presents" to State Department officials. He used the money for a private railway carriage to [[Washington DC]] and an opulent hotel room in the [[Willard Hotel]] for the princess and his entourage.
Weyman proceeded to visit the State Department, dropped names of prominent [[United States Senate|senators]] and succeeded in getting the appointment, first with [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]] [[Charles Evans Hughes]], and on July 26, 1921 president [[Warren G. Harding]] received Princess Fatima. Weyman's minor mistakes in the [[Protocol (diplomacy)|protocol]] aroused some suspicion, but when the press released his picture alongside the other dignitaries, the jig was up. He was indicted for impersonating a naval officer and sentenced to two years in jail.
In one case the ''Evening Graphic'' newspaper called for Weyman to get an interview with the visiting [[Queen Marie of Romania]]. He gained admittance as the Secretary of State and the paper got its interview.
In 1926 Weyman appeared at [[Rudolph Valentino]]'s funeral and attached himself to his grieving lover [[Pola Negri]] as a personal physician. He issued regular press releases on her condition and established a faith-healing clinic in Valentino's house. Pola Negri did not condemn him after he was exposed.
During [[World War II]] Weyman was sentenced for seven years in prison for offering advice to [[draft dodge]]rs—he told them to feign various medical conditions.
In 1948 Weyman made up credentials to become a journalist for the [[United Nations]] at [[Lake Success, New York|Lake Success]]. He got acquainted with the delegates [[Warren Austin]] and [[Andrei Gromyko]]. His comeuppance came when the [[Thailand|Thai]] delegation invited him to become their press officer with full [[diplomatic accreditation]]. Weyman contacted the State Department and asked whether it would affect his US citizenship. They already knew him all too well and exposed him.
In 1954 Weyman tried to get a $5000 home improvement loan for a house that did not exist. He failed to convince the judge that he was [[insanity defense|insane]].
In August 1960, Weyman was fatally shot when he tried to stop a robbery in a New York hotel where he was working as a night porter. The investigating detective said "I've known about the man's past record for years. He did a lot of things in the course of his life, but what he did this time was brave."
==Quote== ''"One man's life is a boring thing. I lived many lives. I'm never bored." ''
==References== * St. Clair McKelway - ''The Big Little Man from Brooklyn'' (Houghton Mifflin 1969) * Sarah Burton - ''Impostors'' (Penguin Books 2000, pages 36–43)
==External links== * [http://thememorypalace.us/2010/05/episode-30-nee-weinberg/ Memory Palace podcast episode about Weyman]
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Weyman, Stanley Clifford}} [[Category:American murder victims]] [[Category:1880 births]] [[Category:1960 deaths]] [[Category:Impostors]] [[Category:People murdered in New York (state)]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in New York (state)]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Women in World War II]]; added [[Category:Soviet women in World War II]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person | name = Tamara Pamyatnykh | image = Тамара Устиновна Памятных.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = Тамара Устиновна Памятных | birth_date = {{Birth date|1919|12|30}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2012|7|26|1919|12|30}} | death_place = [[Rostov-on-Don]], [[Rostov Oblast]] | allegiance = {{USSR}} | unit = [[586th Fighter Aviation Regiment]] | branch = {{flagicon image|Flag of the Soviet Air Force.svg}} [[Soviet Air Forces|Soviet Air Force]] | serviceyears = 1941 — 1945 | battles = [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front of World War II]] |awards = {{Order of the Red Banner (medallion)}} {{Order of the Patriotic War 1st Class (medallion)}} {{Order of the Patriotic War 2nd Class (medallion)}} }} '''Tamara Pamyatnykh''' (1919-2012) was a fighter pilot for the [[Soviet Air Forces]] during the [[Second World War]]. Following an action while on patrol on 19 March 1943, she was awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner]].
==Career== Pamyatnykh began flying [[glider (aircraft)|glider]]s at 16, and soon qualified for a private pilot's license and instructor's certificate at the flight school in [[Ulyanovsk]]. When the [[Second World War]] began, she signed up for the Soviet forces. When [[Marina Raskova]] was asked to recruit female pilots in 1941, Pamyatnykh was sufficiently well-known as a pilot that she was specifically approached.<ref name="welch">{{cite book|last1=Welch|first1=Rosanne|title=Encyclopedia of Women in Aviation and Space|date=1998|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara, Calif|isbn=978-0-874369-588|page=169}}</ref>
She underwent further flight training in [[Engels, Saratov Oblast]] in October 1941, and was subsequently assigned to the 586th Fighter Squadron alongside other female aces such as [[Lydia Litvyak]],<ref name="welch"/> and worked as a duo with [[Galina Burdina]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Noggle|first1=Anne|title=A Dance with Death: Soviet Airwomen in World War II|date=2008|publisher=Texas A & M University Press|location=Texas|isbn=978-1-58544-177-8|page=205|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-ESSJzUOk2oC&pg=PA205&lpg=PA205&dq=%22Galina+Burdina%22&source=bl&ots=8n6x84mBwZ&sig=p5vMFqhEM4KXC1krA4FuzPWWgKM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQjcbC1f_YAhUlKsAKHW_0DAcQ6AEITDAL#v=onepage&q=%22Galina%20Burdina%22&f=false}}</ref> As a junior lieutenant, Pamyatnykh was on patrol with [[Raisa Surnachevskaya]] over a railway junction on 19 March 1943.<ref name="few"/> Faced with an attack by 42 [[Junkers]] bombers, the two pilots attacked with the sun behind them. Each shot down two bombers each, with Pamyatnykh continuing to fight until she ran out of ammunition.<ref name=witches/> She decided to take out a third bomber by ramming it, but as she got close, one of her wings was shot off and she spun out of control.<ref name="few">{{cite news|last1=Glancey|first1=Jonathan|title=The very few|url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2001/dec/15/weekend.jonathanglancey|accessdate=19 November 2017|work=The Guardian|date=15 December 2001}}</ref> She bailed out and [[parachute|parachuted]] to the ground. The nearby locals were shocked when they rushed to help and discovered that she was a woman.<ref name=witches>{{cite news|title=Night Witches|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/mobile/documentaries/2009/11/091102_night_witches.shtml|accessdate=19 November 2017|work=BBC World Service|date=2 November 2009}}</ref> She was taken back to base, where Pamyatnykh learnt that the German attack had been prevented as the rest of the force had turned back. For her heroism, Pamyatnykh was awarded the [[Order of the Red Banner]] and given a gold watch by [[King of the United Kingdom|King]] [[George VI]] of the United Kingdom.<ref name="welch"/>
During another mission she was downed by [[friendly fire]]. In 1944, she married a squadron commander named Nikolai from the same regiment.<ref name="welch"/><ref name="few"/> They both survived the war, although he spent some time in a Nazi [[concentration camp]]. Following the end of the war, they had three children.<ref name="welch"/> Pamyatnykh later went on to become the chairman of the women's war veterans' commission.<ref name="few"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Pamyatnykh, Tamara}}

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Miguel bernal jimenez statue morelia nov2006.jpg|thumb|[[Miguel Bernal Jiménez]], the composer of ''Tata Vasco'' (statue in the Conservatorio de las Rosas, [[Morelia, Michoacán]])]] '''''Tata Vasco''''' is an [[opera]] in five scenes composed by [[Miguel Bernal Jiménez]] to a Spanish [[libretto]] with nationalistic and devoutly [[Roman Catholic]] themes by the Mexican priest and poet, Manuel Muñoz. It premiered in [[Pátzcuaro]], [[Mexico]] on 15 February 1941. The opera is based on the life of [[Vasco de Quiroga]], the first Bishop of [[Michoacán]] and known to the Indians of the region as 'Tata Vasco'. Considered one of Bernal Jiménez's most emblematic scores,<ref name="Brennan" /> the music incorporates native melodies, dances, and instruments as well as elements of [[Gregorian chant]].
==Background and performance history== [[File:Palacio de bellas artes 1.jpg|thumb|left|210 px|Mexico City's [[Palacio de Bellas Artes]]]] Described as a ''drama sinfónico'' (symphonic drama), ''Tata Vasco'' was the first and only opera by Bernal Jiménez and composed when he was 30 years old. It was to be part of the celebrations for the 400th anniversary of [[Vasco de Quiroga]]'s arrival in [[Pátzcuaro]] and was set to a libretto in rhyming verse by Manuel Muñoz Mendoza, a Catholic priest, poet, and writer who lived in [[Morelia]], the composer's native city.<ref>Cortés (1979) p. 149</ref> The world premiere was originally planned for 1940 at the [[Palacio de Bellas Artes]] in [[Mexico City]] but was postponed due to fears that it would "provoke religious controversy".<ref>Standish (2006) p. 102. See also Saavedra (2007)</ref> Instead, it premiered on 15 February 1941 in a performance conducted by the composer in the ruins of the [[Franciscan]] monastery chapel in Pátzcuaro.
The opera had its Mexico City premiere at the Teatro Arbeu on 15 March 1941 and in September of that year was performed to great enthusiasm in [[Morelia]]. It was performed in 1943 at the [[Teatro Degollado]] in [[Guadalajara]] and in 1948 had its Spanish premiere, when at the invitation of [[Francisco Franco|General Franco]],<ref>Standish (2006) p. 102</ref> a reduced [[oratorio]] version was performed in [[Madrid]]. Part of Spain's commemorations for the 400th anniversary of the death of [[Hernán Cortés]], the Madrid performance met with considerable success.<ref>Stevenson (1952) p. 264</ref> On 29 September 1949, eight years after its premiere, ''Tata Vasco'' was finally staged at the Palacio de Bellas Artes where it was given a run of two performances, both conducted by the composer.<ref>pre-1950 performance history in Mexico from Sosa (2005)</ref> The opera was revived there in 1975, 1992 (in concert version), and in 2006 to mark the 50th anniversary of the composer's death.<ref name= "Brennan">Brennan (28 November 2008)</ref>
''Tata Vasco'' was given two performances by the National Opera Company of Mexico at the Teatro de la Ciudad de Mexico in February 2010, the year which marks not only the bicentenary of the [[Mexican War of Independence]] and the centenary of the [[Mexican Revolution]] but also the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth.<ref>''Protocolo'' (12 February 2010)</ref>
==Score== The opera is scored for: 2 flutes, 1 piccolo, 2 oboes, 1 [[Cor anglais (English horn)|cor anglais]], 2 clarinets, 1 bass clarinet, 2 bassoons, 4 [[French horn]]s, 3 trumpets, 3 trombones, tuba, harp, piano, [[celesta]], cymbals, drum, [[timbales]], bombo (type of [[bass drum]]), pandero (type of [[frame drum]]), gong, [[glockenspiel]], bells, [[maraca]]s, [[vibraphone]], [[teponaztli]], and [[String section|strings]].<ref>Sosa (2005)</ref>
==Roles and premiere cast== [[File:Vasco de Quiroga.jpg|thumb|190 px|<center>[[Vasco de Quiroga]]</center>]] *[[Vasco de Quiroga]] ("Tata Vasco", Bishop of [[Michoacán]]), [[baritone]] – Gilberto Cerda<ref>premiere cast from Sosa (2005)</ref> *Coyuva (daughter of the [[Purépecha people|Purépecha]] king, [[Tangaxuan II]]), [[soprano]] – Leonor Caden *Ticátame (a Purépecha prince), [[tenor]] – Ricardo C. Lara *Petámuti (a Purépecha sorcerer), [[Bass (voice type)|bass]] – Felipe Aguilera *Cuninjángari (the Purépecha governor of [[Tzintzuntzan, Michoacán|Tzintzuntzan]]), baritone – Ernesto Farfán *Three [[friar]]s, tenor, baritone, and bass – Nicolás Rico, Miguel Botello and Saturnino Huerta *Watchman, baritone *First singer, tenor *Second singer, [[mezzo-soprano]] *A child, [[boy soprano]]
The cast also includes a [[SATB|mixed chorus]], children, and dancers
==Synopsis== :''Setting: [[Michoacán]], circa 1537'' <ref>synopsis based on the one written by the composer and reprinted in Sosa (2005)</ref>
'''Scene 1.''' At night in a forest where the Purépecha kings are buried, the warriors, led by the sorcerer Petámuti, are dancing around a bonfire. They have sworn revenge for the death of their king who was [[Death by burning|burnt at the stake]] by the Spanish [[conquistador]], [[Nuño de Guzmán]]. Princess Coyuva, the king's daughter, arrives bearing his ashes. Her betrothed, Prince Ticátame, expresses his hatred for the Spanish and determination to avenge her father's death. Coyuva, who has become a Christian, tells him to forgive his enemies and to follow the teachings of 'Tata Vasco', Don [[Vasco de Quiroga]], a priest and the Spanish judge (''[[Oidor]]'') for the territory. When Ticátame is persuaded by Coyuva's words, Petámuti tries to kill him and in the ensuing struggle with the prince is killed. In a fury, Petámuti curses the young lovers.
'''Scene 2.''' In the sacristy of the [[Franciscan]] church in [[Tzintzuntzan, Michoacán|Tzintzuntzan]], Indian children play while waiting for their lesson. A jovial friar arrives and after the lesson tells the children a story and asks them to sing like minstrels. When their song is finished, the children depart and Tata Vasco enters to receive a delegation from the Indians in Tzintzuntzan, led by Cuninjángari, the city's governor and a relative of the dead king. Don Vasco assures them of his desire to help them and urges them to give up nomadic life and [[polygamy]] and convert to Christianity. Ticátame and Coyuva then arrive for an audience and ask Vasco (who has been made Bishop of Michoacán) to marry them in a Christian ceremony. [[File:PatzcuaroLakeIslands fromTheTopOfJanitzioIsland PatzcuaroLake MichoacanMexico.jpg|thumb|<center>[[Lake Pátzcuaro]]</center>]] '''Scene 3.''' At dawn in the courtyard of the Franciscan church, Indians can be heard singing as they work in the fields. They then come to the courtyard bringing gifts. Vasco and his entourage arrive for the wedding of Ticátame and Coyuva. Before entering the church, he speaks to the couple about the [[Sacraments of the Catholic Church|sacrament]] of marriage and they promise to be faithful to each other. The doors of the church swing open and a choir is heard singing. As the wedding party are about to enter the church, the sorcer Petámuti arrives, dagger in hand, to murder Ticátame and Coyuva. Petámuti accidentally falls on the church steps and is mortally wounded by his own weapon. Hearing his cries, Cuninjángari calls to Don Vasco to minister to the dying man. After Vasco speaks to him, Petámuti asks to be baptised before he dies. A group of Indians then carry off his body while songs of praise (''ablados'') heard in the distance.
'''Scene 4.''' On a hill overlooking [[Lake Pátzcuaro]], there is a fiesta to celebrate Ticátame and Coyuva's wedding. Don Vasco arrives and watches four dances performed by the Indians and listens to a song and toast to the couple in their native language. Before leaving, he addresses the Indians and invites them to come to [[Pátzcuaro]] where they can learn new trades to better their lives. Don Vasco departs and the scene closes with another dance in which all present take part.
'''Scene 5.''' In the audience room of the Bishop's palace in [[Pátzcuaro]], Don Vasco is looking over plans for the new cathedral and seminary. A group of Indians arrive to present the first fruits of the industries he has taught them. A colourful parade ensues in which gourd cups, pottery, fishing nets, guitars, blouses and shawls are displayed to Don Vasco. Deeply touched, he tells the Indians that he will dedicate his life to their welfare and shows them an image of the Virgin of Good Health, who he says will protect them and their children.
==Notes and references== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *Brennan, Juan Arturo, [http://www.jornada.unam.mx/2006/10/28/index.php?section=opinion&article=a06a1cul "Tata Vasco: ópera revisionista"], ''La Jornada'', 28 November 2008 (in Spanish, accessed 29 March 2010) *Cortés, Raúl Arreola, ''La poesía en Michoacán: desde la época prehispánica hasta nuestros días'', Fimax Publicistas, 1979 (in Spanish) *''Protocolo'', [http://www.protocolo.com.mx/cultura/con-la-opera-tata-vasco-bellas-artes-inicia-su-temporada-2010/ "Con la ópera Tata Vasco, Bellas Artes inicia su temporada 2010"], 12 February 2010 (in Spanish, accessed 29 March 2010) *Saavedra, Leonora, "Staging the Nation: Race, Religion, and History in Mexican Opera of the 1940s", ''Opera Quarterly'', Vol. 23, 2007, pp. 1–21 *Sosa, José Octavio, [http://www.operacalli.com/argumentos/tata_vasco.htm ''Tata Vasco'']{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}, ''Diccionario de la Ópera Mexicana'', Consejo Nacional para la Cultura y las Artes, 2005 (reprinted on operacalli.com with permission of the author) (in Spanish, accessed 29 March 2010) *Standish, Peter, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Rjq1G32WPtgC&pg=PA102&dq=tata+vasco+opera&as_brr=3&cd=6#v=onepage&q=tata%20vasco%20opera&f=false ''A Companion to Mexican Studies''], Boydell & Brewer Ltd, 2006. {{ISBN|1-85566-134-9}} *Stevenson, Robert, ''Music in Mexico: A historical survey'', Crowell, 1952 *{{GroveOnline|title=Bernal Jiménez, Miguel|author=Stevenson, Robert|access-date=29 March 2010}}
