{{more citations needed|date=April 2018}} {{notability|event|date=April 2018}}
{{Infobox recurring event |name = The Castle of Muskogee |image = |alt = |caption = |location = [[Muskogee, Oklahoma|Muskogee]], [[Oklahoma]] |genre = Multipurpose fairgrounds |first = 1995 |dates = Late April thru first weekend June (six weekends), Late September to Halloween, Thanksgiving to New Year's Eve |attendance = 88,000 (2017 season) |area = {{convert|30|acre|m2}} |free_label = Stages |free_text = 15 |website = {{url|http://www.okcastle.com/}} }} The '''Oklahoma Renaissance Festival''' is a multipurpose [[fair]]ground in [[Oklahoma]] located in [[Muskogee, Oklahoma|Muskogee]], about 135 miles east of [[Oklahoma City]] and 55 miles southeast of Tulsa. The castle runs The Oklahoma Renaissance Festival from late April to Memorial City weekend over 6 weeks. It also hosts a Halloween Festival from late September to [[Halloween]], Castle [[Christmas]] from Thanksgiving to New Year's Eve and Boares Head Feast in mid November.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/</ref> The place was build from a warehouse and the surrounding field.<ref>https://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/17327</ref>
==General information== During the renaissance festival period, the site features 15 stages over 30 acres plus 40 acres of parking.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/renaissance.html</ref> It is set in 1569 during the reign of [[Elizabeth I]]. Its main feature is Castleton Village, a 13-acre area where the majority of merchants reside. The Halloween festival resides in Castleton Village and hosts 11 attractions.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/halloween.html</ref> It also hosts the Castle Zombie Run held annually in September.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/zombie-run.html</ref> The Boares Head Feast occurs in November and provides a four-course meal as well as entertainment.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/boares-head-feaste.html</ref> Castle Christmas takes place in the castle grounds and provides a light display with over 2,000 lights.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/castle-christmas.html</ref> The area also sells fireworks during the Fourth of July and New Year's Eve holiday seasons.<ref>http://www.okcastle.com/fireworks.html</ref>
== See also ==
* [[Renaissance fair]] * [[List of Renaissance fairs]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Renaissance fairs]]

revision.text:
{{italictitle}} '''''The Right Honourable Gentleman''''' is a 1962 play by [[Michael Dyne]], first staged in 1964.<ref name=Manuscript/>
==Plot== ''The Right Honourable Gentleman'' is a dramatization of the rather complicated real-life [[Sir Charles Dilke, 2nd Baronet#Crawford scandal|Crawford Scandal]] of Victorian England. [[Sir Charles Dilke, 2nd Baronet|Sir Charles Dilke]], an important [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal]] member of [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]], is seen as a possible successor to [[William Ewart Gladstone|Gladstone]] as [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]]. The circumstances leading to his destruction, his private affairs as contrasted with those of the Empire, form the crux of the play.<ref name=Playbill/><ref name=DPS/>
The play introduce Dilke in his finest hour, an obvious choice for the new cabinet. But a certain Mr. Crawford sues his wife for divorce, naming Sir Charles as an involved party, based on his wife's confession that she had been having an affair with Sir Charles for some time. Mrs. Crawford provides dates and facts and is quite credible, while Sir Charles offers avowals of complete innocence, not just publicly but solemnly sworn to in private to his fiancee.<ref name=DPS/>
And in fact Mrs. Crawford is lying, and instead is madly in love and carrying on with a certain Captain Foster, which may have been a reason for inventing her charges against the unfortunate Sir Charles. But Sir Charles ''had'' been conducting a long-term affair with Mrs. Crawford's mother, which, when it comes out, destroys his reputation and career.<ref name=DPS/>
==Productions== ''The Right Honourable Gentleman'', produced by [[Emile Littler]], premiered in London's [[West End theatre|West End]] on May 28, 1964,<ref name=Manuscript/> and ran for three years.<ref name=NYTimes/> Players included [[Anthony Quayle]], [[Corin Redgrave]], [[Anna Massey]], and [[Terence Bayler]], and [[Glen Byam Shaw]] directed.<ref name=BaylerObit/>
''The Right Honourable Gentleman'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] on October 19, 1965 at the [[Billy Rose Theatre]]. There were no out-of-town tryouts, instead 12 preview performances at the Billy Rose. [[Charles Gray (actor)|Charles Gray]] played the title role, Sir Charles Dilke. Other players were [[Coral Brown]], [[Sarah Badel]] as Mrs. Crawford, [[William Roerick]] as [[Joseph Chamberlain]], and [[Marie Wallace]]. [[Frith Banbury]] directed.<ref name=IBDb/><ref name=Playbill/><ref name=Wallace/>
The ''[[New York Journal-American]]'' described the production as "a British import in their best tradition", while the ''[[New York Herald Tribune]]'' said "it is deft at keeping you riveted to its tricky game of truth or consequences".<ref name=DPS/> The ''[[New York Morning Telegraph]]'' said "now we have [a play] of meat and substance, of stature and importance" and praised the "superior cast". [[Jack O'Brian]] wrote that "''The Right Honourable Gentleman'' is a fine, fine play... sheer entertainment in its shock-treatment of a theme written brilliantly, plotted beautifully, acted soundly, and produced properly".<ref name=Wallace/> [[Otis Guernsey Jr.]] wrote that it was "a good job expertly done, but perhaps just a bit creaky in its theatrical joints as it played out its mannered exposé".<ref name=Guernsey/>
''The Right Honourable Gentleman'' was only a modest hit on Broadway, and the [[1966 New York City transit strike]] toward the end of its run harmed business.<ref name=Wallace/> The play closed on January 29, 1966 after 118 performances.<ref name=IBDb/><ref name=Playbill/> At the [[20th Tony Awards]] in 1966, ''The Right Honourable Gentleman'' was nominated for [[Tony Award for Best Play|best play]] and [[Tony Award for Best Costume Design|best costume design]].
Revivals have included a 1967 production at the Huntington Hartford Theatre (now the [[Ricardo Montalbán Theatre]]) in [[Los Angeles]],<ref name=LATimes/> and a production during the 1968–1969 season at the [[Citadel Theatre]] in [[Edmonton]].<ref name=Citadel/>
==References== {{reflist|refs= <ref name=Manuscript>{{cite book |last=Dyne |first=Michael |title=The Right Honourable Gentleman |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Right_Honourable_Gentleman.html?id=JFs9Gof00YwC |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |year=1998 |publisher=Dramatist's Play Service |isbn=978-0822209515 |pages=2-5}}</ref>
<ref name=IBDb>{{cite web |url=https://www.ibdb.com/broadway-production/the-right-honourable-gentleman-3256 |title=The Right Honourable Gentleman |work=IBDb (Internet Broadway Database) |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=Playbill>{{cite web |url=http://www.playbill.com/production/the-right-honourable-gentleman-billy-rose-theatre-vault-0000002770 |title=The Right Honourable Gentleman |work=Playbill |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=BaylerObit>{{cite web |url=https://www.thestage.co.uk/features/obituaries/2016/obituary-terence-bayler/ |title=Obituary: Terence Bayler |author=Michael Quinn |date=September 14, 2016 |work=The Stage |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=DPS>{{cite web |url=http://www.dramatists.com/cgi-bin/db/single.asp?key=1589 |title=The Right Honourable Gentleman |publisher=Dramatist's Play Service |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=NYTimes>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/05/19/obituaries/michael-dyne-70-writer-of-dramas-for-tv.html |title=Michael Dyne, 70, Writer of Dramas for TV [obituary] |date=May 19, 1989 |work=New York Times |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=Wallace>{{cite book |last=Wallace |first=Marie |title=On Stage & in Shadows: A Career Memoir |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=onACTz_dL6UC&pg=PA70&lpg=PA70 |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |year=2005 |publisher=iUniverse |isbn=978-0595358779 |pages=70-74}}</ref>
<ref name=Guernsey>{{cite book |last=Guernsey |first=Otis L. |title=Curtain Times: The New York Theatre, 1965-1987 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Tlz1UV4jTr8C&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42 |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |year=2000 |publisher=Applause Theatre & Cinema Books |isbn=978-0936839240 |page=42}}</ref>
<ref name=Citadel>{{cite web |url=http://www.citadeltheatre.com/the-citadel-theatres-seasons/ |title=The Citadel Theatre’s Seasons |publisher=Citadel Theatre |accessdate=February 23, 2017}}</ref>
<ref name=LATimes>{{cite news |date=March 12, 1967 |title=Hartford To Stage Own 'Gentleman' |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |page=177}}</ref> }}
==Further reading== *{{cite book |last=Dyne |first=Michael |title=The Right Honourable Gentleman |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/The_Right_Honourable_Gentleman.html?id=JFs9Gof00YwC |accessdate=February 23, 2017 |year=1966 |publisher=Random House |location=New York |isbn=}}

[[Image:Fluorite-unit-cell-3D-ionic.png|thumb|[[thorium dioxide]]]] [[Image:Thorotrast.jpg|thumb|Thorotrast bottle]] '''Thorotrast''' is a [[suspension (chemistry)|suspension]] containing particles of the [[radioactive decay|radioactive]] compound [[thorium dioxide]], ThO<sub>2</sub>, that was used as a [[radiocontrast agent]] in [[medical radiography]] in the 1930s and 1940s. Use in some countries, such as the [[United States|U.S.]], continued into the 1950s.
[[Thorium]] compounds produce excellent images because of thorium's high opacity to X-rays (it has a high [[cross section (physics)|cross section]] for absorption). However, thorium is retained in the body, and it is radioactive, emitting harmful [[alpha radiation]] as it decays. Because the suspension offered high image quality and had virtually no immediate side-effects compared to the alternatives available at the time, Thorotrast became widely used after its introduction in 1931. [[António Egas Moniz]] contributed to its development.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tondreau | first1 = R. | year = 1985 | title = Egas Moniz 1874-1955 | url = | journal = Radiographics | volume = 5 | issue = 6| pages = 994–997 | doi=10.1148/radiographics.5.6.3916824 | pmid=3916824}}</ref> About 2 to 10 million patients worldwide have been treated with Thorotrast. However, today it has shown an increase risk in certain cancers such as cholangiocarcinomas and angiosarcomas of the liver.
==Safety== Even at the time of introduction, there was concern about the safety of Thorotrast. Following injection, the drug is distributed to the [[liver]], [[spleen]], [[lymph node]]s, and [[bone]], where it is absorbed. After this initial absorption, redistribution takes place at a very slow pace. Specifically, the [[biological half-life]] is estimated to be 22 years.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ead.anl.gov/pub/doc/thorium.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716163231/http://www.ead.anl.gov/pub/doc/thorium.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> This means that the organs of patients who have been given Thorotrast will be exposed to internal alpha radiation for the rest of their lives. The significance of this long-term exposure was not fully understood at the time of Thorotrast's introduction in 1931.
Due to the release of alpha particles, Thorotrast was found to be extremely carcinogenic. There is a high over-incidence of various cancers in patients who have been treated with Thorotrast. The cancers occur some years (usually 20-30) after injection of Thorotrast. The risk of developing [[Hepatocellular carcinoma|liver cancer]] (or [[cholangiocarcinoma|bile duct cancer]]) in former Thorotrast patients has been measured to be well above 100 times the risk of the rest of the population. The risk of [[leukemia]] appears to be 20 times higher in Thorotrast patients.<ref name=Kaick>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.2307/3580117| issn = 0033-7587| volume = 152| issue = 6| pages = S64-S71| last = Kaick| first = Gerhard van|author2=Andreas Dalheimer |author3=Sakiko Hornik |author4=Alexander Kaul |author5=Dagmar Liebermann |author6=Hertha Lührs |author7=Andreas Spiethoff |author8=Kurt Wegener |author9=H. Wesch | title = The German Thorotrast Study: Recent Results and Assessment of Risks| journal = [[Radiation Research]]| date = 1999-12-01| jstor = 3580117}}</ref> Thorotrast exposure has also been associated with the development of [[angiosarcoma]]. German patients exposed to Thorotrast had their median life-expectancy shortened by 14 years in comparison to a similar non-exposed control group.<ref name="Becker">{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.ejca.2008.02.050| issn = 0959-8049| volume = 44| issue = 9| pages = 1259–1268| last = Becker| first = N|author2=D Liebermann |author3=H Wesch |author4=G Vankaick | title = Mortality among Thorotrast-exposed patients and an unexposed comparison group in the German Thorotrast study| journal = [[European Journal of Cancer]]| accessdate = 2011-04-30| date = June 2008| url = http://www.ejcancer.info/article/S0959-8049(08)00174-3/abstract}}</ref>
Thorium is no longer used in X-ray contrast agents. Today, [[iodine|iodinated]] hydrophilic (water-soluble) molecules are universally used as injected contrast agents in X-ray procedures.
The [[Denmark|Danish]] director [[Nils Malmros]]'s movie, ''[[Facing the Truth (2002 film)|Facing the Truth]]'' (original [[Danish language|Danish]] title ''At Kende Sandheden'') from 2002, portrays the dilemma that faced Malmros's father, [[Richard Malmros]], when treating his patients in the 1940s. Richard Malmros was deeply concerned about the persistence of Thorotrast in the body but was forced to use Thorotrast, because the only available alternative ([[Propyliodone|per-abrodil]]) had serious immediate side-effects, suffered from image quality problems and was difficult to obtain during the [[Second World War]]. The use of Thorotrast in Denmark ended in 1947 when safer alternatives became available.
==Current use== Thorotrast has also been used in research to stain neural tissue samples for examination by [[historadiography]].<ref>{{cite journal | pmid = 4593184 | volume=118 | issue=4 | title=Contact historadiography of nervous tissue impregnated with thorotrast |date=August 1973 | journal=Am J Roentgenol Radium Ther Nucl Med | pages=923–6}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist | 30em}}
{{Contrast media}}

{{Infobox military conflict | conflict = | partof = | image = Newfoundland Grand Banks and EEZ border.png | image_size = 300px | caption = The location of the bulk of the conflict | date = 1994–1996 | place = [[Grand Banks of Newfoundland]] and the [[English Channel]] | coordinates = | result = {{cite web|title=Province welcomes Canadian victory in Turbot War case|url=http://www.releases.gov.nl.ca/releases/1998/exec/1204n01.htm|publisher=Executive Council}}{{cite web|last1=Springer|first1=Allen L.|title=The Canadian Turbot War with Spain: Unilateral State Action in Defense of Environmental Interests|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/107049659700600103}}
Canadian position recognized by the [[European Union]] | combatant1 = {{flag|Canada}} {{collapsible list |title= '''Supported by:''' |{{flag|United Kingdom}}

{{navy|Germany}} | casualties1 = 1 fishing vessel captured | casualties2 = 1 fishing vessel captured | casualties3 = | notes = | title = Turbot War | causes = Fishing rights dispute between Canada and Spain | casualties_label = }} The '''Turbot War''' (known in Spain as '''Guerra del Fletán''') was an international fishing dispute between [[Canada]] (supported by the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]]) and [[Spain]] (supported by the [[European Union]] and [[Iceland]]) in which Canada stopped a Spanish [[fishing trawler]] from [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] in [[international waters]] and arrested its crew. Canada claimed that European Union [[factory ship]]s were illegally [[overfishing]] [[Greenland halibut]], also known as Greenland turbot, on the [[Grand Banks of Newfoundland|Grand Banks]], just outside Canada's declared {{convert|200|nmi|km|adj=on}} [[exclusive economic zone]] (EEZ). ==Prelude== Territorial seas have changed over time, having begun with a {{convert|3|nmi|km|lk=in|adj=on}} "cannon shot" territorial sea, followed by the long-standing extension to a {{convert|12|nmi|km|adj=on}} standard. The economic control of the waters surrounding nations to a {{convert|200|nmi|km|adj=on}} [[exclusive economic zone]]s (EEZ) were agreed at the conference on the [[Third United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea]] in 1982, and became recognised internationally on November 14, 1994. As a self-governing colony and dominion, [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]]'s foreign policy, just as Canada's, was established by the British government until the [[Statute of Westminster 1931]]. However, in 1934, Newfoundland's government voted to be put under the administration of a commission appointed by London; this situation remained until 1949 when the dominion entered [[Canadian Confederation]]. Following Confederation, Canada recognized many of the foreign policy agreements Newfoundland had entered under this commission. During the 1950s to the 1970s, the domestic and foreign fishing fleets became increasingly [[Fishing industry|industrialized]], with massive [[factory freezer trawlers]] fishing out of Newfoundland ports – foreign fleets were based in Newfoundland and could fish 12 nautical miles offshore, while domestic fleets could fish in both the territorial sea and the offshore. By the 1970s the overfishing by industrial vessels in the waters of the other provinces of eastern Canada was evident, although each subsequent federal government continued to ignore this problem, and even contributed to it by using the issuance of fishing licenses for more inshore and offshore domestic vessels. Between 1973 and 1982 the [[United Nations]] and its member states negotiated the Third Convention of the [[United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea|Law of the Sea]] – one component of which was the concept of nations being allowed to declare an EEZ. Although not adopted into international law until 1982, the possibility of declaring an EEZ became a ''de facto'' reality in 1977 with the conclusion of those sections of the Third Conference negotiations relating to [[maritime boundary]] and economic control. Many nations worldwide declared 200-nautical-mile EEZs, including Canada and the United States. The EEZ boundaries became a foreign policy issue where overlapping claims existed, as was the case between Canada and the United States in the [[Gulf of Maine]], [[Dixon Entrance]], [[Strait of Juan de Fuca]] and [[Beaufort Sea]], as well as between Canada and [[France]] in the case of [[St. Pierre and Miquelon]]. But on the whole, for fishermen in eastern Canada, it meant they could fish unhindered out to the limit without fear of competing with the foreign fleets. During the late 1970s and early 1980s, Canada's domestic offshore fleet grew as fishermen and [[fish processing]] companies rushed to take advantage. It was also during this time when it was noticed that the foreign fleets now pushed out to 200 nautical miles offshore and excluded from the rich Canadian waters, were increasing their harvest on the small areas of the [[Grand Banks]] that were outside the area of the EEZ. By the late 1980s the smaller catches of [[Atlantic cod|Northern cod]] were being reported throughout the Atlantic coast of Canada as the federal government and citizens of coastal regions in the area began to face the reality that the domestic and foreign overfishing had taken its toll. In the end stocks of cod in and around Canada's EEZ were severely depleted. Reluctant to act at a time of declining political popularity, the federal government was finally forced to take drastic action in 1992 when a [[Collapse of the Atlantic northwest cod fishery|total moratorium]] was declared indefinitely for the Northern Cod. The immediate impact was felt most in Newfoundland, followed by the Atlantic coast of [[Nova Scotia]]. The nascent [[Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization]], organized after the 1977 EEZ declarations to coordinate conservation efforts in Canada, the United States, and member nations in Europe (both western and eastern bloc countries), also declared a ban, however it was implemented too late to be effective – cod which 5–10 years before was being caught in record numbers, had vanished almost overnight to the point where it was considered for [[endangered species]] protection. The economic impact in coastal Newfoundland was unprecedented. To lessen the impact that its policies of permitting overfishing had exacted upon rural Newfoundlanders, the federal government swiftly created a relief program called "The Atlantic Groundfish Strategy" (TAGS) to provide short- to medium-term financial support, and employment retraining for the longer term. Despite TAGS, Newfoundland and coastal Nova Scotia were bleeding severely as communities began to experience an out-migration on a scale not seen in Canada since the prairie [[dust bowl]]s of the 1930s. The anger at federal political figures was palpable and with the wholesale rejection of short-term Prime Minister [[Kim Campbell]], incoming prime minister [[Jean Chrétien]]'s [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberals]] were going to face the ongoing wrath of voters whose entire livelihoods had been decimated as a result of decades of federal neglect and mismanagement, and whose communities, property values, net worth, and way of life were declining rapidly. [[File:briantobin.jpg|thumb|left|[[Brian Tobin]] was the Canadian politician who was largely responsible for managing the conflict. This earned him the nicknames 'Captain Canada' and 'The Turbotonator'{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2005/07/27/Turbot-Estai-050727.html |work=CBC News |title=Court backs Canada's seizure of trawler during 'turbot war' |date=July 27, 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090714191626/http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2005/07/27/Turbot-Estai-050727.html |archivedate=2009-07-14 |df= }}]] In the years since the cod moratorium, federal fisheries policy makers and scientists had scrambled to attempt to find a replacement species that could at least reinject economic stimulus into the affected regions. The ground fishery, while a fraction of what it had been during the cod years, did have some bright spots – one of which was the Greenland halibut commonly known in Canada as turbot. The turbot had decreased in demand due to a common dislike for the taste in the European Union. Canada was not alone in recognizing the growing value of the turbot, and foreign fishing fleets operating off the 200-nautical-mile EEZ were beginning to pursue the species in increasing numbers. By 1994, Canada and NAFO had tracked about 50 violations of boats crossing the 200-nautical-mile EEZ limit to fish illegally within Canadian waters, as well as recording use of illegal gear and overfishing outside Canadian waters. The new federal [[Minister of Fisheries and Oceans (Canada)|Minister of Fisheries and Oceans]], [[Brian Tobin]], directed the [[Department of Fisheries and Oceans (Canada)|Department of Fisheries and Oceans]] (DFO), along with the [[Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade (Canada)|Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade]] (DFAIT) to begin a very aggressive dialogue with the [[European Union]] over the presence of its fishing fleet and its practices, particularly the use of illegal trawl nets just outside the Canadian EEZ while fishing for turbot. Tobin's critics in Canada noted that he was likely using his department as a political prop to shore up support during a time of increased social unrest in the region, yet in the winter of 1995, Tobin directed DFO to establish a legal argument which could be made for the seizure of a foreign vessel in international waters using the premise of conservation. ==The ''Estai'' incident== Minister Tobin and the federal cabinet then told the DFO to demonstrate Canadian resolve on the issue by "making an example" of a European Union fishing vessel. On 9 March 1995, an offshore patrol aircraft detected the Spanish stern trawler ''Estai'' in international waters outside Canada's 200-nautical-mile EEZ. Armed DFO fisheries patrol vessels, Cape Roger, Leonard J. Cowley and [[Canadian Coast Guard]] Ship Sir Wilfred Grenfell, intercepted and pursued ''Estai'', which cut its weighted trawl net and fled after an initial boarding attempt, resulting in a several hours' chase which ended after the Canadian Fisheries Patrol vessel ''Cape Roger'' fired a .50 calibre (12.7 mm) machine gun across the [[Bow (ship)|bow]] of ''Estai''. The Canadian Coast Guard ship {{ship|CCGS|Sir Wilfred Grenfell||2}} used high-pressure fire-fighting [[water cannon]] to deter other Spanish fishing vessels from disrupting the operation. Finally, armed DFO Fishery Officers and [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) officers boarded ''Estai'' in international waters on the Grand Banks. ''Estai'' was escorted to [[St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador|St. John's]], arriving with great [[fanfare]] across the province and region — and the country. Canada's [[Federal Court of Canada|federal court]] processed the case and the charges against the crew while Spain and the European Union protested vehemently, threatening boycotts against Canada and wishing to have the case heard at the [[International Court of Justice]]. Tobin and his department ignored the controversy and instead had the oversized trawl net which ''Estai'' had cut free salvaged. The DFO contracted a Fishery Products International ground fish trawler to drag for ''Estai''{{'}}s trawl. On the first attempt it retrieved the ''Estai''{{'}}s net which had been cut. It was found that ''Estai'' was using a liner with a mesh size smaller than permitted by the Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organisation (NAFO). The net was shipped to [[New York City]] where Tobin called an international press conference on board a rented [[barge]] in the [[East River]] outside the [[United Nations]] headquarters. There, the net from ''Estai'' was displayed, hanging from an enormous crane, and Tobin used the occasion to shame the Spanish and EU governments, pointing out the small size of the holes in the net which are illegal in Canada. Spain never denied that the net was from ''Estai'' but continued to protest Canada's use of "extra-territorial force". The Spanish government asked the International Court of Justice in The Hague, Netherlands, for leave to hear a case claiming that Canada had no right to detain ''Estai''. However, the court later refused the case.{{cite web |url=http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/96/7533.pdf |title=Fisheries Jurisdiction (Spain v. Canada), Jurisdiction of the Court, Judgment, I. C.J. Reports 1998 |date=1998 |publisher=International Court of Justice |issn=0074-4441 |pages=432}} Later, Canada released the crew of ''Estai''. On the same day that Tobin was in New York, the United Kingdom blocked an EU proposal to impose sanctions on Canada. Tobin claimed that Canada would not enter negotiations as long as illegal fishing continued, and demanded the withdrawal of all fishing vessels in the area as a precondition. On March 15, the owners of ''Estai'' posted $500,000 bond for the vessel, and it was returned to Spain. Subsequently, the rest of the fishing fleet also left the area, and preliminary talks were scheduled for the upcoming [[G7]] conference. These talks failed, as the Spanish refused to change their position, and Spanish fishing vessels subsequently returned to Grand Banks. Spain also implemented a visa mandate for all Canadians visiting, or planning to visit Spain. This resulted in several Canadians being deported from Spain who had been legally in Spain up until the moment the visa mandate was adopted.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/03/15/news/15iht-fish_3.html |title=Madrid Sets Visa Rules And Calls for Vessels To Start Fishing Again : Spain Steps Up Pressure on Canada in Boat Dispute |newspaper=The New York Times |last=Buerkle |first=Tom |date=15 March 1995 |accessdate=15 December 2016}} The visa mandate was later overturned by the EU in 1996. The [[Spanish Navy]] deployed the {{sclass-|Serviola|patrol boat}} ''Atalaya'' to protect its country's fishing vessels. The Spanish Navy also prepared a surface task group with frigates and tankers, but Spain eventually decided against sending it. Negotiations ceased on March 25, and the following day, Canadian ships cut the nets of the Spanish trawler ''Pescamero Uno''. The Spanish Navy responded by deploying a second patrol boat. Canadian warships and patrol planes in the vicinity were authorized by Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chrétien to fire on Spanish vessels that exposed their guns. Direct negotiations between the EU and Canada eventually restarted, and a deal was reached on April 5. Spain, however, rejected it, demanding better terms. After Canada threatened to forcibly remove Spanish fishing vessels, the EU pressured Spain into finally reaching a settlement on April 15. Canada reimbursed the $500,000 that had been paid for ''Estai''{{'}}s release, repealed the CFPR provision that allowed the arrest of Spanish vessels, and a reduction of Canada's own Turbot allocation. A new international regime to observe EU and Canadian fishing vessels was also created.[http://www.cda-cdai.ca/cdai/uploads/cdai/2009/04/sneyd05.pdf cda-cdai.ca: "Fighting over fish: A look at the 1995 Canada-Spain Turbot War"]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} (Sneyd, 2005) The dispute raised Brian Tobin's political profile, helping to preserve his political career in Newfoundland at a time when federal politicians were being increasingly vilified. It also led to his decision in 1996 to pursue to the leadership of the [[Liberal Party of Newfoundland and Labrador|Liberal Party of Newfoundland]] following the resignation of [[List of Newfoundland and Labrador premiers|premier]] [[Clyde Wells]], as well as a widely discussed future possibility for leadership of the [[Liberal Party of Canada]]. ==The ''Newlyn'' incident== Although Spain was getting political support from the EU (including naval support from Germany among others), the United Kingdom and [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] supported Canada.[http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.ca/en/article/fish-war-ends/ thecanadianencyclopedia.ca "Fish War Ends"](reprint of a 24 April 1995 article from [[Maclean's]]) The then prime-minister [[John Major]] risked his status within the EU community by actively speaking out against Spain. Because of this, some British fishing boats took to flying Canadian flags to show their support. This brought the conflict to European waters when a [[Cornwall|Cornish]] fishing boat, ''Newlyn'', then flying the Canadian flag, was arrested by a French ship that believed it to be Canadian. This dragged Britain from its position of passive backing into full support of the Canadians. Overnight, Canadian flags began to fly from all manner of British and Irish vessels.[http://base.d-p-h.info/fr/fiches/premierdph/fiche-premierdph-3975.html "The Turbot War – UK and Ireland support Canada"] (Sharma, ICSF) The rest of the EU rallied behind France and Spain, but hesitated to make any mobilizations against the British, Irish, or Canadians. Upon hearing the news of the conflict, [[Iceland]] spoke up and took the side of the EU against Britain in light of their similar clash with the British, known as the [[Cod Wars]]. As with the EU, no military mobilization took place. Iceland tried to put political pressure on the United Kingdom and Ireland.[https://www.jstor.org/pss/3551905 "The Canada-European Union Turbot War: A Brief Game Theoretic Analysis"] by Missios and Plourde (Canadian Public Policy Journal, Vol. 22, No. 2 Jun., 1996, pp. 144–150) The British and the Irish pointedly ignored these actions and continued their unquestioned support of Brian Tobin and the Canadians. In the end ''Newlyn'' was returned to the British without further incident. ==See also== *[[1993 Cherbourg incident]] *[[Cod Wars]] *[[Lobster War]] ==References== ===Footnotes=== {{Reflist|30em}} ===Works cited=== {{refbegin}} *Barry, Donald, Applebaum, Bob, and Wiseman, Earl (2014). "Fishing for a Solution: Canada’s Fisheries Relations with the European Union, 1977–2013." Calgary: University of Calgary Press. {{ISBN|978-1-55238-778-8}}. http://uofcpress.com/books/9781552387788. *Barry, D., B. Applebaum and E. Wiseman (2014). “How Europe Came Close to Killing the Atlantic Fishery.” iPolitics, 21 October 2014. URL: http://www.ipolitics.ca/2014/10/ 21/how-Europe-came-close-to-killing-the-atlantic-fishery/. *Gough, Adam (2009). "The Turbot War: the Arrest of the Spanish Vessel Estai and Its Implications for Canada-EU relations." Ottawa: University of Ottawa, Master’s dissertation. 2009. http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/obj/thesescanada/vol2/002/MR61207.PDF. *{{cite book |title=Iron Man: The Defiant Reign of Jean Chrétien |last=Martin |first=Lawrence |year=2003 |publisher=Penguin Group (Canada) |location=Toronto |isbn=0-670-04310-9 }} {{refend}} ==External links== *[https://archive.is/20130418064225/http://econpapers.hhs.se/article/cppissued/v_3A22_3Ay_3A1996_3Ai_3A2_3Ap_3A144-150.htm Game Theory and the Turbot War] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090507210004/http://www.lavozdegalicia.es/hemeroteca/2005/03/12/3542428.shtml ''El día que Canadá y España vivieron su guerra del Fletán''. La voz de Galicia] {{es}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3RWP-a01hSs&context=C3515b35UDOEgsToPDskIEVWGB45N3BaJLFDFUSiLk For Cod and Country] Spoof song based on Turbot War performed by Cultus Cod at Spring Scream 1995, Kenting, Taiwan. {{fishing history}} {{1995 shipwrecks}} [[Category:Military history of Newfoundland and Labrador]] [[Category:Law of the sea]] [[Category:1995 in Canada]] [[Category:1995 in Spain]] [[Category:History of fishing]] [[Category:Battles and conflicts without fatalities]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1995]] [[Category:Conflicts in 1995]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1996]] [[Category:Fishing conflicts]] [[Category:Fisheries law]] [[Category:Fishing in Canada]] [[Category:International maritime incidents]] [[Category:1990s in Newfoundland and Labrador]]

revision.comment: Removing [[:c:File:John_Rees-Evans_(cropped).png|John_Rees-Evans_(cropped).png]], it has been deleted from Commons by [[:c:User:Ronhjones|Ronhjones]] because: [[:c:COM:L|Copyright violation]]: https://www.facebook.com/johndavidreesevans/photos/a.633615870
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox Election | election_name = UK Independence Party leadership election, November 2016 | country = United Kingdom | flag_image = Logo_of_UKIP.svg | type = presidential | ongoing = no | turnout = 46.9% ({{decrease}}7.6%) | previous_election = UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016 | previous_year = September 2016 | election_date = 28 November 2016 | next_election = UK Independence Party leadership election, 2017 | next_year = 2017 | 1blank =Popular vote | 1data1 = '''9,622''' | colour1 = 70147A | image1 = [[File:Paul Nuttal 2014 (cropped).jpg|x150px]] | candidate1 = '''[[Paul Nuttall]]''' | running_mate1 = '''[[Peter Whittle (politician)|Peter Whittle]]''' | percentage1 = '''62.6%''' <!-- --> | colour2 = 70147A | image2 = [[File:Suzanne Evans Chatham House Special Debate (cropped).jpg|x150px]] | candidate2 = [[Suzanne Evans]] | running_mate2 = – | percentage2 = 19.3% | 1data2 = 2,973 <!-- --> | image3 = | candidate3 = [[John Rees-Evans]] | running_mate3 = – | percentage3 = 18.1% | 1data3 = 2,775 | colour3 = 70147A | title = Leader | posttitle = Leader after election | before_election = [[Nigel Farage]] (''interim''); previously [[Diane James]] (''leader-elect'') | after_election = [[Paul Nuttall]] }} {{United Kingdom in the European Union}}
The '''November 2016 UK Independence Party leadership election''' took place following the announcement on 4 October 2016 by [[Diane James]], the leader-elect of the [[UK Independence Party]], that she would not accept the leadership of the party, despite winning the [[UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016|leadership election]] 18 days earlier.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37558485|title=UKIP leader Diane James standing down after 18 days|publisher=BBC News|date=5 October 2016|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37559186|title=UKIP turmoil returns after Diane James resignation|publisher=BBC News|date=5 October 2016|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref> [[Nigel Farage]], whom James was to succeed after the previous leadership election following his resignation, was selected the next day to serve as interim leader.<ref name="FarageInterim">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37561065|title=Nigel Farage steps back in at UKIP as Diane James quits|publisher=BBC News|date=5 October 2016|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref>
On 28 November 2016, former deputy leader [[Paul Nuttall]] was announced as the new leader of the UK Independence Party with 63% of the vote.
==Background== The party was seen as having two major factions. On one side were those who backed [[Nigel Farage]]; in [[UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016|the previous leadership contest]] these had favoured [[Steven Woolfe]], and then, when he was not nominated, [[Diane James]]. On the other were those who wanted a more collegiate party, including figures like [[Suzanne Evans]], the party's only MP [[Douglas Carswell]] and its former director of communications [[Patrick O'Flynn]]; this group had supported Lisa Duffy in the previous election.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37584412|title=Where did it all go wrong for UKIP?|publisher=BBC News|last=Stamp|first=Gavin|date=7 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
Woolfe was seen by many as the favourite in the election.<ref>{{cite web|author=Matthew Smith Data journalist at YouGov |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/matthew-smith3/steven-woolfe-ukip-leader_b_12536034.html |title=Woolfe Was Firm Members' Favourite For Ukip Leader Before Quitting Party |publisher=Huffington Post |date=18 October 2016|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref> He admitted he had considered defecting to the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] following the previous leadership election; an argument concerning this with his MEP colleagues at a meeting in the [[European Parliament]] resulted in an altercation with [[Mike Hookem]], after which Woolfe collapsed and had to be hospitalised. He claimed Hookem had punched him, an accusation denied by Hookem. A few days later, on 17 October 2016, Woolfe withdrew his candidacy and quit UKIP, describing the party as ungovernable without Farage as leader.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/steven-woolfe-quits-ungovernable-ukip-a3371491.html|title=Steven Woolfe: Ukip MEP quits party following Mike Hookem altercation|publisher=''[[London Evening Standard]]''|last=Simpson|first=Fiona|date=18 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref>
The party's National Executive Committee was expected to meet on 10 October 2016 to set a date and rules for the leadership election, but later rescheduled the meeting to 17 October.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ukip-leadership-contest-steven-woolfe-breitbart-editor-first-declare-bids-1585130|title=Ukip leadership contest: Steven Woolfe and Breitbart editor first to declare bids|publisher=[[International Business Times|International Business Times UK]]|last=Silvera|first=Ian|date=6 October 2016|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://order-order.com/2016/10/12/ukip-leadership-runners-and-riders/|title=UKIP Leader Runners & Riders|publisher=[[Paul Staines|Guido Fawkes]]|date=12 October 2016|accessdate=12 October 2016}}</ref> While party chairman Paul Oakden initially mooted that the election could be delayed until 2017,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/politics/balance-must-be-found-between-immigration-and-economic-success-a3370906.html|title=Jeremy Hunt says 'balance must be found between immigration and economic success'|publisher=''[[London Evening Standard]]''|last=Murphy|first=Joe|date=17 October 2016|accessdate=18 October 2016}}</ref> the NEC opened nominations on 17 October, to close at midday on 31 October. Hustings were expected in early November, and ballots were to be sent out on 11 November. The result was to be announced on 28 November.<ref name="warnes1">{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/722155/Ukip-to-have-new-leader-by-November-28th-NEC-confirms|title=Ukip to have new leader in place by November 28th, NEC confirms|last=Warnes|first=Indra|date=17 October 2016|publisher=''[[Daily Express]]''|accessdate=17 October 2016}}</ref>
==Campaign== On 7 October, Woolfe and [[Raheem Kassam]] announced their intent to run for the leadership.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37682828|title=MEP Woolfe quits 'death spiral' UKIP|date=17 October 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37570023|title=UKIP's Steven Woolfe and Raheem Kassam to stand for leadership|date=5 October 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Woolfe was seen as favourite to succeed Diane James, following his failure to submit his nomination in time for the previous leadership election.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/06/ukip-leadership-favourite-steven-woolfe--in-serious-condition-af/|title=Steven Woolfe collapse: Ukip leadership favourite in hospital after clash with colleague, as Nigel Farage says it was 'one of those things that happens between men'|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Woolfe's campaign message was that UKIP had to "stand up for the ignored working class and secure a radically different political landscape in Britain".<ref name=":0" /> On 6 October, Woolfe had been hospitalised following an altercation with fellow MEP Mike Hookem at the European Parliament. On 17 October, Woolfe withdrew from the contest and left UKIP, claiming the party was in a "death spiral".<ref name=":0" /> Party chairman Paul Oakden stated this was "regrettable", and former party leader Nigel Farage said it was "unfortunate".<ref name=":0" />
Kassam, who given Woolfe's withdrawal was expected to be the first ethnic minority candidate for the UKIP leadership, stated that he was the person to end "corruption" at the top of the party and heal the party divides.<ref name=":1" /> He sought to address cultural and social divisions across the country by eliminating [[Islamism in the United Kingdom|Islamism]] in schools, prisons, and neighbourhoods.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/RaheemKassam |title=Raheem Kassam (@RaheemKassam) |publisher=Twitter |date=21 March 2010 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> He was criticised by ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' for his past comments on social media; for example, when he told people with whom he had disagreed on [[Twitter]] to "fuck off". Moreover, the language used to describe the transgender community caused disputes both internally and externally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metroweekly.com/?p=117243|title=UKIP leadership candidate accused BBC of "tranny-pushing" - Metro Weekly|website=www.metroweekly.com|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/raheem-kassam-ukip-leadership-election-twitter-deleted_uk_580cf387e4b056572d82f392|title=Ukip Leadership Contender Raheem Kassam Sparks Outrage For History Of Controversial Twitter Posts|date=23 October 2016|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref> He openly referred to himself as "[[Islamophobia in the United Kingdom|Islamophobe]] of the Year" in 2014, and advertised 'Brits for Trump' shirts that he said he had made in response to requests.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/ukips-biggest-donor-backs-a-former-aide-to-nigel-farage-to-be-the-next-party-leader-a7375841.html|title=Ukip's biggest donor backs a former aide to Nigel Farage to be leader|date=22 October 2016|newspaper=The Independent|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Promoting himself as a "straight-talking" candidate, some of his tweets and social presence had been strongly condemned, including a derogatory comment following Scottish First Minister [[Nicola Sturgeon]]'s miscarriage in 2014.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/raheem-kassam-ukip-leadership-election-twitter-deleted_uk_580cf387e4b056572d82f392|title=Ukip's 'Frontrunner' For Leader Is Sparking Outrage For This Now-Deleted Post|date=23 October 2016|newspaper=The Huffington Post|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Rival candidate Suzanne Evans criticised him as "far right", whilst Nigel Farage responded, calling her "poisonous".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-10-23/ukips-raheem-kassam-hits-out-at-rival-suzanne-evans-over-far-right-label/|title=Ukip's Raheem Kassam hits out at rival Suzanne Evans over 'far right' label - ITV News|date=23 October 2016|publisher=Itv.com|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37799679|title='Farage-ist' Raheem Kassam launches UKIP leadership bid|date=28 October 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=28 October 2016}}</ref> As the self-described "Farage-ist" candidate, his ideas on the party's future included introducing the position of party [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] so the party can be "run like an organisation". Kassam's key message had been to prevent UKIP moving to the "squishy centre ground".<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
On 12 October, the leader of UKIP in the [[London Assembly]], [[Peter Whittle (British politician)|Peter Whittle]], announced his candidacy,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/720535/Peter-Whittle-UKIP-leadership-bid|title=Peter Whittle announces UKIP leadership bid|last=Maddox|first=David|date=12 October 2016|newspaper=Express.co.uk|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> promising, if elected, to ensure [[Brexit]] is delivered. He further pledged that if UKIP under his leadership were to form a government, a priority would be ensuring national pride across the UK. Whittle proposed schools fly the [[Union Jack]], a statement that angered some groups.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2015/jan/22/ukip-fly-union-jack-at-schools|title=Ukip culture spokesman urges schools to fly union flag to promote Britishness|last=Mason|first=Rowena|date=22 January 2015|last2=correspondent|first2=political|newspaper=The Guardian|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref>
[[John Rees-Evans]], a former [[British Army]] soldier, declared his candidacy on 17 October.<ref>{{Citation|title=UKIP leadership: John Rees-Evans declares|date=24 October 2016|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37756167|language=en-GB|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> He pledged to ensure that the UK left the EU, and said the government ought to be reduced in size and function. He stated his belief that the current "political class" in Westminster was detached from citizens, and pledged to make politics more transparent and open if elected UKIP leader. Rees-Evans caused controversy in 2014 when he claimed that a "gay donkey tried to rape my horse". He later clarified his comments as "playful banter with a mischievous activist" and apologised.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/ukip-leadership-candidate-john-rees-evans-admits-mistake-of-claiming-gay-donkey-raped-his-horse_uk_580df412e4b0fce107d142b3|title=Ukip Leadership Candidate Admits Mistake Of Claiming 'Gay Donkey Raped His Horse'|date=24 October 2016|newspaper=The Huffington Post|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref>
A few days later, on 18 October, fellow AM [[David Kurten]] announced his intention to stand. His policies include protecting the [[green belt]], banning [[Sharia|Sharia law]],<ref>{{Citation|last=UKIP GLA|title=David Kurten AM addressing the issue of Sharia on London's Streets|date=14 September 2016|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LUpwBPMTIhg&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> scrapping [[High Speed 2|HS2]], [[Crossrail 2]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/davidkurten/status/783029618290860032 |title=David Kurten on Twitter: "Tories pretending to be @UKIP but will not protect green belt & waste £ billions on HS2, Heathrow expansion, Crossrail 2 + wind farms." |publisher=Twitter.com |date=3 October 2016 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> and a third runway at [[Heathrow Airport|Heathrow]], introducing [[proportional representation]] for general elections in the UK, and making the [[House of Lords]] a fully elected, smaller second chamber.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.davidkurten.net/policies|title=David Kurten|website=David Kurten|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref>
Two significant UKIP politicians, [[Paul Nuttall]] (former deputy leader) and Suzanne Evans (former deputy chair of UKIP and director of policy for the party, before being expelled following the 2015 general election) entered the contest on 23 October.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37744003|title=Suzanne Evans and Paul Nuttall run for UKIP leadership|date=23 October 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Nuttall described himself as the "unity candidate" for the party, able to "bring the factions together."<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=http://www.paulnuttallmep.com/|title=Paul Nuttall MEP {{!}} UKIP MEP for the North West of England {{!}} UKIP Member of the European Parliament for the North West of England|website=www.paulnuttallmep.com|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Nuttall's message was that UKIP could become the patriotic face of the working class, something shared by Kassam and Whittle. He said that UKIP could fill the "political gap vacated by what’s left of the Labour party" under [[Jeremy Corbyn]], who had "abandon[ed] his principles" over the EU, and promised to hold the government accountable over immigration. His key campaign message was to unify the party and to make the party the true "voice of the common man and woman".<ref name=":4" />
Evans’ message was party "detoxification".<ref name=":3" /> She is a member of the party faction that favours more centrist conservative views; her priorities for leadership included ensuring that the 1972 [[European Communities Act 1972 (UK)|European Communities Act]] is repealed by the UK government, ensuring that UKIP led the [[Electoral Reform Society|electoral reform]] process, and bolstering the current [[First May ministry|Conservative government's]] stance on law and order.<ref name=":5">{{Citation|title=UKIP's Suzanne Evans on leadership and party future|date=21 October 2016|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37724681|language=en-GB|accessdate=27 October 2016}}</ref> Evans caused some disruption with her pledge to end the "Trump-styled rhetoric" in the party. This was seen by some, including former party leader Nigel Farage, as an indirect swipe at Raheem Kassam's campaign (whose logo was ‘Make UKIP Great Again’ similar to the ‘[[Make America Great Again]]’ of [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Donald Trump's 2016 presidential campaign]]). Evans has previously stated that she wished to see the UK's defence budget increased, foreign aid budget and energy bills reduced and corporate tax avoiders held accountable for their actions.<ref name=":5" />
Evans appeared on ITV's ''[[The Agenda with Tom Bradby|The Agenda]]'' on 26 October, where she was criticised by fellow panellist [[Jeremy Paxman]] over whether she had "compassion" regarding [[Migrants around Calais|child refugees in Calais]]. She replied "of course I have compassion, but this system is being abused here, it's quite obvious" in reference to some refugees, who have claimed to be children but who are believed by some to be grown adults.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/26/have-you-no-compassion-jeremy-paxman-tackles-ukip-leadership-con/|title='Have you no compassion?' Jeremy Paxman tackles Ukip leadership contender Suzanne Evans after she backs physical checks on child migrants|newspaper=The Telegraph|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref>
Two candidates formally withdrew from the contest: Andrew Beadle on 13 October<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/Andy_Beadle/status/790993884146987008 |title=Andrew Beadle on Twitter: "A Statement: After due thought and consideration I have decided to windup my UKIP Leadership campaign and... https://t.co/3elkvJNgyj" |publisher=Twitter.com |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=28 October 2016}}</ref> and [[Bill Etheridge]] (who had come third in the previous leadership election) on 26 October.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-37757628|title=UKIP contender Bill Etheridge quits leadership race|date=25 October 2016|newspaper=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=27 October 2016}}</ref> Both argued that Paul Nuttall would be the most suitable candidate for leader, able to unify the party and help it move onto more “fertile ground.”<ref name=":6" /> On 30 October, David Kurten withdrew from the race; praising his fellow candidates, he stated that he would be "happy to work with any of the remaining candidates... on ensuring Brexit is delivered."<ref name="twitter1">{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/davidkurten/status/792697612415664128 |title=David Kurten on Twitter: "Statement on UKIP Leadership Contest https://t.co/gBfDMCRLL6" |publisher=Twitter.com |date=30 October 2016 |accessdate=30 October 2016}}</ref>
A 25 October survey of 91 UKIP councillors for ''[[The Times]]'' found 42% supported Nuttall and 22% Evans. Others receiving support were Raheem Kassam (9%), Douglas Carswell and Lisa Duffy (5% each), Patrick O'Flynn (4%), Bill Etheridge (2%) and Peter Whittle (1%). 8% said none of the above.<ref name="thetimes1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/nuttall-zooms-ahead-in-ukip-leadership-race-kdf8btgzq|title=Nuttall zooms ahead in Ukip leadership race|access-date=26 October 2016}}</ref>
Kassam withdrew from the contest, endorsing Peter Whittle, on 31 October.<ref name="theguardian1">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/blog/live/2016/oct/31/nhs-spending-will-fall-on-a-per-head-basis-before-2020-says-health-committee-chair-politics-live?page=with:block-5817114ae4b01c528432e89a#block-5817114ae4b01c528432e89a |title=Raheem Kassam withdraws from Ukip leadership contest |publisher=The Guardian |date=2016-10-31 |accessdate=2016-10-31}}</ref>
==Candidates==
===Declared=== * [[Suzanne Evans]], Co-Deputy Chair of UKIP (2014–2016), candidate for [[Shrewsbury and Atcham (UK Parliament constituency)|Shrewsbury and Atcham]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 2015|2015 general election]]<ref name="EvansNuttall">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-politics-37744003|title=Suzanne Evans and Paul Nuttall both run for UKIP leadership|publisher=BBC News|date=23 October 2016|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="TheContenders"/><ref name="TheContenders2"/> * [[Paul Nuttall]], Leader of UKIP in the [[European Parliament]]; former Deputy Leader of UKIP (2010–2016); [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] for [[North West England (European Parliament constituency)|North West England]], candidate for [[Bootle (UK Parliament constituency)|Bootle]] in 2015<ref name="EvansNuttall"/><ref name="TheContenders"/><ref name="TheContenders2">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/05/ukip-leadership-contest-steven-woolfe-raheem-kassam-paul-nuttall-suzanne-evans-lisa-duffy|title=Ukip leadership contest: five likely contenders to succeed Diane James|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|last=Mason|first=Rowena|date=5 October 2016|accessdate=9 October 2016}}</ref> * [[John Rees-Evans]], candidate for [[Cardiff South and Penarth (UK Parliament constituency)|Cardiff South and Penarth]] in 2015<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/politics/724556/John-Rees-Evans-ukip-leadership-contest-nigel-farage|title=John Rees-Evans announces decision to run for UKIP leadership|publisher=''[[Daily Express]]''|date=24 October 2016|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>

==Previous endorsements==
===Steven Woolfe=== '''MEPs''' * [[Nigel Farage]], interim Leader of UKIP; former Leader of UKIP (2006–2009; 2010–2016); MEP for [[South East England (European Parliament constituency)|South East England]]<ref name="FarageandBanksforWoolfe">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/06/ukip-leadership-favourite-steven-woolfe--in-serious-condition-af/|title=Steven Woolfe collapse: Ukip leadership favourite in hospital after clash with colleague, as Nigel Farage says it was 'one of those things that happens between men'|last2=Bennett|first2=Asa|date=7 October 2016|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|last3=Hope|first3=Christopher|last4=Swinford|first4=Steven|last5=Chazan|first5=David|last1=Hughes|first1=Laura|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref> Farage, saying he had not intended to endorse any of the candidates, said he would not be voting for Evans in response.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/news/2016-10-23/ukip-leadership-nigel-farage-suzanne-evans-peston-on-sunday/|title=Nigel Farage 'will not vote for Suzanne Evans' as Ukip leader after 'toxic' comments|date=23 October 2016|publisher=ITV News|accessdate=24 October 2016}}</ref>
'''Other people''' * [[Arron Banks]], businessman; co-founder of the [[Leave.EU]] campaign; prominent UKIP donor<ref name="FarageandBanksforWoolfe"/>
=== Raheem Kassam: 'Make UKIP Great Again.' === * [[Arron Banks]], businessman; co-founder of the [[Leave.EU]] campaign; prominent UKIP donor (previously endorsed Steven Woolfe)<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2016/oct/22/ukip-donor-backs-former-nigel-farage-aide-as-party-leader|title=Ukip donor Arron Banks backs Raheem Kassam for party leadership|date=22 October 2016|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref>
=== Peter Whittle: 'Win with Whittle.' === * [[Raheem Kassam]], withdrawn candidate for Leader, Editor of [[Breitbart]] London, former senior advisor to [[Nigel Farage]].
==Timeline== *4 October: [[Diane James]] stands down as leader, triggering a new contest *7 October: [[Steven Woolfe]] and [[Raheem Kassam]] both announce their candidacies *12 October: [[Peter Whittle (British politician)|Peter Whittle]] announces his candidacy *17 October: Nominations open; Woolfe resigns from UKIP; [[John Rees-Evans]] announces his candidacy *18 October: [[David Kurten]] announces his candidacy *20 October: Andrew Beadle announces his candidacy *23 October: [[Paul Nuttall]] and [[Suzanne Evans]] both announce their candidacies *24 October: [[Bill Etheridge]] withdraws his candidacy and endorses Nuttall *25 October: Andrew Beadle withdraws his candidacy and endorses Nuttall *30 October: David Kurten withdraws his candidacy *31 October: Raheem Kassam withdraws his candidacy and endorses Whittle *4 November: Peter Whittle withdraws his candidacy and endorses Nuttall
==Opinion polling==
Some of the polls below include people who will not be candidates. Polls show both free choices among all candidates and constrained choices among particular pairs of candidates. {| style="text-align:center" class="wikitable sortable" |+ |- ! style="width:150px;" |<small>Poll source</small> ! style="width:150px;" |<small>Date(s)<br /> administered</small> ! <small>Sample<br />size</small> | <small>'''[[Jonathan Arnott|Jonathan<br />Arnott]]''' | <small>'''Phillip<br />Broughton''' | <small>'''[[Douglas Carswell|Douglas<br />Carswell]]''' | <small>'''Lisa<br />Duffy''' | <small>'''[[Bill Etheridge|Bill<br />Etheridge]]''' | <small>'''[[Suzanne Evans|Suzanne<br />Evans]]''' | <small>'''[[Nigel Farage|Nigel<br />Farage]]''' | <small>'''[[Nathan Gill|Nathan<br />Gill]]''' | <small>'''[[Neil Hamilton (politician)|Neil<br />Hamilton]]''' | <small>'''Elizabeth<br />Jones''' | <small>'''[[Raheem Kassam|Raheem<br />Kassam]]''' |<small>'''[[Paul Nuttall]]'''</small> |[[Peter Whittle (British politician)|<small>'''Peter Whittle'''</small>]] | <small>'''[[Steven Woolfe|Steven<br />Woolfe]]''' | <small>'''Other/<br />Undecided'''</small> |- |[[The Times]], Red Box surveys<ref name="thetimes1"/> |<small>25 October 2016</small> |<small>91 UKIP councillors</small> |– |– |5% |5% |2% |22% |– |– |– |0% |9% | {{party shading/UKIP}} align="center" | '''42%''' |1% |– |<small>None of the above 8%</small> <small>'''[[Patrick O'Flynn]]''' 4%</small>
<small>'''[[David Kurten]]''', '''Andrew Beadle, John Rees-Evans''' 0%</small> |- | || data-sort-value="2016-06-23" |<small>17 October 2016</small>|| colspan="16" | <small>'''Nominations open, [[Steven Woolfe]] resigns from UKIP.'''</small> |- | rowspan="2" |[[YouGov]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://d25d2506sfb94s.cloudfront.net/cumulus_uploads/document/kdyxlfbd4m/InternalResults_161014_UKIPMembers_W_StevenWoolfe.pdf|title=YouGov Survey Results|date=5–14 October 2016|publisher=YouGov}}</ref> | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2" | <small>5–14 October 2016</small> | style="text-align:center;" rowspan="2" | <small>1,003 UKIP members</small>{{efn|name=UKIP1|Eligible members of UKIP.}} | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| 1% | style="text-align:center;"| 3% | style="text-align:center;"| 4% | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| 7% | style="text-align:center;"| 31% | style="text-align:center;"| 1% | style="text-align:center;"| 1% | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| – |– |– | {{party shading/UKIP}} align="center" | '''37%''' | style="text-align:center;"| <small>Don't know 8%</small><br><small>None of the above 3%</small> |- | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| 1% | style="text-align:center;"| 5% | style="text-align:center;"| 5% | style="text-align:center;"| 3% | style="text-align:center;"| 10% | style="text-align:center;"| – | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| 2% | style="text-align:center;"| – |– |– | {{party shading/UKIP}} align="center" | '''47%''' | style="text-align:center;"| <small>Don't know 16%</small><br><small>None of the above 4%</small> |}
==Results==
[[Paul Nuttall]] was elected Leader with 62.6% of the vote.
32,757 ballot papers were issued and 15,370 members voted in the contest, a turnout of 47%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-politics-38125432 |title=Paul Nuttall elected as UKIP leader |publisher=BBC News |date=2016-11-28 |accessdate=2016-11-29}}</ref> This was a drop in turnout from the [[UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016|September leadership election]], which saw 17,842 members cast a ballot, a turnout of approximately 54%.
{| border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background:#e9e9e9;" ! colspan="5"|UK Independence Party leadership election, November 2016 |- style="background:#e9e9e9;" ! colspan="2" style="width: 190px"|Candidate ! colspan="2" style="width: 100px"|Votes ! style="width: 40px"| % |- ! style="background-color: {{UK Independence Party/meta/color}}" | | style="width: 230px" | {{Y}} '''[[Paul Nuttall]]''' | style="text-align:right;"| ''' 9,622 ''' | align=center | {{percentage bar|62.6||70147A}} | style="text-align:right;"| '''62.6%''' |- ! style="background-color: {{UK Independence Party/meta/color}}" | | style="width: 230px" | [[Suzanne Evans]] | style="text-align:right;"| 2,973 | align=center | {{percentage bar|19.3||70147A}} | style="text-align:right;"| 19.3% |- ! style="background-color: {{UK Independence Party/meta/color}}" | | style="width: 230px" | [[John Rees-Evans]] | style="text-align:right;"| 2,775 | align=center | {{percentage bar|18.1||70147A}} | style="text-align:right;"| 18.1% |- style="background:#f6f6f6; text-align:right;" | colspan="3"|'''Turnout''' || ''' 15,370''' || '''46.9%''' |- style="background:#f6f6f6;" | colspan="5" | '''Paul Nuttall elected as leader {{Y}}''' |}
==See also== * [[Conservative Party (UK) leadership election, 2016]] * [[Green Party of England and Wales leadership election, 2016]] * [[Labour Party (UK) leadership election, 2016]] * [[UK Independence Party leadership election, September 2016]] * [[List of UK Independence Party leaders]]

revision.comment: /* Vancouver International Burlesque Festival Association (VIBFA) */ Lower case
revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=June 2014}} {{refimprove|date=June 2014}} }} {{infobox theatre festival | theatre_festival_name =Vancouver International Burlesque Festival | image = [[File:Sex At The Circus Burlesque 09.jpg|250px]] | caption = Performers onstage at the 2011 VIBF. | location = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia|B.C.]] | country = [[Canada]] | status = Active | frequency = Annual | genre = Festivals | playtype = Burlesque, neo-burlesque, vaudeville | dates = May 6–7, 2016 | founded = 2006 | founders = Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society,
Sweet Soul Burlesque Ltd. | website = http://www.vibf.ca/ }} The '''Vancouver International Burlesque Festival''' is an annual four-day festival that takes place every spring in [[Vancouver, BC]]. The festival features burlesque performers, comedians and musicians. The 2017 festival showcases will be held at the [[Vancouver Playhouse (theatre venue)]] on March 31 & April 1, with Tit Talks at The Post at 750 on March 30, and The Diamonds in the Buff Industry awards on March 29. The 2018 festival dates will be April 4 - 7.{{cite web|url=http://www.vibf.ca/|title=VIBF 2016 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} == History == The first festival took place in February 2006 and was founded by two local troupes; The Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society {{cite web|url=https://iliveineastvan.com/2013/06/28/taboo-revue-burlesque-variety-show-at-wise-hall-sat-june-29th/ |title=Taboo Revue Burlesque Variety Show At Wise Hall Sat. June 29th |work=iliveineastvan.com |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} and Sweet Soul Burlesque.{{cite web|last=Conner |first=Sean|url=http://www.insidevancouver.ca/2013/01/22/sweet-soul-burlesque-10th-anniversary/ |title=VANCOUVER TROUPE SWEET SOUL BURLESQUE CELEBRATES ITS 10TH ANNIVERSARY |work=Inside Vancouver |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=10 February 2016}} Performances were held at the Red Room, the Chinese Cultural Center and the [[New Westminster#Arts and culture|Burr Theatre]]. Festival production was returned to the community, leading to the founding of the Vancouver International Burlesque Festival Association (VIBFA).{{cite web|url=http://vibf.ca/about-us/|title=Our Team |accessdate=10 February 2016}} Success of the first festival led to an expanded second year featuring two stages and workshops. The new event platform included cross-collaboration opportunities and workshops, and produced events such as movie nights, discussion panels and fashion shows focusing on the art of [[neo-burlesque]]. The 2008 Festival ran for ten days, and attracted over 100 singers, dancers, comedians, musicians, filmmakers, and costume designers from around the world. == Vancouver International Burlesque Festival Association (VIBFA) == The VIBFA is a not-for-profit elected board whose primary goal is to produce a festival that focuses on the Vancouver burlesque scene and the world of burlesque on an international level. === 2017 VIBFA Board === * Norm Elmore - President * Ava Lure - Vice-President * Dee Lushious - Secretary * Diamond Minx - Treasurer * Just Call Her Heather - Production Member, Director of Marketing * David Kerr - Production Member, Production Manager * Faye Havoc - Production Member, Spokesperson == Venues == Past venues include the [[Rio Theatre]] and the [[Vogue Theatre]]. The 2016 festival will take place at the Vancouver Playhouse. == Performers == Past notable performers include [[Jo Weldon|Jo Boobs]] (New York City, New York) and Burlesque Hall of Fame inductee [[Judith Stein (burlesque)|Judith Stein]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Vancouver International Burlesque festival}} * [http://vibf.ca Vancouver International Burlesque Festival Association] * [http://www.sweetsoulburlesque.ca/index.html Sweet Soul Burlesque] * [http://screamingchicken.net Screaming Chicken Theatrical Society] * [http://www.flamingoburlesque.com Pink Flamingo Burlesque] [[Category:Festivals in Vancouver]] [[Category:Sex festivals]] [[Category:Burlesque]]

{{ infobox music festival | music_festival_name = Walk the Line Festival | image = | caption = | location = [[Cheltenham]] | years_active = 2009-2011 | founders = | dates = | genre = | website = {{URL|http://www.walkthelinefestival.co.uk/}} }} The '''Walk the Line Festival''' was a music and poetry festival which took place at various venues in [[Cheltenham]], southern [[England]].<ref>[http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/walktheline/ Walk the Line], [http://www.efestivals.co.uk/ efestivals], UK.</ref><ref>[http://www.facebook.com/group.php?gid=59158784994 Walk the Line Festival], [[Facebook]].</ref>
The first Walk the Line festival took place on Friday 30 and Saturday 31 October 2009.<ref>[http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/walktheline/2009/ Walk the Line '09], efestivals, UK.</ref>
==2011 line-up== * [[Ellen and the Escapades]] * [[Beans on Toast]] * Crazy Arm * [[Tellison]] * [[Charlie Baxter]] * [[Swift Maneuver ]] * [[We are The Afterglow]] * [[I The Lion]] * [[Pink Crudge Caravan]] * [[The Peppermint Hunting Lodge]] * [[Miss 600]] * [[Changing Horses (band)|Changing Horses]] * [[Midwest Dilemma]] * [[Jim Wain]] * [[Ellie Dussek]] * [[Tina Lundelius]] * [[Nina Condron]] * [[Joe Noel]] * [[4bel]] * [[Thrill Collins]]
==2010 line-up== * [[Brown Torpedo]] * [[Midnight Mile]] * [[Jim Lockey & The Solemn Sun]] * [[The Dawn Chorus]] * [[David Ford]] * [[Hitchhikers of the Galaxy]] * The Echoes * Reachback * [[Will Kevans]] * [[I Call A Strike]] * [[Che (band)|Che]] * [[Joe Noel]] * [[Pete Taylor]] * [[Gareth Harper]] * [[Thrill Collins]] * [[Dale Campbell]] * Ryan Martin * [[Edd Donovan]] * [[Faded Circus]] * [[My First Tooth]] * [[The Strange Death of Liberal England]] * 6 Day Riot
==2009 line-up== * 8-fold * [[Ben Marwood]] * [[Broadcast 2000]] * Byron Vincent * [[Chris T-T]] * Crazy Arm * Crowns on Rats Orchestra * Fighting Fiction * Lets Tea Party * Oxygen Thief * Post War Years * Sam Isaac * Talons * [[This Town Needs Guns]] * Thrill Collins * [[Tubelord]]
